column2: PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The French Communist party began moving into new headquarters today as part of its modernization process. But a poll indicated that for a large part of the French public, it is still the same old party.
Honeywell, Inc., information systems announced yesterday at Waltham, Mass., that it has raised prices on computer equipment products and services up to 7 1/2 per cent, effective Aug. 1.

A scarecrow image. This is what South Africa's detractors manufactured for that country in the past number of years. The nightmarish image often scares and infuriates peoples and nations to the ends of the earth.

Surplus stocks of American wheat may increase by more than 100 million bushels during the 1971-72 marketing season, economists of the Agriculture Department estimated in a summary of the agency's wheat-situation report, which was released yesterday.
The credit markets tossed aside the implications of costly steel and rail labor settlements and scored a modest advance yesterday.
The first indictment growing out of an investigation of the Municipal Loan Program was returned yesterday against a contractor accused of paying $8,200 in bribes to five public officials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The House ordered today that the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare furnish Congress with information on the extent of school busing to achieve racial balance.
City officials called yesterday for measures to prevent parking violations that impede fire - fighting and jeopardize lives.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Secretary General Thant warned today that a major conflict could break out between India and Pakistan, which "could all too easily expand."

Ellis T. Cox has been elected president of Allis-Chalmers Powers Systems, Inc., an affiliate company of Allis-Chalmers Corporation and Kraftwerk Union of West Germany. He will also continue to serve in his present post as group executive and vice president of the Allis-Chalmers Corporation.

SAO PAULO, Brazil -- Stock market averages soaring 250 per cent in six mouths. Thousands of investors crowding brokerage offices each day with fistfuls of money. And share earnings jumping 50 per cent or more a year.

Directors and management of the Collins Radio Company and the North American Rockwell Corporation approved yesterday a definitive agreement under which North American Rockwell will invest $35-million in a new Class A $5 cumulative convertible preferred stock of Collins.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (AP) -- New fighting was reported today in eastern Cambodia, where 3,500 South Vietnamese infantrymen launched a sweep operation six days ago.
An anonymous caller said before hanging up that Pan American World Airways and its agency, J. Walter Thompson, were coming to a parting of the ways. So calls were placed to both parties.
The National Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday reports that it had new assignments for David Brinkley and John Chancellor on its "N.B.C. Nightly News."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A California dentist and his son were arrested on their yacht by the Coast Guard near Cuba yesterday, and their indictment in connection with aiding draft evaders was announced here today.

William F. Buckley's syndicated column, "On the Right," has been dropped by The Record, a New Jersey newspaper published in Hackensack. The Record explained in an editorial that it had taken the decision because Mr. Buckley had "destroyed the credibility of his own publication" -- National Review, the conservative magazine -- by the publication of false "secret documents."

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The board of the Cunard Steamship Company recommended today acceptance of an offer of $65.5-million to take over the company. The offer was made by Trafalgar House, a huge property group.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- The top leaders of all the Soviet-bloc countries except Rumania held a one-day meeting today and issued a communique denouncing deviations from Moscow's line and expressing "grave alarm" over the antiCommunist campaign in the Sudan.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A finding of contempt of court against Anthony J. Russo, who has refused to testify before a Federal grand jury that is investigating the leak of the Pentagon papers, was affirmed today by a panel of three Federal judges.

In modern times it has become popular on the part of Government officials to condone cover stories (a euphemism for lying) on the supposed ground that the requirements of our Government are superior to the homely virtues that have been taught to us since childhood.
Retail business in New York is holding at a steady level, a survey of leading department stores indicated yesterday.

State Supreme Court Justice Harry B. Frank ruled in a decision published yesterday that residents in publicly aided middleincome housing had no right to secrecy of their state income tax returns because they received what he called "public assistance."
MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Richard E. McDevitt's Sultan's Quest, who has won 13 championships in a row, finished second in three classes today at the Orange County horse show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -The Senate opened debate on campaign spending legislation today with the Nixon Administration and the Democratic leaders at loggerheads over how much candidates should be allowed to devote to radio and television.

John F. Kennedy's senior thesis at Harvard in 1940, which won him academic honors despite his undistinguished grades, generated substantial disagreement in the university's government department at the time.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Britain widened her unofficial lead over the United States, the defending champion, in today's second race of the four-event Admiral's Cup series by placing her three yachts among the top 11 finishers.

A suit seeking to block the Internal Revenue Service and the General Services Administration from establishing a $25-million regional I.R.S. center in the Town of Brookhaven on Long Island because of the lack of low-income, integrated housing in the area was filed today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

Instead of rushing home after their visit to the moon, the Apollo 15 astronauts are spending two more days in lunar orbit, scooping up radioactive particles for analysis and collecting data for physical and chemical maps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Two former military - intelligence agents asserted today that Vietnamese were indiscriminately rounded up, tortured and murdered by Americans in an effort to eliminate Vietcong cadres.

" We all talk about justice," said William V. Shannon for openers, then proceeded to ignore pertinent facts so essential to elementary justice in his piece he calls the "United Mine Workers Mystery" on July 27. He asks, "Why is an Administration pledged to law and order so reluctant to intervene on behalf of ordinary workers against union bosses who treat the U.M.W. as their private preserve?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Rev. Jesse Jackson, director of the Operation Breadbasket arm of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, accused the new United States Postal Service today of job discrimination against blacks.

HAVANA -- When I came to Cuba recently -- my third visit since 1968 -I brought with me a little red book. Not the prescriptions and prophecies of Chairman Mao, but a 22-page pamphlet of the Department of State: "U.S. Policy Toward Cuba."

A group representing most of New York's police commanders has denounced the commission investigating allegations of police corruption and has told its members not to fill out a commission financial report.

HOUSTON, Aug. 2 -- With their lift-off from the moon today the Apollo 15 astronauts have completed what may ultimately be regarded as one of the most triumph and expeditions in the history of geology.

Though New York's Chinese community is predominantly Cantonese-speaking, films in the Mandarin dialect, the official tongue in both Nationalist and mainland China, have all but completely replaced Cantonese movies here over the last five years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -Seven Southern Governors published today brief, dispassionate and generally sanguine statements on race relations.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The newest rage in Paris is the Chinese worker's suit. It has overshadowed perfume, gloves and scarves as the object of tourists' quests along the Faubourg Saint-Honore. Artists, working people and students are already wearing the heavy navy blue cotton suit as a utilitarian garment, and it's likely to be the next big fashion-in-the-street.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 -- A four-hit shutout by Fritz Peterson, a busy night for Horace Clarke at second base, and a well-coordinated attack that produced four runs with two out in the fourth inning gave the New York Yankees a 7-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
Is a seven - hour - and - 46 - minute round trip on a train a "commute"? And is someone who makes the trip twice a week a commuter?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is working on a new rule that would require brokerage firms to make public disclosure of their financial condition and other significant facts, chairman William J. Casey said today.

Some concrete evidence is beginning to emerge from the program developed four years ago by the City Planning Commission to revitalize the theater district by persuading builders to construct playhouses in new office buildings on and around Broadway.

Mrs. Whitney M. Young Jr., speaking softly and with tears often brimming in her eyes, announced yesterday the creation in her husband's memory of a foundation devoted exclusively to training young black leaders in the field of social relations.

Thunderstorms that dumped nearly six inches of rain on the city since Friday gave way to patches of sunshine yesterday, but the effects of the storms lingered on in disrupted telephone service, flooded basements and scattered delays in transit services.

In an editorial of July 14, The Times praised the decision of the House of Representatives to recommit to the Commerce Committee a proposed contemptof-Congress citation against the Columbia Broadcasting System and its president, Dr. Frank Stanton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Justice Department and the Civil Service Commission are considering a proposal that would make it easier for the Government to dismiss employes who belong to "terrorist /revolutionary" organizations.

The Administration has won handsomely its gamble that it could persuade both sides in the long battle over modernizing railroad work rules to settle their dispute without a fresh recourse to Congress for no-strike legislation.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 2 -Western military sources reported today a determined push by the Laotian Army toward the town of Pak Song, a key control point on the Boloven Plateau in the southern panhandle. Pak Song and the plateau were overrun by North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao forces in May.

When the Rev. Margaret Howland began looking for a job as pastor after serving eight years as a minister in other capacities, one of the questions that Presbyterian church officials asked her was whether she would not be embarrassed if the plumbing were to spring a leak and a trustee had to visit her at midnight to repair it.
Fifteen hundred people were evacuated in less than 15 minutes from the 42-story Westvaco Building at 299 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon after a smoky fire broke out in a 16th-floor storage room.

PRAGUE, Aug. 2 -- A simple grave covered with fresh flowers in Prague's Olsany Cemetery, the burial place of Jan Palach, appears to represent the last token of resistance to the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia nearly three years ago.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 2. Tanzania and Uganda are' at ach other's throats diplomatieaHy, but it is the little coun. try of Rwanda that is strangling.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A helicopter pilot testified today that more than 500 eagles were killed from the air in Wyoming and Colorado from last November to February.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The United States officially announced its support today for the seating of mainland China in the United Nations this fall but declared its continued opposition to the expulsion of the Taiwan-based Chinese Nationalist Government.

Thomas R. Wilcox, 54-year-old vice chairman of the First National City Corporation, quit his $144,000-a-year job yesterday "to pursue other business interests." The resignation will be effective Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The two-year draft-extension bill, already in trouble in the Senate, hit a parliamentary standoff in the House tonight, apparently ending chances for Congressional approval before September.

KENT, Ohio, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Dr. Glenn A. Olds, former United States representative to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, was elected today president of Kent State University by the school's board of trustees.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A panel of three Federal judges today upheld a lowercourt ruling reversing the murder conviction of Edgar Smith, who has been on death row longer than anyone in United States history, and gave him the right to apply anew for freedom on bail.

Pele, soccer's premier star, was supposed to be the main attraction in the 2-2 Santos-Depertivo Call match at Yankee Stadium last night, but the show was stolen by a supporting actor on the Santos squad named Edu.

A crowd of about 100 youths went on the rampage in the East Village last night, setting scattered fires in trash cans fire-bombing a passing bus and breaking into two stores, following the arrest of a man carrying .22-caliber pistol by two plainclothes men.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- The Anglican Dean of Johannesburg pleaded not guilty today at the opening of his trial on charges of plotting the violent overthrow of the Government. This was followed by the testimony of a member of the Dean's congregation who had been working for the security police.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The United States, the world's largest consumer of minerals, faces an acute shortage of raw materials in the coming decades, Interior Department officials told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Nixon Administration's housing and community development programs, policies and proposals were strongly defended today by George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

PEKING, Aug. 2 -- China may have the answer to America's problem of overeating and over-weight. Having unsuccessfully tried every slimming formula from Lenten repentance to Joe Alsop's drinking man's diet, I have switched to chopsticks and reached the scientific conclusion that it is impossible no.t to lose weight if you rely on these slippery implements:

HOUSTON, Aug. 2 -- The two moon-exploring astronauts of Apollo 15 blasted off the lunar surface today in the first televised launching from another world, then rejoined their orbiting command ship two hours later.
Most of the nation's major steel producers announced yesterday that they would raise prices by an average of about 8 per cent on nearly all types of steel products.

Why is it so necessary to defend DDT and to resist attempts to ban it? First, let it be clear that saving DDT will not protect the profits of the chemical industry. Quite the contrary. The replacement insecticides cost far more than DDT, which sells for around 17 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -David L. Norman, acting head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, said in a letter today that he had given Attorney General John N. Mitchell a summary of a private report released last month on the Kent State shootings.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 2 -- In a corner of the practice field, John Riggins, the Jets' first-round draft choice, was attending his first class today in Coach Weeb Ewbank's required course for running backs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco told a Senate subcommittee hearing today that a Federal commitment of at least $1-billion for nationwide drug treatment programs was necessary to reverse what he called "the growing menace of narcotics abuse" in the United States.
Discussions these days seem to imply that the only fiscal tool for stimulating the economy is to step up Federal spending.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2 -- A Texas legislative plan for reapportionment of the State House of Representatives was declared unconstitutional today by a State district judge.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 2 -A Nassau County District Court judge has violated the Republican and Democratic parties' ban on cross-endorsements from minor parties and will face a primary fight next month from the major parties.

HOUSTON, Aug. 2 -- While the men of lunar module Falcon roamed the mountains and valleys of the moon, Joseph Percival Allen 4th served as the single human link between them and the hundreds of technicians, engineers and scientists on earth.

A prisoner in the Men's House of Detention here has asked a Senate subcommittee to let him testify that he bribed the secretary of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer with $15,000 in an attempt to avoid a conviction for arson, burglary and grand larceny.

When a company decides to establish a house agency or otherwise bring its advertising creativity "in-house," usually two reasons are offered for the move: It will save money and it will lead to better ads.

If the United States Public Health Service should give up its 636-bed hospital on Staten Island, six private organizations say they are ready to take it over to serve the island's rapidly growing population.

Maurie H. $[ans, the SecreLaly of Commerce, yesterday appointed John L. Jenkins, a black official of the department, to head minority business programs, thus ending a behind-the-scenes struggle over the position.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe of Miami, avenging an upset loss to Nikki Pilic two weeks ago, defeated the tall Yugoslav, 6-4, 6-3, today in the first round of the $50,000 United States pro tennis championships.
WESTBURY L.I., Aug. 2 -William (Buddy) Gilmour, the nation's leading harness driver, was given clearance to drive here again in a surprise move today by Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The essentially flat trend of manufacturers' inventories continued in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

No matter how little validity the domino theory may have in international relations, the bing-bang increase of steel wages and prices leaves no basis for doubt that it is working with chilling inexorability in labor relations.
A police sergeant with 20 years on the force was accused of bribery yesterday after he allegedly tried to shake down the operator of a social club in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 2 -- Sudanese officials said today that their Government had ordered the counselor of the Soviet Embassy and the Bulgarian Ambassador to leave the country.

Ever since publication of the Pentagon papers, Government people have been complaining about the press invading the Government's privacy. "Unthinkable," said an F.B.I. man. "Unthinkable to have a situation where people cannot even write memos in the privacy of Government offices without some newspaper getting hold of the material."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Edward Waskiewoicz's Mr. Ed Stables of Canterbury, Conn., produced two champions and two reserve winners last night as the western section of the Orange County horse show ended.
The text for the day's class was written on the blackboard: "Transform boiled eggs into sparkling chandeliers."

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- British legislators and labor union leaders expressed relief tonight at the Senate's decision, which insures the continued production of the Rolls-Royce RB-211 engine for the Lockheed L-1011 Tristar airbus.
The Boston Red Sox are determined to keep baseball interest in at least one division race.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Diplomats here voiced agreement today that the United States' "support" for seating Communist China in the United Nations, while a major policy development, hardly affected any of the obstacles to Peking's arrival.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- Robert L. Vesco, head of the International Controls Corporation, was reported today to have acquired about 40 per cent of the preferred shares of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., in his fight for control of this mutual-fund complex.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 -- A fourth candidate for South Vietnam's presidential elections has appeared without fanfare here, and some political sources speculate that he is a token rival promoted and helped by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

The Cincinnati Reds, who were in first place by 11 games a year ago, arrived in New York last night in fifth place, 18 games out with a five-game losing streak. But they got prompt, temporary relief when they scored two runs in the ninth inning and defeated the wandering Mets, 4-2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a war powers bill that would require the President to report promptly to Congress when he commits the armed forces to conflict without specific Congressional authorization.

HOUSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Col. David R. Scott dropped a hammer and a feather on the moon from waist high today to illustrate that both objects are accelerated equally by lunar gravity and that both would hit the surface at the same time despite their differences in mass or weight.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 2 -- Sister Margaret Murtha, the Dominican nun who went to jail five days ago for refusing to cooperate in a grand jury murder investigation, was freed today when the case was remanded to Juvenile Court.

Melvin Hatcher, for two years a home-relief recipient while receiving treatment for tuberculosis, cheerfully showed up at the city's Transportation Administration yesterday morning as the first relief recipient referred there for a payless city job under a new state law.

HONOLULU, Aug. 2 -- The Gannett Company, Inc., of Rochester will acquire The Honolulu Star-Bulletin and five other newspapers of the Hawaiibased corporation in an exchange of stock conservativey estimated at more than $27-million.

It is unfortunate that Harry Schwartz's article of July 18 [The Week in Review], inveighing against chiropractic, ignores the people's side of the story and echoes tired old diatribes that should long since have been put to rest.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 2 -- The Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, Joseph J. Sisco, held a second working meeting today with Premier Golda Meir and other top Israeli policymakers, with all the signs suggesting that a new diplomatic initiative to reopen the Suez Canal is being worked out.

A strong finish in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton Sunday night gave victory to Dan Salkoff, Keith Garber, Jay Wendt, Fred Dossenbach and Merle Tom, all of New York, and Frank Mela of Great Neck, L. I.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- The Saratoga racing meeting, a financial shot in the arm to the economy of this region, started its 103d season today with the running of the $34,950 Flash Stakes.

TRENTON, Aug. 2 -- Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that a House Judiciary subcommittee in Washington had agreed to hold a public hearing on a proposed compact approved by New Jersey and New York that would extend the police powers of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to the region s major jetports.

The Coca-Cola Company achieved record second-quarter earnings of $48,660,439, or 82 cents a share, up 14 per cent from the year-earlier $42,453,263, or 72 cents a share, the company reported yesterday from Atlanta.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP) -Ken Harrelson battled a balky putter and struggled to a 76 today in his first brush with professional golf, but the former baseball star promised to break par tomorrow.
Following is a transcript of a news briefing by Secretary of State William P. Rogers in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

State Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader who has been seeking to oust Mayor Lindsay from the party, went to court yesterday and obtained an order requiring the Mayor to show why his enrollment as a Republican should not be nullified.
Mrs. Margaret Smith Court, the world's top-ranking woman tennis player, will not be in the United States Open at Forest Hills, Queens, Sept. 1 through 12.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was yesterday's most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange. A total of 197,000 shares changed hands and the issue fell 7 to close at 55.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 2 -- An experimental employment program began here today in an effort to find new careers for 200 engineers discarded by the shrinking aerospace industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Senate, by a one-vote margin, gave final Congressional approval today to legislation aimed at saving the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

The carefully drafted announcement by Secretary of State Rogers that the United States would support the admission of Peking to the United Nations while opposing the expulsion of Taipei responds to the realities of the world situation.

In the Summer Nationals in Chicago last month it was possible to play three sessions of bridge each day, beginning about 9 A.M. and ending around midnight with brief breaks for meals. One of the few who undertook this strenuous program was the ubiquitous Benito Garozzo of Rome, a holder of many world titles who played for several days in Chicago en route to a business appointment in New York.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- A confidential report indicating that Rolls-Royce, Ltd., was financially unsound had been made more than a year before the company went into liquidation last February.

Fears of continued inflation and a possible increase in the prime lending rate sent stock prices tumbling yesterday in the second biggest setback of 1971. The Dow-Jones industrial average plummeted 14.89 points to 850.03.

PERKASIE, Pa. -- Time changes everything. This is a trite saying but it is annoying to realize how true trite sayings are. Verily there is nothing new under the sun! The United States now agrees to the admission of Communist China into the United Nations. Communist China will be admitted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- A Chicago banker told Senate investigators today that his bank, relying on the word of a favored customer, had been lured into granting $300,000 in loans secured by collateral that proved to be forged.

A privileged minority contrives to go through life strewing gratuities with such grandiose flourishes that the recipients knuckle their brows and even mutter words of thanks. The suspicion is strong that these lordly creatures have overtipped as a cowardly way of protecting their egos.
The number of crimes reported to the police in June showed an overall decrease of 5.1 per cent from the figures for June, 1970, according to statistics released yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange took its worst beating in more than 14 months yesterday as prices tumbled in moderate trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Nixon asked Congress today to appropriate $636,000 to begin an immediate and massive declassification of 160 million pages of World War II documents.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 3 -- No handicapper could have improved on the job done blindly today by Charles Plumb of the New York State Harness Racing Commission and Lee Benson, a trainer from Great Neck, L. I., as they officiated at the post-position draw for Friday night's $32,200 Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
New York's only legal bookmaker promised yesterday never to welsh on a bet.

Duke Ellington's annual August visit to the Rainbow Grill, where he appears with a small group drawn from his full orchestra, can usually be counted on by Ellington followers as an opportunity to hear the Duke from the set routine he has been following in his concert appearances during the previous year.

A former vice president of the Diners' Club in charge of computer operations received a one-year prison sentence in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiring in false dealings and charging the club for work that was not done.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that because of telephone cable problems, the association's automatic quotation system for the over-the-counter stock market may be out of line with actual market prices for some stocks.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 3 -A boxing riot, the defection of a Cuban athlete, the condemnation of a Colombian hero and a contingency crisis for two American marathaners have added more tumult to the first week of the Pan-American Games.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 3 -Fidel Castro has lost his fastball, or so the story goes, but Cuba regained some of its tarnished amateur baseball pride today with a 4-3 victory over a young but determined United States Pan American Games team.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 3 (UPI) -- A Federal judge granted eight antiwar activists access today to certain F.B.I. evidence used to indict them in an alleged plot to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, Presidential foreign affairs adviser.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Washington Post announced today the appointment of Howard Simons as managing editor. Mr. Simons, who has been deputy managing editor since October, succeeds Eugene C. Patterson, who resigned yesterday to become a professor at Duke University.

HOUSTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -The Apollo 15 astronauts were told today how disaster was averted 201 years ago by James Cook, the English explorer and captain of Endeavour, seagoing predecessor of their spaceship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- George Bush, the United States delegate was host to other delegates today in what was understood to be the first of a series of meetings on tactics in dealing with the Chinese membership this fall.

HOUSTON, Aug. 3 -- Somewhere inside the moon an extraordinary upheaval occurs every time the moon comes closest to the earth and, within the next week, the location of this phenomenon may become apparent.
CALI, Colombia, Aug. 3 -- United States track and field athletes saw their string of successes in the Pan-American Games interrupted again tonight by Donald Quarrie of Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Senator James L. Buckley of New York said today that the seating of mainland China in the United Nations would raise "significant questions" about the future of the world organization.

Renewed selling pressure smacked a jittery stock market yesterday and sent prices toppling across a broad front. Stocks registered their second largest setback of 1971.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The big wage settlements in the steel and railroad industries and the immediate large price increase for steel have added to the sense of alarm about the economy in some political quarters here -- not to mention in the business and financial community -- but there is no evidence that these events will bring about an early change in President Nixon's economic policy.
A bomb hoax diverted a London-bound 747 jumbo jet from Montreal to Denver yesterday before the plane flew on to England with 361 passengers and a crew of 22 aboard.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that 47 per cent of the brokerage firms covered in a monthly survey by the exchange had losses on their commission business in the month of June.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and a coalition of humane organizations that have criticized the A.S.P.C.A. for inhumane practices have agreed to set up joint committees to "insure a cooperative effort to improve the lot of all New York City animals."

The wheels rolled again yesterday on 10 railroads, ending an 18-day selective strike by the United Transportation Union. The end came late, however, for many companies that had already suffered millions of dollars in losses.

A number of predominantly low-income housing groups presented examples yesterday of what they termed "grand-scale fraud" in the city's Municipal Loan Program, including inflated mortgages, kickbacks and other abuses.

Shareholders meetings in 1971 were no humdrum business. Although James M. Roche, chairman of General Motors Corporation, may rail at the "professional Critics and the instant ecologists," social-political proposals have been in the limelight now as they are in our society.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to send a special commission of three of its members to the West African Republic of Guinea to investigate charges by President Sekou Toure that his country is about to be invaded by forces based in the neighboring territory of Portuguese Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The helicopter pilot who first told Federal agents that bald and golden eagles had been illegally shot from the air said today that antelope, elk, deer and Canada geese had also been shot illegally in the same manner over Wyoming.

The proposed transportation center at Farmingdale on Long Island promises a substantial, gain for the people of eastern Nassau and western Suffolk counties. It may not quite add up to what Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, calls "the most modern transportation facilities in the nation." But, as the first attempt to give coherence to travel by rail, air, bus and automobile, it deserves full encouragement.

If Mario Andretti and A. J. Foyt teamed up against Al and Bobby Unser in a court-tennis match or a checkers game, some promoter would probably sell out the house at $10 a head. The reason is that the public knows those golden box-office names, glamorized in the promotional efforts of the United States Auto Club.
The Oregon Legislature recently passed a set of bold new laws designed to help protect and enhance that state's unique environmental quality.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Nixon Administration is considering a plan to modernize the Israeli Air Force by selling it about 110 jets over the next three or four years.

EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Today was Lee Trevino Day and townsfolk by the thousands turned out to welcome their favorite son, home for the first time since his sweep of the American, Canadian and British Open golf titles.

PARIS -- The big American fashion import on the streets of Europe this summer is the United States Army look. T-shirts in olive green, decorated with shoulder patches and insignia, have replaced last year's tie-dyed T-shirt as the everyday uniform among the young. But multizippered pilots' jackets, fatigue green shorts and pants and camouflagecolored suits are also ubiquitous.

President Nixon's announcement of his planned visit to China is quite a political coup. But this magnanimously volunteered journey in an aura of peace and friendship doesn't fit the President's historical image. Perhaps the truth is more nearly that Mr. Nixon is being dragged kicking to Peking.

NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July, 31 -- Some friends of Tran Tan, aged 15, who worked with him in a bar frequented, by American soldiers asked him to sniff some white powder they were peddling. It made him feel strong and happy. Within a month he was injecting heroin into his arm twice a day.

H. P. Hood Sons announced yesterday the election of John M. Fox as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Fox, who recently resigned as president of the United Brands Company and its United Fruit Company division, succeeds Ezra Merrill as president.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 3 -- Premier Golda Meir met with her closest Cabinet advisers in a private session late tonight as the Israeli public heard suggestion that the Government was considering reported American proposals for an Israeli pull back of about 25 miles from the Suez Canal.
Vida Blue didn't win again, but he didn't lose either.

A Missouri Congressman who has been complaining that Battery Park is a garbage dump" because of litter announced yesterday that he was drafting a bill that would authorize sending two National Park Service employes to help the city clean up the park at the foot of Manhattan.

Net income of the American Stock Exchange in the six months ended June 30 rose to $913,000 from $235,000 in the first half of 1970, Paul Kolton, president, reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Sales of United States-type cars in the final third of July trailed the year-earlier pace by 4 per cent, with 247,046 deliveries against 256,057 the year before, the four American car manufacturers reported today. But the sales in all July, at 667,812, were up 4 per cent from 640,514 deliveries in July, 1970.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The United States sought support from other delegations today for two proposed resolutions to assure seats to both Peking and Taipei in the United Nations.
Like bringing up children, the care of dividends takes skill, understanding and dexterity these days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Fourteen Pakistani diplomats -- all of Bengali origin -- resigned today from their embassy here or from the mission to the United Nations in protest against what they called "crimes against humanity" in East Pakistan by the Government of President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan.

A new process for modifying kaolin clays for use as pigments with such materials as polypropylene, polyethylene and polystyrene was disclosed yesterday by the Freeport Kaolin Company, a division of the Freeport Minerals Company.
COWES, England, Aug. 4 -- The Dutch yacht, Belita, won today's race in the Admiral's Cup series, but the British team, which includes Prime Minister Edward Heath, retained the over-all lead.

HOLMDEL, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Jack Benny, who has been appearing here in a concert series with Henry Mancini and his orchestra, took time out today to give away a million dollars. Smiling bravely, and shedding only a tear or two like the trouper he is, not to mention his self-created image of a tight-fisted fellow with a buck, he handed a certificate representing the sum to Mrs. Patsy K. Tilton.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- A nation where computers would be tools used by almost everyone and a computer the size of a pack of cigarettes and almost as cheap were two of the many visions of the future presented today by a panel of informed prognosticators at the annual conference of the Association for Computing Machinery.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 4 (AP)--John Newcombe and Arthur Ashe led the advance !to the quarterfinal round while young John Alexander of Australia provided an upset today in tile $50,000 United States pro tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.

New York State's Council of Economic Advisers reported yesterday that the state was "receiving far less than its equitable share" of Federal jobs and pay -- only 40 per cent of the average for the rest of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate voted today to impose a limit on the amount of money a wealthy politician and his immediate family may invest in his campaign if he runs for President, Vice President, Senator or Representative.

SCARSDALE, Aug. 4 -- A live, fully grown tiger stares out at patrons of the bar of the Spa Health Club here from a glass enclosure. A plaque on the wall describes him as "a perfect mascot for the spa since he represents perfection of natural beauty, strength and agility."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 -- The C. H. Sugar Company's refinery at Crockett, Calif., ran out of raw sugar yesterday, a victim like hundreds of other companies of the longshoremen's strike, which has closed West Coast ports for more than a month.
Concern over a lagging domestic economy and problems facing the dollar abroad sent stock prices skidding yesterday after a mid-session rally lost its momentum.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which is seeking to bolster its financial position through a $250-million Government-guaranteed loan, reported yesterday a $3-million profit, equal to 26 cents a share, for the quarter ended June 30. This was down from earnings of $3.2-million, or 28 cents a share, in the 1970 quarter.
As snare drums draped in mourning beat out a funereal cadence, ranks of firemen saluted the body of Battalion Chief William C. Rinsdale yesterday morning.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Bwamazon Farm's Well Mannered stalked the leaders to the middle of the turn and then slowly pulled away to a 1 1/2-length victory in the $28,200 Salvator Mile Handicap at Monmouth Park today.
GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed on a draft of a treaty that would forbid biological weapons, informed diplomatic sources said today.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Attorneys for Angela Davis demanded today that the grand jury that indicted her be called into court for questioning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Nixon cautioned today against speculation that his forthcoming journey to Peking would produce "instant detente" with China or a settlement of the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe, the President's adviser on narcotics, told a Senate subcommittee today that many American servicemen using drugs in South Vietnam were doing so before they entered the military service.
HOUSTON, Aug. 4 -- A rich harvest of new information concerning the moon's surface, its interior and its influences on nearby space was reported here today.
President Nixon's action in the conflict over desegregation of the public schools in Austin, Tex., places the Administration squarely on every side of the controversy.
William V. Shannon writes in the July 29 Times, "Ireland was the first British colony and the first to break free."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United States Commission on Civil Rights believes that much stronger antidiscrimination provisions are needed if the money from the Administration's $5-billion general revenue-sharing plan is not to be used to perpetuate racial discrimination.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 -- The current talks between the United States and Israel, aimed at breaking the deadlock over reopening the Suez Canal, neared an end today with few clues to their outcome.

MONTREAL, Aug. 4 -- An international airlines conference that began here five weeks ago to set new trans-Atlantic fares remained deadlocked today over rival fare plans to attract more middle-income travelers.
CALI, Colombia, Aug. 4 -- The United States men's volleyball team has requested visas to play a series of games in Cuba later this month in an attempt to qualify for the 1972 Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Senate investigators reported today that more than $494-million in securities had been reported stolen this year, more than twice the total for all of 1970 and $100 - million more than for the last two years combined.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The House moved today to ease the plight of the unemployed by voting the full $1-billion that President Nixon had sought to create emergency public service jobs. The vote was 321 to 76.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday in moderate trading, after a morning rally had petered out. The exchange's price index, which was up 0.07 at noon, finished the session off 0.08, at 24.29.

A planetary catastrophe is taking place in Asia, a human disaster so massive that it could bathe the future in blood, not just for Asians, but for those of us in the West as well. Yet the response of the global community has been minimal at best. In the United States, the official response has been worse than minimal and morally numb.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced yesterday receipt of a $21.8-million Air Force contract to design and develop an advanced command and control system to increase targeting and communications capabilities of the Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missile system.

A little haltingly at first and then with a steady rhythm, water began flowing yesterday for the first time in more than a year from the "Fountain of Abundance" at the Grand Army Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Central Park South.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 4 -- One of the players Coach Weeb Ewbank is not going to look at Saturday night when the Jets play the Detroit Lions at Tampa is Larry Grantham. The outside linebacker has been with the New York organization longer than Ewbank, as well as everybody else except Don Maynard, who is also a charter member.

In the continuing polemics surrounding vacancy decontrol, neither tenant nor landlord groups have come to grips with a residual consequence of rent control -- housing underutilization. It is a fact of city living that many large controlled apartment units are being occupied by one or two people while larger families are cramped in small quarters.

The first hospital community board in the city with the power to help select executives and determine fiscal policies was elected yesterday at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island by 225 patients in wheel chairs and on stretchers and hundreds of nurses, doctors and clerks.

BACLIEU, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 -- A group of citizens in this southern Mekong Delta town charge that the province chief is using his sweeping powers to intimidate voters into backing pro-Government candidates in the lower house election set for Aug. 29.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- A number of events in East and West during the last few days point to an attempt by the ambassadors of the Big Four nations to complete the major phase of agreement on the Berlin problem in marathon sessions next week.
The corporate bond market, buoyed by the successful sale of this week's two triple-A utility issues, rose in price yesterday.

Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams called yesterday "for the total elimination of fares on the city's buses and subways" and proposed that the transit system be financed by a $150-a-year surcharge on city income tax payers and 1.8 per cent tax on the net profits of corporations in the city.
REHOVOT, Israel, Aug. 4 -- An American scholar touched off a debate today among 30 American and Israeli intellectual by asserting that American Jews were "overcommitted psychologically" to Israel.
HOUSTON, Aug. 4 -- The homeward voyage of Apollo 15 began today with the successful firing of the spaceship's rocket to break out of the moon's orbit and end six days of lunar exploration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Negroes in America owned and operated about 2 per cent of all United States business enterprises in 1969, a Government report disclosed today. Based on a survey conducted by the Census Bureau, the report also indicates that receipts from black-owned businesses amounted to less than half of 1 per cent of the nation's total business revenues.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday urged the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, William J. Casey, to take immediate steps "to restore public confidence in financial markets."
Leaders of municipal unions here planned yesterday for a renewed effort to prevent the termination of Blue Shield medical and surgical coverage as an option for city employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The House passed today compromise legislation extending the draft, but final Congressional approval of the measure by the Senate appeared likely to be postponed until September at the earliest.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Roxanne Pierce of Kensington, Md., won her third and fourth gold medals of the Pan-American Games today when she finished first in both the horse vaulting and uneven parallel bars of the women's gymnastics competition.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Paul McCartney has formed a new British-American pop group in which his American wife, Linda Eastman, will play piano.

AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The New England Patriots patched up their Duane Thomas-Carl Garrett deal with the Dallas Cowboys today, returning Thomas, getting back Garrett and keeping the two other players.
Soybeans Were substantially lower at the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Wheat and corn were lower, and oats fractionally higher.
The banning of a controversial book from the libraries of a school district in Queens was allowed to stand yesterday by Judge Jacob Mishler in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

A television commercial was filmed yesterday at a home in Liberty Corner, N. J., in which an American family endorsed an American product. But it wasn't a typical American family and it wasn't a typical American product.

NEPTUNE CITY, N. J. -- "Take a nap end of hough, about three pounds or so. Put into a saucepan and nearly cover with water. Put it on the fire at night, bring it almost to a boiling point, then place it on the hob and let it gently simmer all night. Don't let it boil. In the morning the meat will fall from the bones."

CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 4 -- George Allen, the great trader, made his 16th and 17th deals today in the crash program to rebuild the Washington Redskins that began six months ago. The exchanges were typical of the crafty Allen -- complex and shrewd.
TRENTON, Aug. 4 -- The New Jersey Commuter Operating Agency approved rail fare increases of up to 20 per cent today, denying increases on those lines where it felt service was inadequate.
President Nixon attended the Broadway musical "No, No, Nanette" last night and immediately afterward pronounced himself in favor of nostalgia in the theater.
Merv Rettenmund may be the least heralded of the Baltimore Orioles but last night he was the most important.
Specially trained plain-clothes men, posing as bicycle riders in Central Park in recent evenings, have made eight arrests after being attacked in some harrowing incidents.

Almost before Richard Nixon took office, Democrats, especially in the Senate, began their attacks -- on his military budgets, his negotiating positions, his foreign policies -- and the attacks still continue.

A ranking economist, in urging yesterday that a wage-price review board be established to combat inflation, suggested that, to allow time for its organization, the "President might have to decree a temporary 'freeze' on wages and prices for two or three months."

FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 4 The court-martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson on charges arising from the killings of civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 got under way today with selection of a seven-member jury of officers.

Assistant Secretary of State Sisco's discussions with Israeli leaders in Jerusalem this week are taking place against a background of dissension in the Arab world and of strain in Arab-Soviet relations, both factors that could profoundly affect the prospects for a Middle East peace settlement.
Illegal parking, which the Fire Department said was in part responsible for the death of a battalion chief at a fire last Sunday in the Bronx, is becoming a mammoth problem here.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- A Puerto Rican athlete who made a "black power" salute during the playing of the United States national anthem during the Pan-American Games was ordered home today, refused to go, and then was promised a hearing by the Puerto Rican Olympic Committee.
RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 4 -- A biologist with Vermont's Fish and Game Department, Dr. Joseph Artman, has a Ph.D. in wildlife biology from the University of Minnesota.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Daniel J. Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, expressed confidence today that the way was now clear for the Tristar jet and its Rolls-Royce engine.

Wait till you see the London digs of Vincent Price in "The Abominable Dr. Phibes." That's our boy, the Pride of the Zombies. This time he's a brooding old vaudevillian, knocking off a surgical team of nine who operated on his wife.
Bruce Catton, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Civil War historian, served as Pennsylvania's heavy artillery yesterday in the battle of Gettysburg tower.

The Soviet Union, with a team headed by Grandmaster Vasily Tukmakov and including several other experienced players, swept this year's recent world student team championship at Mayaguez, P. R. The defending champion United States team, composed of Andrew Soltis and Ken Rogoff of New York, William Martz of Wisconsin, Greg De Fotis of Illinois and Jim Tarjan and John Grefe of California, finished second. Canada was third and Israel fourth.

Within the last few years, New York's once-remarkable public transportation network has deteriorated with alarming swiftness. Although the Long Island Railroad reputedly is the "finest railroad in the country," our twice-daily subway, commuter railroad or bus rides are increasingly unpleasant, expensive, and prone to accidents.
OTTAWA, Aug. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign-exchange reserves rose to a record $4,924-million at the end of July, from $4,852-million a month earlier, the Finance Department reported today.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Reuters announced today that it had decided to reopen its bureau in Peking.

A walk to Woody Woodward, a double by Pete Rose and two excellent fielding plays by Tommy Helms contributed to Cincinnati's 1-0 victory over the Mets yesterday and ruined a vow Gary Gentry made to himself about 10 days ago.

BRASILIA, Aug. 4 -- The majority leader in the Brazilian Senate, who recently spoke out for limited constitutional reforms, has retracted some of his opinions and announced that the military Government plans no changes.

The Federal Aviation Administration has granted approval of the first use of a new instrument landing system for commercial airline traffic. The system's developers say it has significant advantages over the system long in use.
The third high-grade utility bond issue this week came to market yesterday and, like the first two, was a smashing success.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Main Spring, owned by Lee Barney of Burlington, Wis., and handled by Rod Jenkins, won the intermediate jumper class at the Orange County Horse Show today and moved into a commanding lead for the championship.

According to copies of official records, a six-story house on the Lower East Side was completely rehabilitated two months ago with almost $400,000 from a city loan fund. It stands today a doorless, windowless bulk.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -Wayne Duke, who enhanced the Big Eight's image of a national football power while serving as conference commissioner the last eight years, was named today as commissioner of the Big Ten.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A United States District Court judge today ordered Dr. Daniel Ellsberg removed to Los Angeles Aug. 16 to face charges of illegal possession of secret Government documents in the Pentagon papers case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A major Federal study of the nation's health care costs, made public today, forecasts that medical expenses will rise 50 per cent in the first half of this decade to more than $100-billion.

CHICAGO -- Liquor consumption was down 99 per cent at the Pick-Congress Hotel earlier this week. Orange juice, however, was being gulped as fast as it could be squeezed. The reason was simple: More than 1,000 members of the World Woman's Christian Temperance Union were quartered there for their 25th triennial convention.

HOUSTON, Aug. 5 -- Today and tomorrow the Apollo 15 astronauts, in prearranged collaboration with Soviet and Dutch astronomers, are trying to observe what some scientists suspect are "black holes" in the sky.

The Dictaphone Corporation announced yesterday the election of E. Lawrence Tabat, 58 years old, as president and chief executive officer effective Sept. 13. Mr. Tabat, currently vice president and division manager of the Power Tool division of the Rockwell Manufacturing Company, succeds Walter W. Finke, chairman and president, who will relinquish both those positions on that date. Mr. Finke will continue as a director and a consultant to the office machine company.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 5 -- George C. Wallace says he has decided to run again for the Presidency in 1972.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Selective Service System, in a lottery drawing that lasted just over two hours, determined today the order in which about two million young men born in 1952 will be subject to the draft next year.

The Jewish Defense League announced a drive yesterday to arrange for Jews to buy rifles and shotguns, Rabbi Meir Kahane, the league's director, who has been ordered by a court to have nothing to do with weapons, was present but did not participate in the news conference announcing the drive.

Third-quarter corporate profits are not likely to match the inspiring results of the vigorous second quarter. However, the final three months may push the year's performace to a lofty total exceeded only by the record year of 1966, according to a preliminary survey by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Ignoring Treasury Department objections, Senator William Proxmire made public today the deposits of more than $1.3-billion by three international financial institutions in commercial banks in the United States.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- The General Motors Corporation said today that it would raise 1972 car prices by an average of $176, or 3.9 per cent.

ATLANTA, Aug. 5 -- The New York Mets didn't need a 17-inning game to open a two-week trip after they had lost 24 of 34 games. But they got one tonight, and lost it, when the Atlanta Braves punched over a run in the bottom of the 17th for a 2-1 victory.

MIAMI, Aug. 2 -- Homeowners in Miami's most exclusive neighborhood gather on their porches in the long summer evenings to watch the sun melt into the horizon and listen to porpoises slide past their front doors.
A 27-year-old Suffolk County man was convicted in Federal Court in Brooklyn last night of taking part in the $25,000 robbery of a Bay Shore, L.I., bank last Dec. 21.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 5 -- A world-record performance in the triple jump, another gold-medal run by Frank Shorter and a raucous series of fights highlighted a hectic windup to track and field competition at the sixth Pan-American Games tonight.
A sweeping reorganization of the nation's securities industry was recommended yesterday by William McChesney Martin Jr., the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

Gore Vidal's best man for '72, Ralph Nader, is taking over more and more territory for his free-fire zone in America. The unofficial Inspector General of the United States has planted his depth charges from Detroit to Washington in the last few years and one by one they zero in on their targets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Senate approved overwhelmingly today a comprehensive campaign bill designed to reduce mounting political spending and to let the public know who finances bids for office and how the money is spent.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Kevstone Stable's Willywin repelled Famous Gun's stretch rally and drew away to a 3 1/2-length victory today at Monmouth Park.

TORONTO, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., said today it was closing two mines with a combined work force of about 1,000 men because of reduced demand for nickel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -Reversing an earlier stand, the House agreed today to open the way for further expansion of trade with Communist countries through Export-Import Bank financing of exports.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 5 -- A 57-year-old Vienna-born stock-broker who fled Nazi persecution to come to the United States 30 years ago, was elected the Interim Mayor of Jersey City today by a 7-to-1 vote of the City Council.

The Institute for Juvenile Justice announced yesterday that it would file suit in Federal and state courts early next week asking for the immediate and permanent closing of the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx, the city's largest child-detention facility.

NEWARK, Aug. 5 -- New Jersey labor leaders held a rally in front of the strikebound Evening News today in an effort to demonstrate solidarity behind the strike by the American Newspaper Guild, which is now in its 11th week.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Declaring himself impressed with the way London governs its 8 million people, Governor Rockefeller suggested today that New York City study the British capital's methods of decentalization.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 5 -- A red and white banner draped over the entrance to the Taipei Municipal Council Building on one of the city's busiest corners proclaims in Chinese and English: "No U.N."

Maybe Juan Pizarro can now unpack his suitcase and stay awhile. Since he left Puerto Rico in 1956 to try baseball as a career, the 34-year-old left-hander has worn seven different major league uniforms in both leagues and five minor league baseball suits from Jacksonville, Fla., to Hawaii.

For nearly three years now an odd aggregation called NRBQ has been my favorite rock band. This has not been an easy conviction to maintain. In terms of popularity, the going has been rough for the group.

Henry M. Ramirez, a onetime migrant worker in California, was named by President Nixon yesterday as chairman of the Cabinet Committee on Opportunities for Spanish-Speaking Peoples. He is the first HispanicAmerican to serve on the President's staff.
Plans were officially abandoned by the Lindsay administration yesterday for a giant incinerator that, in 1967, was called the answer to the city's growing garbage crisis.
The battered shareholders of Ecological Sciences have another ordeal ahead of them when the shares begin trading over-the-counter on Monday.

AREA A -- Color this report blue. Huge loads of bluefish are being taken by fishermen in boats, according to John Falkiewicz of Surf City, N.J. Chumming is having the best luck on the ridge, with trollers doing very well with feathers and squid spoons.

Like a well-mannered tiger, John Prinz danced the male lead in "Theme and Variations" for the first time Wednesday evening at the State Theater. The production, one of American Ballet Theater's perennials, offers a series of virtuoso and partnering challenges that Mr. Prinz met with caged exuberance.

Members of the Amalgmated Clothing Workers of America picketed Alexander's here and department stores in three other metropolitan areas yesterday as part of the union's continuing protest against the sale of imported men's clothing from low-wage countries.

While Mrs. Cheryl Schmidt of Independence, Ohio, was watching a performance of "Applause" at the Palace Theater on Broadway near 46th Street, a thief broke into her car parked nearby and stole her purse.

The nation's credit managers have yet to make any significant progress in cutting back the rate of expansion in the money supply, Federal Reserve banking data indicated yesterday. During July, for example, the money stock -- currency in circulation plus private checking accounts -- grew by more than 12 per cent on a seasonally adjusted annual rate basis, even more than the rate of growth during the first half of the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills announced today that he and the House Ways and Means Committee, which he heads will visit Brussels in early November to confer with the executive commission of the European Economic Community.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Mike Hill curled in a 30-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to shoot a three under-par 67 and tie Jerry Heard for the first-round lead in the $150,000 American Golf Classic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The rise in industrial wholesale prices quickened in July though there was a welcome decline in food prices, the Labor Department reported today.

LONDON -- The nightmare vision of Soviet policy runs something like this: Moscow is preparing a long-range plan to assert unchallenged leadership of the Communist world by smashing China to the east and re-establishing control over heretical Marxist lands to the west.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he thought there was "a good possibility" that President Nixon would replace Vice President Agnew with Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally when Mr. Nixon runs for re-election next year.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5 -- Seymour L. Lustman, professor of psychiatry at Yale University, drowned today while sailing a small boat in Lincolnville, Me. He was 51 years old.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Many summer communities have a theatrical choice -- if they have a choice at all -- between reruns of recent Broadway hits or revivals of old Broadway hits. But in East Hampton, almost any night of the week, one can see a program of experimental one-acts (at the Old Post Office Theater) or a new fanciful creation of the John Drew Repertory Company (at the John Drew Theater).

BROOKLINE, Mass. Aug. 5 (AP) -- Third-seeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, able to concentrate fully on his game in the absence of demonstrations, moved into the quarterfinal round today in the $50,000 United States pro tennis tournament at Longwood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, who is chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, was asked today to investigate last Friday's incident on NBC-TV's "Today Show" in which George Jessel, the comedian, was removed from the show after making remarks about The New York Times and The Washington Post.

Russians will be introduced to the fun of an American amusement park next week when a parachute ride and modern versions of the Whip and other whirling carnival attractions go on display at a trade fair in Moscow's Gorki Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Despite Republican grumblings, the Senate rushed through legislation today to provide the same Federal disaster aid for economically distressed areas as that given victims of hurricanes, earthquakes, forest fires and other calamities.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- The discussions between the United States and Israel over reopening the Suez Canal ended today with both sides agreeing that the prospects for an interim accord with Egypt were still alive.

One of the world's most famous bridge clubs acquired a new home and a new character earlier this week. The Mayfair House of Bridge, long established on 57th Street under the direction of Alvin Roth, and before him, Harry Fishbein, moved into luxurious new quarters at 14 East 60th Street and became a membership club.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Three editors of an underground newspaper were ordered to prison today for up to 15 months in sentences that set off bitter social and political protest.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5 -Del Insko, a little man who has had some busy days and nights recently, spent today and tonight in comparative idleness.

During the latter part of May several major newspapers carried a onepage advertisement expressing concern about the environmental impact of thermal-electric power plant development in the Southwest United States.

On the basis of sales so far this year, the automobile industry should chalk up a new industry mark of between 9.7 million and 10 million units, William D. Innis, executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company for North American automotive operations, said here yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 -- A witness for a group of Black Panthers charged with attempted murder testified today that she saw two persons shot from a helicopter in a police raid on the New Orleans Black Panther headquarters last September.

Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday that 17 per cent of employable welfare recipients failed to pick up their biweekly relief checks last Friday. This figure compared with 22 per cent who failed to pick up their checks in the first two weeks of July.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -The Administration asked Congress today for Federal authority to prosecute cases involving attacks on American and foreign officials and their families.

HONOLULU, Aug. 5 (UPI) -A group of 26 scientists inspected Mars from a special jet flying 45,000 feet over the Pacific early today for man's closest look at the mysterious planet. They termed the venture a success.
LISBON, Aug. 5 -- The political police arrested the secretary of Portugal's journalist union today while parliament was approving a Government bill abolishing formal press censorship.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 5 -- Turkey announced today that she had recognized Communist China and severed diplomatic relations with Nationalist China. A joint communique issued simultaneously in Ankara and Peking said Turkey recognized that "the People's Republic of China is the sole legal government of China."

Net income of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the world's largest non-American-based industrial enterprise, rose 15.7 per cent in the second quarter of 1971 to $253.4-million from $218.1-million in the period a year ago.

State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer will not subpoenaed by the United State Senate subcommittee that has already heard testimony that the judge received $50,000 in bribes, the chief counsel for the subcommittee said yesterday.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The United States lost the women's springboard diving gold medal in the Pan-American Games for the first time today, but the United Stages men's basketball team crushed Surinam, 128-48, to retain a chance at that title.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill appropriating $20.8-billion for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare.

Leading chain-store organizations in the country chalked up sizable gains in sales volume during July compared with the year before, indicating that consumer spending continues as a strong factor in the economy.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 5 -Ron Johnson, Tucker Frederickson, Junior Coffey and Les Shy, all suffering from various degrees of leg trouble, won't accompany the New York Giants to Houston on Sunday for their first exhibition game of the season, against the Oilers on Monday night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 6 -- Five American soldiers were killed and two were wounded when a United States armored personnel carrier from the 196 Brigade, Americal Division, struck a mine yesterday 26 miles south of Danang, the United States command reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky today lost a major round in his fight to get on the ballot for the presidential election Oct. 3. The South Vietnamese Supreme Court rejected his application for candidacy on the ground that it did not comply with the rules established in a stiff electoral law sponsored by Mr. Ky's chief rival, President Nguyen Van Thieu.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The locations of seven additional satellite, or supplemental, bases for the Strategic Air Command were disclosed late today by the Pentagon. This will bring the total number of such bases to 20.

HOUSTON, Aug. 5 -- An Apollo 15 astronaut, Maj. Alfred M. Worden of the Air Force, stepped into the black vacuum 196,000 miles from the earth today to become the first man ever to take a floating excursion outside his craft in interplanetary space.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 5 -- At the Arthur Frank Haberdashery on Main Street, "business was frankly lousy this past month, if you'll pardon a pun," according to the shop owner, Si Frank. Out at Bud's hardware store, on suburban 62d South Street, clerks report "very good sales" of paint, plumbing supplies, wood paneling and the like.

CAIRO, Aug. 5 -- President Anwar el-Sadat has told the Soviet Union unequivocally that Egypt will continue to resist Communism in the Arab world, it was reliably reported today. The Kremlin appears to have bowed to his position and to have decided that its strategic interest in the Middle East outweighs the fate of Arab Communists.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP) -Top-seeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., received a scare today but won his third match in the $30,000 Western Tennis tournament in a day of upsets.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Nelson B. Hunt's Lucky Traveler took the right route in the $35,500 Test Stakes today. Under a resourceful ride by Chuck Baltazar, Lucky Traveler sped along on the outside of her 11 rivals in a field of 3-year-old fillies and registered a surprising two-length triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Despite a recent court ruling that radio and television stations must accept some "controversial" paid advertisements, the Federal Communications Commission rejected today a demand by the Communications Workers of America for air time to discuss a proposed contract settlement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Defense Department did not have a current five-year plan for military assistance and therefore could not provide one as requested by the committee.
HOUSTON, Aug. 6 -- The Apollo 15 astronauts sped closer to earth today with such precise aim that, for the first time, no course correction was considered necessary before splashdown.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A New York consulting physicist, who contracted rheumatoid arthritis and lost almost completely the use of his hands, regained full control of them with an exerciser he invented.

In his eagerly awaited report to the New York Stock Exchange, William McChesney Martin Jr. has presented a plan for reshaping the nation's securities markets into a single, closely integrated, auction market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- In a complex deal reflecting the dollar's international weakness, the United States said today that it would exchange $862-million in Belgian francs and Dutch guilders for dollars those two nations don't want.

CAMBRIDGE -- Is man descended from the apes? Recently, it was still thought that our ancestors branched off from something pretty close to the gorillas and chimps, as late as the Ice Age. The Offtrack Betting Corporation ended a week yesterday in which it twice made a handsome return on wagers it had been unable to transmit to race tracks.
After holding up a Bronx bank, a robber was shot in the leg by a detective yesterday but managed to escape in a crowded city bus. He did not have the required exact fare, but he did have two guns.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy said yesterday that he had information indicating that a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet, badly damaged taking off from San Francisco on July 30, "may have been between 10 and 25 tons overweight."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- The Whitney Stakes, one of the more attractive races on the local calendar, will serve as the feature on tomorrow's card. WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Men born in 1952 who hold draft deferments next year will not be inducted for military service as long as they retain their deferments. If they lose their deferments in a subsequent year they will be drafted only if their lottery number is reached in that year's call.

"Mission Impossible."

ATLANTA, Aug. 6 -- The New York Mets, who would have given their kingdom for a run during 17 innings last night, rebounded with all sorts of runs tonight as Tom Seaver cruised to a 9-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- The recent 8 per cent rise in steel prices will cause the industrial-price component of the wholesale-price index to rise 0.3 per cent in the next two months, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
CALI, Colombia, Aug. 6 -- Bobby Lee Hunter stands 5 feet 2 inches and weighs 112 pounds, a quiet, 21-year-old black convict from a South Carolina correctional institution.
Three Queens men were arrested by Secret Service agents yesterday in two separate arrests involving the sale of $175,000 worth of counterfeit money.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate today approved the establishment of the Gateway National Recreation Area, which would open up more than 26,000 acres at the entrance to New York harbor to an estimated total of 10 million visitors a year, more people than visited the nation's six national seashores last year.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio -- The recent dramatic developments in Washington-Peking relations have created an atmosphere conducive to a more rational and less emotional discussion concerning the future of Formosa. Inevitably, it is one problem the United States will have to face, because adjusting relations with Peking automatically involves adjusting relations with Taipei.

Recent events in the case involving Justice Schweitzer illustrate clearly the need for an improved procedure in New York State to investigate, discipline and remove judges. Six privately owned companies -- engaged in petroleum exploration, double-knit fabrics, automobile supplies, sportswear, electronics and the installation of telephone lines -- offered their shares to a generally unenthusiastic public this week, specialists in new issues reported.

A 24-year-old fireman called "Super Sam" by members of his ladder company because of his athletic interests and his zeal for the job has lived up to the name.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 6 -- F. J. Caldwell's Jim French gets a chance to settle a score with October House Farm's Pass Catcher tomorrow in the $100,000 Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park. Ten other 3-year-olds are scheduled to start.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The turmoil in European foreign-exchange markets subsided today as the unexpected midweek outburst of speculation involving the French franc petered out. Dealers said the whole thing might have been avoided by more adroit handling in Paris.
Nearly $5.5-million in retroactive parity payments went to 3,208 transit patrolmen and to 829 housing authority policemen yesterday, the City Controller's office announced.

Norm Cash reported to spring training determined to prove a point. He had to convince Billy Martin, the new Detroit Tiger manager, he wasn't washed up and fit only for part-time duty at the age of 36.

On the 26th anniversary yesterday of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, demonstrations were held throughout the city protesting the Government's use then of nuclear weapons.

Duong Van Minh.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- The State Department plans to contact a West German businessman who played a role in reports yesterday that Hanoi might release 187 United States prisoners of war.

His book is divided into three essays, on Jews as revolutionaries, on the durability of Theodor Herzl's "Jewish State," and the merging of the twin forces of nationalism and revolution that resulted in the present state of Israel.

Leaders and technicians representing the Municipal Labor Committee will confer tomorrow and Tuesday with city officials in a further attempt to find a solution of the dispute over the city's plan to terminate Blue Shield coverage for city employes.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla, Aug. 7 -- Patches of the fish-killing microorganism called the Red Tide remained bottled up in Tampa Bay this week as clean-up crews claimed they were winning the massive job of carting away tons of dead fish.

The Carnegie Corporation and the Fresh Air Fund are working on a preliminary study of the 94-year-old summer vacation program as the first step toward a long-range comprehensive investigation next year.

READING, Pa., Aug. 7 -- Why training camps? Is it really necessary to run a pro football team through eight weeks of Spartan life in a training camp to get ready for the season? For at least the first two weeks, in the heat of midsummer, the athletes are practicing twice a day.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- From behind the tall hedgerows of this resort community, when the intense heat of a sunny Sunday summer afternoon has begun to wane, the careful listener may hear an unusual combination of sounds -- the thwack of a mallet against a polo ball and the squeal of brakes.
