" Cool Cat" is a brisk, well-told story about a group of teen-age boys in a ghetto suburb of Los Angeles. Buddy, whose father is a probation officer and whose mother is a social worker, carries on a valiant struggle for survival in his jagged environment.

While you were correct in pointing out that Judge John T. Clancy's resignation was timed so as to avoid a primary and thus disenfranchise the Queens voters, you were in error about the length of Mr. Laurino's term.

The crowd gathered for the New York Philharmonic concert at Sheep Meadow in Central Park on Tuesday night seemed especially relaxed and comfortable, and its good feelings were certainly engendered in part, at least, by the music.

The City Planning Commission approved unanimously yesterday a controversial luxury housing development on the Glen Oaks Golf Course in Queens, and by a split decision approved low-income housing for a Manhattan site currently occupied by squatters.
TORONTO, Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Rodney George Laver, tennis's biggest superstar, left here tonight to get away from the game for at least a week and maybe as long as a month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Export-Import Bank today rejected a Chilean request for approximately $21-million in loans and loan guarantees for the purchase of three airliners -- two Boeing 707's and a Boeing 727.
The makers of Vita herring products have imitated her voice to sell fish, Katharine Hepburn charged, and she sued the company and its advertising agency, Solow-Weston Inc., for $4-million.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- President Nixon signed three bills today involving appropriations and Federal safety standards for boats.
In a July 22 editorial you referred to the agreement between the United States Postal Service and its employes as a victory for collective bargaining. You also reported a 20 per cent wage settlement.
The tax-exempt bond market again yesterday seemed able to handle another large load of new issues without much difficulty.

Although he has concentrated on only four years of Shaw's life, Stanley Weintraub has revealed a complete man. I do not believe that any book within the same compass could show so much of Shaw's character, the play of his mind, his multifaceted interests, his relentless and unending labors for literature, for Fabianism, for good works, for mankind itself.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- India privately assured Washington today that her new friendship treaty with the Soviet Union was not directed against the United States or any of its allies.

About 100 tenants who consider their East Side apartment building a "notorious" site of "prostitution, drug peddling and other illicit activities" have been given an Aug. 23 hearing date in Civil Court here on which to argue their demand for a court-appointed administrator, one of those tenants said last night.
The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard, criticizing the management of defense contracts by the Pentagon and industry, announced today a new program aimed at attacking some of these problems and producing more experimental weapons systems.
The New York Shipping Association a trade group made up of 129 steamship companies, stevedores and other waterfront employers, has elected two new top officers and a new board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Congressional actions to date have already added about $4.2-billion to the budget spending level proposed by President Nixon for the current fiscal year, a joint committee of Congress reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Pamela Mott Grosvenor and Maj. Gen. Ellsworth Ingalls Davis, U.S.A., retired, were married here this morning in the chapel of the Episcopal Christ Church Cathedral. Canon C. William Ziegenfuss performed the ceremony.
The first "rapid detoxification" program for drug-addicted veterans has been introduced by the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan.

A batch of what appeared to be City of New York Finance Department checks was found in the sand at Long Beach, L. I., early yesterday, and Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin put into operation a program designed to keep banks from honoring forged checks.

The City Investing Company, whose diversified interests include housing and land development, manufacturing and financial services, increased its earnings from operations in the second quarter and first half, the company reported yesterday. Because of reduced gains on sales of real estate and securities, the net income in both periods declined from the year before.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- When David H. Meid was 14 back in 1950 he worked a 50-acre farm near Fort Wayne, Ind., that was his father's hobby.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The White House warned today that Government officials could lose their jobs or be transferred if they sought to impose widespread busing as a means of desegregating schools in the urban South.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Frank Heckl of the United States swam to his fifth and sixth gold medals in record-shattering time tonight and established himself as undisputed king of the pool in the Pan-American games.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 11 -- The first photographs clearly showing the twisted, double-stranded structure of DNA, the molecule that carries the "code of life," have been produced by a team of scientists at two universities.

The father of the bride has more than bills to pay, once the happy and frantic few hours of the wedding and reception are over. True, his daughter becomes some other man's responsibility, but there are some worries that a chat with his new son-in-law might put to rest.
A man suspected of running a $6-million-a-year policy racket in Jamaica, Queens, paid out $1,500 a month for city police protection, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Patricio Cornejo of Chile upset sixth-seeded Frank Froehling of Miami in men's singles today at the national clay courts tennis championships. The scores were 6-4, 7-6.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11 -- Strikes in two big copper mines and a wave of rural work stoppages are taxing the political skills of President Salvador Allende Gossens. A Cabinet crisis, which involved the resignation of five ministers, was resolved tonight.

The United States has formally proposed to the executive directors of the International Monetary Fund that the band within which currencies are allowed to fluctuate be widened to 3 per cent above and below their defined par values from the present 1 per cent, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The National Alliance of Postal and Federal Employes charged today that blacks in the United States Postal Service were being subjected to "sophisticated elimination" from the new system.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 11 -- As a precaution against both Al Woodall and Bob Davis being injured in the same game, Weeb Ewbank selected today Gus Hollomon, the strong side safetyman, as the New York Jets' new "emergency" quarterback.
SAN FRANCISCO -- The Bay Area has become a home away from home for Hollywood filmmakers looking for a nice place to visit and work, if not necessarily live.
SAULT SAINTE MARIE, Mich. -- The "no vacancy" signs are lighted nightly now at the 20 motels in this 300-year-old border town. The attraction is the Soo Locks, among the busiest in the world.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 -- Bonds totaling $113-million were sold today to finance construction of a domed stadium seating 82,000 people.

The appointment of John D. Pomfret as assistant to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, was announced yesterday by the publisher. The appointment is effective Sept. 1.

Congratulations on your editorial appealing to city and state officials to save the Health Research Council [July 12]. The city has many unique health problems that will continue to cost it much more than some $4 million annually to keep the council going. Associated costs of lost wages, increased crime to keep the addict supplied with heroin, etc., should be added to the costs of caring for those who are unnecessarily sick or disabled.
SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Billy Casper, two-time United States Open champion, rejoined the pro tour here, hoping to end a slump.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Total business inventories continued to rise at a slow pace in June and in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the country's second largest steel company, surprised the industry late yesterday with an announcement that it would defer for two months a previously scheduled price increase on an important class of products.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 11 -- The size of wine bottles could become the next addition to the growing list of trade disputes between the European Common Market and the United States.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union today lent its support to a sharp attack on Rumania for failing to join with the rest of the Soviet bloc in criticizing China's policies.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- A Soviet airliner crashed and exploded on take-off from the Irkutsk Airport in Siberia, killing all 97 persons aboard, travel officials said today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 11 -- Gun battles, sniping and fires broke out today in Belfast. It was the third day of violence since the Government invoked emergency powers of preventive detention.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Lawrence A. Tate, a 45-year-old former I.B.M. executive who for nearly a year and a half has contended that he is the victim of local police harassment, was sentenced in Village Court here this afternoon to a $1,000 fine and a year's probation on two misdemeanor convictions arising from a police drug raid on his home a year ago.

A mutual fund shareholders' suit filed here yesterday seeks to require Kansas City Southern Industries, Inc., and certain of its officers to return some $13.4-million of profits obtained from the sale of a controlling interest in Supervised Investors Services to Kemperco, Inc., in May, 1970.

After months of indecision Mayor Lindsay has switched his political affiliation from Republican to Democrat. The Mayor is still not saying whether he will seek the Democratic Presidential nomination next year, but his decision to press for "new national leadership" is likely to have important consequences for the Mayor himself, both political parties, and not least for the city.

Accusations that the Broadway Maintenance Corporation and the Welsbach Corporation rigged bids to obtain millions of dollars in street-lighting contracts with the city were made yesterday in testimony at a perjury trial in Federal Court here.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Aug. 4 -- "The Black Power movement in Nam was kicking off good in 1968, it had unity up to 1970, but that year I saw skag was going to be a problem and separate the bloods," the black soldier said.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 -- India and the Soviet Union issued a joint statement tonight that Indian official sources said should be read as a declaration that the two countries hold "identical" views on the crisis in East Pakistan.

Every morning, Monday through Friday, Barbara Spurgeon, a 47-year-old mother of 10, gets up at 7:30 A.M., catches an 8:15 subway near her hotel in Brooklyn Heights, and rides into Manhattan to begin her day as a Dictaphone secretary at a Wall Street law firm.
MANKATO, Minn., Aug. 11 -- The Minnesota Vikings, one of the strongest teams in pro football, made two small trades today typical of a challenger beefing up for a run at the championship.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Legislation cutting welfare expenditures, tightening antifraud controls and requiring greater support of the aged by their adult children was approved today by the California Legislature.

LONDON -- The most noticeable result of women's lib in England is that most women have already benefited from it. To some extent, they are beginning to feel freer from doubletalk, doublethink, isolation and guilt. Worry about sexual role and sexual performance; physical exhaustion at the social and psychological load they have been carrying; distaste for the projected images of women -- all are being aired.
A 21-year-old man who resigned from West Point last September after being denied a discharge as a conscientious objector is receiving such a discharge from the Army.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Aug. 11 -- Suffolk County legislative officials, faced with community reaction against plans to expand the Suffolk County airport at Westhampton Beach, said today that public hearings would be held and "extensive consideration would be given to community feelings" before any expansion plan was put into effect.

LAKE OF THE OZARKS, Mo., Aug. 11--Lynn Townsend, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he was optimistic about the coming year for the auto industry because, despite inflation and high unemployment this year, people will still end up buying about 10 million cars.

HARTFORD, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- The Connecticut House of Represenatives late last night rejected a bill passed earlier by the Senate that would have repealed the recently enacted state income tax and substituted a sales tax of 6.5 per cent -- up from 5 per cent.

In a move to extend its operations outside the New York metropolitan area, Alexander's, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement for the acquisition of Jefferson Stores, Inc., a Florida chain of discount stores.

A handwritten message by McGeorge Bundy, President John F. Kennedy's adviser on national security, praising the vague wording of a 1963 press announcement on Vietnam policy, did not assert that such communiques "should say nothing in such a way as to fool the press without deceiving them," as reported last week in The New York Times.

The new Commerce Department standard for flame-resistant fabrics will change the nature of the textile industry in the next few years, Robert Bendheim, president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., said yesterday.

Thunderstorms from the northwest moved through the metropolitan area yesterday, deluging communities on Long Island Sound, knocking out electrical power in parts of Westchester County and uprooting trees in other suburban areas.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 -- In the month before a visit by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party chief, Yugoslav leaders are talking louder than ever of their preparedness to mobilize the nation against any aggressor.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and 10 other inmates at the Federal prison here who were involved in a hunger strike were moved today to a medical center for Federal prisoners at Springfield, Mo.

A casting director's dream of a television-era politician, Mayor Lindsay, wearing levis and an open-at-the-throat blue shirt, sat in a Colorado ski lodge chatting casually over cheeseburgers and beer.

Delegates to the convention of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. took a strong "Buy American" stand yesterday and called for regulation of imports that they said were destroying the jobs of American workers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Red Reality turned out to be the real thing in the $35,300 Bernard Baruch Handicap today. The Cragwood Stable's late-running star swept over his opposition in the 1-16-mile-mile turf event under the guidance of Jorge Velasquez, and won by one length from the Tartan Stable's Shelter Bay.
Wanna buy a duck? A cold duck, that is.

The outstanding performer in the Summer National Championships each year receives the Sally Fishbein Trophy. In two decades the winners have been exclusively male, and they have owed their successes largely to good performances in the Spingold master team championship.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Secretary General Thant appealed today for more money to help send relief to East Pakistan.

NEWARK, Aug. 11 -- Robert J. Burkhardt, a former New Jersey Democratic state chairman, and State Senator Willard B. Knowlton, a Bergen County Republican, were indicted separately here by a Federal grand jury on charges of bribery and extorting a total of $211,000 from a New York construction company.

STERLING, Va. -- Andrew T. Weil, M.D., is a doctor with only one patient -- himself. He lives alone here in a house surrounded by woods and filled with exotic Amazonian plants, not far from Washington's Dulles International Airport. He is conducting a private experiment.
Following is a transcript of the statement by Mayor Lindsay announcing his switch in political parties, as recorded by The New York Times:

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 11 -- With an air of resignation evident in the way they moved and the way they played, the Giants went back to their workouts today for the first time since their double-knockout of recent days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Japanese Ambassador to the United States cautioned the Nixon Administration tonight to consult fully with Tokyo on further initiatives in China policy and denounced the Chinese Communists' accusations of Japanese military ambitions as "nonsense."
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- The nearly extinct California condor may be alive and well in Mexico.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 11 -- Larry Stahl, who earlier saved the Padres with a diving, backhanded catch in center field, scored an unearned run in the 12th inning that gave San Diego and Dave Roberts a 1-0 victory over the Mets tonight.
The Controller of the Currency has issued a warning to the presidents of all national banks that "unsafe and unsound" practices involving municipal bond transactions are increasing in number.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- President Nixon has sent to Congress a proposal to establish a Cabinet-level Department of Natural Resources. The department would take over responsibilities now scattered among six existing departments and agencies -- Interior, Agriculture, Defense, Commerce, Transportation and the Atomic Energy Commission.

QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 11 -- A young Long Island marine who spent 18 months as a prisoner of war was acquitted today of charges that he had run from his unit and, when captured, had made propaganda statements broadcast over the Hanoi radio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Government sued Stokely-Van Camp, Inc., today for all the profits the company has made from Gatorade, a soft drink that is advertised as unusually effective in quenching thirst.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- A bull market in the thoroughbred racing stock was confirmed last night as the 51st annual Saratoga Yearling Sales began.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Rest Assured, an aged brown gelding from the Bennett College stables, was the class of the field in the open jumper competition at the Sussex County Horse Show today and won the blue ribbon with speed to spare.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Between 75,000 and 90,000 Indonesians are still in prison without trial five or six years after being arrested as Communists, according to a memorandum by Amnesty International made public here today.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The General Motors Corporation has authorized its dealers to start selling 1972 model cars now instead of waiting until the official introduction date of Sept. 23.

In his July 27 letter, Prof. Joseph Zaremba states, "Mankind has shown a remarkable ability to find new resources to replace those used up, and has shown an equal ability to adapt to new environments, such as reduced living space, as the need arose."

A double-round team match on 18 boards between Switzerland and Bavaria, played at Kaufbeuren, Germany, last month, was won by the Swiss, 19 1/2-16 1/2. The Bavarians, with Grandmasters Wolfgang Unzicker and Lothar Schmid on the top boards, had tied, 16-16, in a similar match played last year at Lucerne, but this year, in their absence, the Swiss team pulled ahead.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- China is not a new land settled by nineteenth-century pioneers devoted to self-determination. The Chinese have a distinctly non-American background. The concept of Taipei's autonomy under Peking's sovereignty comes from two thousand years' experience in the world's largest political unit, which invented bureaucracy and civil service examinations when Europe was still in the Dark Ages.

Mayor Lindsay and his wi,fe, Mary, made their first public appearance after his announcement ,that they had become Democrats before an exuberant throng of 1,200 supporters last night in an atmosphere akin to[ that of a campaign kickoff.

STONY BROOK, N. Y. -- The pesticide industry tells us that DDT controls insects, yet frequently DDT creates more insect problems than it solves. DDT is a broad-spectrum poison that kills all insects, including parasitic and predatory insects that help keep pests under control.

DALLAS, Aug. 11 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie called today for an immediate $3-billion tax cut and a new $4-billion program of Federal aid to states and cities to reverse what he called the Nixon Administration's "no win" economic policy.
David Rockefeller reaffirmed yesterday the appointment of William P. Bundy as editor of the quarterly journal Foreign Affairs.
By almost every measure the draft is an odious business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Nixon and the Civil Aeronautics Board today divided the interisland tourist routes of the Central and South Pacific between Continental Airlines and Pan American World Airways, ending a hard-fought battle.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 11 -- (UPI) -- A Brigham Young University official said yesterday he banned a new Stanley Kramer film from the campus because it showed materialistic parents, blood-thirsty hunters, sex-obsessed summer campers and doltish counselors.

HOUSTON, Aug. 11 -- Scientists said here today that preliminary scrutiny of the photographs and rocks brought back from the moon by the Apollo 15 astronauts tended to confirm some previously held ideas about the moon's formation but that new subjects for inquiry had been raised.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said this morning that the Supreme Court decision that he had not qualified as a candidate for the presidential election on Oct. 3 was illegal and that he still considered himself a candidate.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States picked up 21 points on Britain in the final event of the Admiral's Cup series, but the American yachtsmen wound up second to the Britons and Prime Minister Edward Heath, who won the trophy today.

The state administration ordered local welfare officials yesterday to refer to District Attorneys cases in which welfare recipients classified as employables were failing to report to job centers or work or training.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1971 corn crop at a record of 5,345,057,000 bushels, 30 per cent more than last year's.

The Justice Department and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were reported yesterday to be preparing to seek Federal court approval this week or early next week for proposed consent decrees in settlement of three antitrust suits.

Arbatov's Pravda article on Washington-Peking relations was originally prepared as a classified memorandum for Mr. Brezhnev and his Politburo comrades. WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Leading Democrats opened their arms, but not necessarily their hearts, to Mayor Lindsay of New York today.

Sport Fishing USA, a profusely illustrated 464 - page volume produced by the Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife, presents a sweeping portrayal of a pursuit that as early as 1955 involved the expenditure of billions of dollars annually.

Mayor Lindsay, Who made himself the state's most powerful Democrat and a front-running candidate for Governor yesterday, has told his staff that he wants to stay "somewhat detached" from the internal politics of his new party, but does intend to campaign hard around the state for a Democratic Legislature in 1972.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Calling for the United States to end or ease its insistence on a "two China" policy, three long-time China scholars said today that Taiwan has been used for 20 years to mount covert offensive operations against mainland China.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested 25 persons in nine states today in what its director, J. Edgar Hoover, called a "major crackdown" against organized interstate gambling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Environmental Defense Fund sued in Federal District Court here today to halt the Tennessee Valley Authority's construction of the $69-million Tellico Dam, which it said would destroy what it called "historic and sacred" Cherokee Indian village sites.
Senator George McGovern charged yesterday that President Nixon's economic policies were a "total disaster" and said they would be the major isue in the campaign for President next year.

Mayor Lindsay is not the first Mayor of New York to abandon his Republican party enrollment and register in another party. Florello H. La Guardia took the same step in 1936, and in his case, too, national rather than local politics were a principal cause.
Trading was cautious yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade before the release of crop harvest estimates by the Agriculture Department.
The city reversed itself yesterday and announced that it would continue Blue Shield medical insurance for the 112,000 municipal employes now covered by contracts.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 -- Lufthansa, the West German airline, rejected tonight a new trans-Atlantic fare package worked out by other airlines at the end of a bitter conference that lasted more than six weeks. The veto threatened to touch off a price war over Trans-Atlantic fares next Feb. 1.

Before unisex, the hairdressing shop was clearly either his or hers. Women went their own way to beauty salons, while barber shops were as masculine as football locker rooms. These days, when you can't tell which twin has the shoulder-length locks or the pony tail, nothingis so square to the under-30 generaation (and some of its older followers) than going to the beauty parlor or the barber's.

SONGBE, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 -- In the most pacified province in South Vietnam, according to American security standards, the candidates campaigning for the lower house elections do not dare travel by road.

TEL GEZER, Israel -- "Biblical archeology," the romantic and evocative quest of gentle scholars who often seem bent on proving the Bible, is rapidly giving way to a nonpartisan science of "Syro - Palestine studies."
DAWSON CITY, Yukon Territory, Aug. 5 -- "As far as I know, this is the richest pay streak in the world," Gus Heitman said as he surveyed his claim in the heart of the Klondike gold fields.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Acting Premier Sisowath Sirik Matak said today that the Cambodian Army would mount a winter offensive with American air support and South Vietnamese ground forces against the Vietnamese Communists.
In announcing his switch to the Democratic party yesterday, Mayor Lindsay said his decision had been reached during his recent vacation with his wife, Mary, in the Colorado mountains.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its membership had approved a $20-million increase in authorized assistance funds for customers of member organizations that went into liquidation before the formation of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The Chappaqua Summer Theater, which started three years ago when a dozen high school students played "Antigone" to a loyal audience of parents, winds up its current season on Saturday as a repertory company of 75 young adults, playing to packed houses and promising a 50 per cent return to its stockholders.

Sailors Snug Harbor, founded in 1806 as a home for "aged, decrepit and worn-out seamen" is seeking court permission to move from the site it has occupied on Staten Island for almost a century and a half to North Carolina.

In your Aug. 6 editorial you call for the immediate suspension of United States aid to Pakistan, pointing to increasing evidence that the Bengali resistance is "deep-rooted and spreading." In his report from New Delhi appearing Aug. 8 Sydney Schanberg confirms that West Pakistan's military repression in East Pakistan is not succeeding and warns that the specter of an international war is hovering over the continent.

The bloodiest rioting in the fifty years of Ulster's existence as a separate Irish province, united with Britain, is threatening to destroy self-rule in Northern Ireland. It is also erasing the best hope in years for peaceful reconciliation of the province's two warring religious communities.

Prices surged on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday on a small wave of increased trading activity.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that it would move its administrative offices from the Villard Houses, a Renaissance revival landmark on Madison Avenue, into a $21.5-million building to be constructed at First Avenue and 55th Street.

The Mexican Government took steps yesterday to stabilize the price of Frasch-process sulphur by restricting production to assigned amounts. The Government itself is the majority stockholder in the two sulphur producers.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 11 -- At 9:37 A.M. today, in the offices of the American Consulate, final approval was received from Washington granting visas to the United States men's volleyball team for its trip to Cuba tomorrow.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- The ambassadors conducting the four-power talks on Berlin conferred for eight hours more today, bringing their current session to 17 hours.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Terry Neff of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in the second Lightning Class Division, and Edward Coneys of the Port Washington Y.C. in the second Blue Jay Midget Division scored repeat victories today in the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound Race Week on Manhasset Bay.
DUBLIN, Aug. 12 -- The Irish Government, after lengthy reflection on the violent crisis in the North, called today for abolition of the Government of Northern Ireland in its present form.

Satchel Paige was formally inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame this week, an honor that was simultaneously unearned and beneath him. BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 17 -- A trailer truck loaded with radioactive waste material, which has been sitting on a lot near Sunrise Highway here for more than a year, was set to roll tonight toward its final destination, a nuclear waste disposal site near Buffalo.

Prices continued to rise on a broad front in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday although the advance and turnover were less than on Monday. The upswing on Monday stemmed from President Nixon's plan to curb inflation and to strengthen the economy.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 17 -- A not-so-funny thing happened to Tidalium Pelo on the French trotter's way to Roosevelt Raceway this morning. When the van transporting Tidalium Pelo and and Une de Mai, the other French entrant in Saturday night's $125,000 Roosevelt International, from the quarantine station at Clifton, N. J., reached Garden City, Tidalium Pelo reared and bounced against the wall of the truck, bruising his right hip.

Brooklyn Borough President Sebastian Leone and City Council Finance Chairman Mario Merola called on the Board of Estimate and City Council yesterday to unite in urging a state subsidy to save the 30-cent bus and subway fare.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- The Big Four ambassadors, still pressing to negotiate a settlement of the Berlin problem, conferred for six more hours today and emerged indicating that a conclusion of their meetings was much on their minds.

BOSTON -- President Nixon on Aug. 15 announced the de facto devaluation of the dollar. The moment he instructed Secretary of the Treasury Connally to suspend gold payments, the fixed-exchange system set up in 1944 at Bretton Woods became part of history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froelke has ordered new disciplinary action against nine officers and enlisted men previously cleared of criminal charges stemming from the Mylai mass killings.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 17 -- Vic Seixas and Alex Olmedo were defeated in the second round of the 72d annual Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club today.
New York State plans to switch its monthly lottery to a weekly lottery around the end of the year, to provide ticket-buyers with "faster action" and to provide the state with, hopefully, more money.
The spectacular "Nixon rally" kept rolling through Wall Street yesterday with automobile stocks leading the parade.
SAIGON, Wednesday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- American artillerymen moved west along the demilitarized zone yesterday to support South Vietnamese troops in the sixth day of a North Vietnamese drive.

The New York Mets need all the help they can get these days and one fellow who could have supplied the extra oomph was playing center field yesterday for the Kansas City Royals in the Yankee Stadium. He is Amos Otis and the flounderers from Shea Stadium have no one to blame but themselves. They had him but let him get away.

VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 17 -- International Grandmaster Larry Evans of Reno retained his lead, by half a point, when he drew with International Grandmaster Pal Benko of New York in the eighth round of the United States open chess championship yesterday.

VALLETTA, Malta, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Union, which is said to be seeking air and naval facilities on this Mediterranean island between Sicily and Libya, has told the new Maltese Government that it is "favorably ready to consider a request for economic assistance," informed sources said today.

DENVER, Aug. 17 -- Is the cash dividend obsolete? Genial, rapid-talking Robert M. Abisch seems to think so. He is certainly convinced that this is true as far as mutual funds are concerned, and he thinks it is possible that corporate cash dividends are obsolete as well.
HONG KONG, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A typhoon killed more than 90 people in Hong Kong and surrounding waters today when it struck the British colony head-on with 130-mile-an-hour winds and 12 inches of rain.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined as much as $3 a bale yesterday on general liquidation.
PAGE, Ariz., Aug. 17 -- Secretary of Interior Rogers C. B. Morton is moving with apparent ease among the bureaucrats and politicians on the eighth day of his month-long tour of 17 Western states.
The Neighborhood Police Team system went into effect yesterday in two more precincts, including for the first time, the entire area covered by one precinct.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- Port Authority transit buses resumed their runs out of the Homewood garage at 4 A.M. today, ending an eight-day walkout that began after a black driver had been suspended for wearing a "Free Angela Davis" button.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Dorothy McConville's Go Blow Your Horn scored his second straight victory today in the Hamilton Purse before 12,282 at Atlantic City race track.
The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that a $50-million-a-year gambling syndicate controlled by members of organized crime had been smashed with the arrests of 11 men and three women.
Fresh from a two-day interlude at Saratoga, Howard J. Samuels predicted yesterday the Offtrack Betting Corporation would be handling $1-million a day by October.
Cafe Chauveron, one of the few remaining grand luxe French restaurants in the city, has closed its doors for good.

ALGIERS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- President Nixon's economic program will require a "fundamental revision" of the Tehran and Tripoli agreements on crude oil prices. The Algerian Government newspaper El Moudjahid-The Combatant -- said today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Dr. R. Bernard Finch was ordered released on parole today from a life term in the slaying of his wife.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- The policy of Erich Honecker, the new East German leader, directed at "fencing off" his Communist state from West Germany is assuming ever stronger forms, according to his party press.
Hurried executive meetings and detailed studies of President Nixon's sweeping new economic program took place yesterday in corporate conference rooms across the country.

The Beacon Press, a nonprofit publishing branch of the Unitarian Universalist Association, announced yesterday that it would publish a 3,000-page, four-volume version of the Pentagon's secret study of United States involvement in Indochina.
Thomas F. Patton announced yesterday his retirement as chairman and chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corporation.

President Nixon seems to be making a habit of the bombshell approach to major news announcements. The pattern is becoming predictable relatively short preliminary notice of a major announcement, a broadcast detonation of some radical change in policy, and finally a hectic scramble in the news media to report and, when possible, to interpret that change.

TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- With all the furor over President Nixon's announcement of a 10 per cent surtax on imports to the United States, Japanese manufacturers have been making sideward glances at what some of them have dubbed a "chewing gum and chocolate war."
President Nixon appealed here last night to the nation's "moral power" and for "temporary sacrifice" to back up his new economic program.

ATHENS -- A Greek minister complains: "We only have problems with our friends; our enemies sit back and hope they can benefit." He referred to Greece's expulsion from the Council of Europe, the row about continuing U. S. military aid and festering behind-the-scenes arguments in NATO.
The prosecution's chief witness in a loan-shark conspiracy case named a missing defendant yesterday as the go-between in getting $12,000 in loans for him over a long period of time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Amid governmental and public confusion over the specifics of President Nixon's 90-day freeze on wages and prices, the Office of Emergency Preparedness said today that policy guidelines on wage-price controls would be issued before the end of the week.
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Super S.D.R. has reared its head in the worldwide debate now under way over monetary reform following President Nixon's announcement he would suspend the dollar's links with gold.

FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 17 (AP) -- A military judge has promised to rule on a defense motion just 30 minutes before Col. Oran K. Henderson of the Army goes on trial on charges of trying to conceal the Mylai mass killings.
The formation of a partnership that will conduct a worldwide brokerage business in commodity futures was announced yesterday by the Louis Dreyfus Corporation and ACLI International, Inc.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 17 -- Frank W. Sharp, key figure in a stock transaction scandal, testified for three hours and 40 minutes before a Travis County grand jury today after first invoking the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- In Paris today, just before flying to Washington, Paul Adolph Volcker, the United States Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told reporters, "The dollar is healthier today than it was at the weekend."

The New York office Of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused 19 individuals and corporations of having misused $1.9-million raised in a December, 1969, underwriting of the shares of Manor Nursing Centers, Inc.

In a few weeks two human sperm banks are expected to open for business in New York, providing facilities where, for a fee, any man may have his semen frozen and stored indefinitely for use in the procreation of a child perhaps decades later.
The controller of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had issued checks to Herbert Itkin after receiving bills from him for professional services.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Senator Edward W. Brooke, who has often been at odds with the Nixon Administration, strongly endorsed today the President's foreign policy and said his "quest for a generation of peace . . . entitles him to the trust and support of every American."

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was "deeply troubled" by the impact of President Nixon's wage-price freeze on the 65,000 men in the city's uniformed services, whose contract expired last December.

Clifford Tweter, president of Western Bancorporation, was elected chief executive officer of Western and Norman Barker, president of United California Bank, was elected chief executive officer of United California.
Can a coffee shop charge 5 cents more today for a cup of coffee than it did on Friday?
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The United States surcharge on imports and the unresolved questions about the value of the dollar caused continuing anxieties today among American and other businessmen in Europe.

The forthcoming season of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center will offer plays by Arthur Miller, Friedrich Schiller, Edward Bond and Shakespeare at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Each production will run for seven consecutive weeks, preceded by 12 previews. The cast will be announced later.

In a move to broaden its competition, the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America has invited license-holders from other racing groups to enter its Enduro Race Sunday at the Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit.
The Aug. 10 article by C. D. Darlington on the Op-Ed page concludes with these sentences:

President Nixon told an enthusiastic audience of Roman Catholics here last night that they could count on his help in efforts to reverse the current trend toward the closing of financially troubled parochial schools.

" Cymbeline" is one of Shakespeare's most inconstant works, which is why it might be easy to forgive its duplicities and call it modern. In his production for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, A. J. Antoon, the director, has changed the title to "The Tale of Cymbeline."
Pressure mounted yesterday for the Government to allow a floating price on industrial gold, as manufacturers of gold products were squeezed by higher world prices.

An apparent "frequency disturbance" in the power system in upstate New York caused brief blackouts in sections of Long Island and Queens and a temporary 8 per cent voltage reduction throughout New York City and Westchester County late yesterday afternoon.

A model program for reducing harmful automobile emissions is likely to start in New Jersey some time next spring. Empowered by the Legislature and helped by a Federal grant, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has for several years been developing equipment for the instant measurement of exhaust emissions. It is preparing now to require all cars registered in the state to be checked on this score as part of their annual inspection.

PEGNITZ, West Germany, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A United States helicopter carrying American troops to a field exercise exploded in the air early this morning, plunged into a hayfield, and all 37 soldiers aboard died in the flaming wreckage.

Their status under the order freezing wages and prices and to a lesser extent, under the import surcharge, continued yesterday to trouble commodity exchanges in New York and Chicago as they awaited clarification from Washington.

ATLANTA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The defending champion, Martha Wilkinson of Anaheim, Calif., scored a 7-and-6 triumph over Margaret Simpson Brass of Orlando, Fla., today in the first round of the United States women's amateur golf championship.
DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 18 -- A Government spokesman said today that Sheik Mujibur Rahman, imprisoned leader of the Bengali separatist movement of Pakistan, is already on trial.
Betty Furness probably doesn't realize it, but she accomplished considerably more during her brief career as Governor Rockefeller's No. 1 consumer watchdog than she knows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- The Army said today that it had found no evidence of misconduct by United States troops after investigating charges that they shelled a Vietcong hospital complex in Cambodia in February, 1969.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Both the training and main tracks at Roosevelt Raceway were extra-busy this morning. Eight of the nine trotters in Saturday night's $125,000 International here worked out over one or both of the ovals.
Profit taking weakened most prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday following two sessions of good advances as most issues declined in slower trading.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company introduced today its new Continental Mark IV and all-new Montego series as part of a 1972 lineup that included only minor refinements in other models.
Looking like a man on the campaign trail, Mayor Lindsay got a mild reception yesterday during a shirt sleeves walking tour of a predominantly black Brooklyn neighborhood.

PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- French officials said today that France would continue her current series of nuclear tests in the South Pacific despite protests from Japan and New Zealand and a Peruvian threat to break relations.

Jim Grabowski, who made up half the Green Bay Packers' $1-million rookie running-back duo in 1966, was placed on waivers yesterday. "It was a move we had to make," said Dan Devine, the Green Bay coach. "I was afraid he was going to get hurt."

Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed a special task force of deputy administrators and accountants from the city's Finance Administration to conduct a thorough review of the fiscal operations of the city's Muncipal Loan Program.

The Government of South Africa, true to its promise, is giving President H. Kamuzu Banda of Malawi a punctiliously correct and warm reception on his state visit. What makes this a matter of note is that Dr. Banda is black, while his cordial white hosts in Pretoria are the same men who ruthlessly enforce a policy of apartheid in their own country.
The haunting taste and smell of fall was in the air along the East Coast recently, reminding some sportsmen that duck hunting is not far away.
FLAT ROCK, N. C. -- Carl Sandburg's last home was a strange dwelling place for a prairie poet and biographer of Lincoln.

President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller had breakfast together in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, and they talked about aid to parochial schools, Mr. Nixon's new economic program, welfare reform and revenue-sharing -- but not, the Governor insisted, about political matters, such as Mayor Lindsay's switching from the Republican to the Democratic party.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Louis Lee Haggin put up $2,500 to supplement his Cohasset Tribe in the six-furlong, $42,500 Sanford Stakes today, and he walked off with first money of $25,500.

HOUSTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Cynthia Potter, in fourth place going into the finals, sparkled on her last three optional dives today to win her fourth straight national Amateur Union one-meter outdoor diving championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to delay court-ordered integration of the Corpus Christi, Tex., school district under a massive busing plan originally proposed by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 18 -- The chiefs of state of Syria, Egypt and Libya met here tonight to approve a constitution for the Federation of Arab Republics, but faced more urgent business on their agenda -- the crisis with Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Controller General of the United States ruled today that funding of foreign military aid will cease Sept. 1 unless the Nixon Administration meets a demand by Congress for a military-aid document.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The United States has made its first move to muster support for a "two China" policy in the General Assembly, which opens next month.

The details on the later games of the match between Tigran Petrosian and Viktor Korchnoi, two Soviet grandmasters, played in Moscow last month, have at last become available in the West. Petrosian won 5 1/2-4 1/2, and gained the right to meet Bobby Fischer of the United States in the match that will determine the challenger for the world title held by Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.
LYNDHURST, N. J., Aug. 18 -- Officials of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission disclosed today that they were planning to construct and operate the world's largest garbage incinerator.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 18 -- The alleged slaying of several Vietnamese children, one of them in the presence of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, was described today at the 34-year-old officer's court-martial.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Heublein, Inc., a major wine producer, announced today an agreement with the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee, ending a nationwide boycott of the company's products.

Macy's New York, the metropolitan area's largest retailer, which last week announced that it would establish budget centers for low-priced goods, is going one step further. Besides planning seven such budget centers, mostly to be situated in the existing basements of its stores, the 14-store group will also open six Furniture Clearance Centers on Long Island and Westchester County.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered an investigation today into allegations that Anthony J. Russo, who refused to testify in the leaking of the secret Pentagon papers, has been mistreated in jail.

Stock prices retreated yesterday in a profit-taking and consolidation move that followed two days of market euphoria ushered in by President Nixon's dramatic new economic game plan. Mr. Nixon unwrapped his package dining a nationwide address Sunday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, said today that the union would continue its strike of West Coast docks despite a request from the Nixon Administration that the stoppage be terminated.

How time goes by. Here it is, "The Last Whole Earth Catalog" already, and some people hadn't even gotten it straight yet what the first one was, or any of the 14 in between. Well, happily for them, among the smallest trinkets in this huge plum pudding of a publication is Stewart Brand's history of the venture he founded.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18 -- City officials offered today to turn over a 61-acre section of New Haven Harbor at "virtually no cost" to any developer who promised to build an island there for business and leisure use.

When Mel Stottlemyre is sharp, he is the kind of pitcher baseball people call "an artist," and he was artistically sharp last night. He held the Kansas City Royals to four hits and pitched the New York Yankees to a 3-1 victory at Yankee Stadium, closing out a home stand during which the Yankees won eight of 13 games.
Striking unions in many sections of the nation defied yesterday the Nixon Administration's call for a return to work during the 90-day wage and price freeze imposed last Sunday.

Milton Lipkins, an assistant vice president of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation, was characterized as a sophisticated corrupter and as a victimized businesssman in summations yesterday by the prosecution and the defense at his perjury trial in Federal Court here.

The government's chief witness in a loan-shark conspiracy case admitted under cross-examination yesterday that he had lied to a Federal grand jury, the Westchester County District Attorney and other law enforcement agencies.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 18 -- Australia and New Zealand announced today that they would withdraw their combat forces from South Vietnam in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States announced today that Irish International Airlines would be barred from landing in New York unless American carriers -- long allowed to land only at Shannon Airport, 120 miles from Dublin -- are allowed to fly directly to the Irish capital. The ban would take effect in a year.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 -- Six candidates -- three white and three black -- are seeking the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Baltimore in a campaign that has started to heat up.

There are two types of Signs on the boarded-up windows and the padlocked doors of a number of small shops along the Upper East Side these sultry summer days. One type says, "On Vacation." The other says, "For Sale."

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Aug. 18 -- Although he said he had been "admonished not to participate," Lee Elder, a leading black professional golfer on the United States tour, has completed plans to compete in the South African championship and in an exhibition match against Gary Player near Johannesburg.

The State Department has replied with a non sequitur to Congressional criticism of United States support for Thai soldiers fighting in Laos. The department argued the other day that it was entitled to withhold compliance from the Geneva accord neutralizing Laos because of what it termed massive violations of neutrality by 80,000 North Vietnamese now in that country.

Seven prominent national conservation groups yesterday filed with William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, a petition calling on him to help stop interstate shipment of poisons used to kill coyotes.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18 -- President Nixon declared today that the international elements of his new economic policy were designed to meet "the need to revalue the currencies of the world."
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Anger, puzzlement and even some humor marked the struggle by American tourists in Europe today to exchange the fewest dollars for the most foreign currency.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- Tommie Agee, battling a sore right knee and a brief slump, sparked the Mets to a 3-2, 10-inning victory over Los Angeles tonight, a victory that allowed them to win their only series on this four-city road trip.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- President Nixon's effort to blame international speculators for the troubles of the dollar were dismissed as a red herring today by international bankers and corporate officials here.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Jan Coehlo can go back to baking brownies for the Hollywood Hills High School football team and leave the quarterbacking duties to the boys.

Oscar Mayer Co., Inc., meat processors, realized a rise of 108.9 per cent in earnings for the third fiscal quarter ended July 31, on a sales gain of 9.2 per cent, according to the results announced yesterday. Similar increases were shown for the nine months period.
Following are developments yesterday affecting consumers and wage-earners under the 90-day wage and price freeze:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Government officials said today they assumed that commodity futures trading in soybean oil and meal, frozen orange juice and pork bellies came under President Nixon's 90-day price freeze.

HOBSON CITY, Ala., Aug. 18 -- While angry, young Negroes tried to shout him down, Gov. George C. Wallace challenged the Federal Government again today by ordering two Alabama school boards to ignore a court-approved desegregation plan.

MIAMI, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The United States scored its second straight victory in the Olympic volleyball elimination in Havana tonight, defeating Mexico in a match much tougher than the 3-0 score indicated.

BAY SHORE, L. I. -- "Man can drop down a mountainside, float back up again, soar through a canyon, merely by inhaling and exhaling, by flipping his feet a little bit," said Bob Shorout, his gin and tonic forgotten, his eyes far away. "You drink in all that beauty and it's your own private domain. It's especially yours because you can't communicate down there, you can't turn to your buddy and say, 'Wow.'

A group of Manhattan shoe-store employes who have been buying lottery tickets for two and a half years won one of the three $100,000 grand prizes in the July New York State Lottery, which was drawn yesterday.
YENAN, China -- Yenan, this sacred place of the Chinese revolution, has the air of a frontier town that has known better days.
QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 8 -- "Your legs, are they wood or real?" the elderly Vietnamese in soiled garments asked.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- No country has been more affected than Japan by President Nixon's twin stunners -- his proposed visit to Peking and his new economic policy. So Japanese officials here are ruefully quipping that what happens twice may happen three times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission warned banks today to make sure, in exercising securities - transaction orders for their customers, that the order in question was not illegal, as for example the sale of an unregistered security.
The 90-day wage-price freeze applies to housing rents even if landlords and tenants agreed on an increase before Aug 15, the Office of Emergency Preparedness said yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 18 -- The Greek Government bowed to worldwide protests tonight and drastically revised its draft press law, which called for suspension of newsmen who failed to heed "Hellenic-Christian traditions".
Daily and Sunday newspaper ads for discount stores hit a new peak last year, according to the annual census of the industry compiled by Discount Store News.
A few news items regarding magazines crossed the desk yesterday and are worthy of mention. In ascending order of circulation, they involve the Saturday Review, Family Weekly and Reader's Digest.
A city patrolman was arrested yesterday on a charge of having sold $10,000 in counterfeit $10 bills to an undercover Secret Service agent in a Queens diner last month.
Interest rates on new issues of tax-exempt bonds moved down sharply yesterday, but this week's stupendous rally in prices of Government and corporate bonds lost some of its vigor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Nixon's request for a year's delay in implementing welfare reform has sharply reduced the prospect that the welfare program will be enacted before the 1972 election.

There could be worse places to spend a Wednesday matinee than in an air-conditioned theater watching a highly sophisticated "three-act" plotless ballet that also has great popular appeal. Certainly, one of the best places to be yesterday afternoon was at the State Theater, where the New York City Ballet presented George Balanchine's "Jewels" in the first of six matinees during its two-week nonsubscription season.

City Council President Sanford D. Garelik yesterday challenged Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's assertion that the city streets were safer and warned that such statements could create "a false sense of security" in the people of the city.

Exeuctone, Inc., announced yesterday the election of N. A. Karr as chairman of the board. Mr. Karr, who had been president since 1962, will be succeeded by Edward Brody, who had been executive vice president. Philip H. Seaman, the former chairman, was elected chairman of the executive committee.
Two Brooklyn teenagers, one of them 14 years old, were arrested early yesterday and charged with the mugging murder Monday of a telephone company employe.
When the Berkshire Boy Choir gave a concert last year in the Medieval Sculpture Court of the Metropolitan Museum, this listener found it to be an extraordinarily good choir.

The sleek new highways begun under the Eisenhower Administration are nearing completion at the edges of the metropolitan region, and they may have already set the basiccourse of suburban growth for the rest of this century.

Carlos Feliciano, a 42-year-old Puerto Rican nationalist, accused of trying to bomb the General Electric Building here, won a reduction in bail yesterday from $150,000 to $25,000. He had sought the reduction unsuccessfully for more than a year.

Hidden under its recent "smiling offensive" is the true nature of the Peking regime. A few civil words expressed by Chou En-lai have been blown up out of all proportion to their real intentions. Sweeping conclusions have been drawn that Red China is now abandoning its violent revolutionary principles.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese command today reported that 142 North Vietnamese and 22 South Vietnamese had been killed in the biggest battle in months just below the demilitarized zone.

SILIGURI, India -- I am one of the unfortunates who managed to escape from the massacre perpetrated on the morning of June 13th at Saidpur (Rangpur), a non-Bengali Muslim majority town of North Bengal in Bangla Desh. I call myself unfortunate because I left behind 150 members of my community including my parents, brothers, sister-in-law, nephew and nieces -- butchered by the goondas of the Pakistan army in collaboration with the non-Bengali police.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 18 -- Frank Froehling, lured back to the game last season after a five-year absence, put a decided threat from abroad out of contention for the 72d Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship in gaining the quarterfinals by defeating Georges Goven, France's No. 1 player, 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, today at Merion Cricket Club.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Jim Dietz, a 22-year-old New Yorker, turned in the first upset on the opening day of the European rowing championships today when he won his heat of the single sculls from the world champion, Alberto Demiddi of Argentina.
American Airlines, Inc. and Trans World Airlines, Inc., showed a sharp recovery in profits in the month of July, their reports disclosed yesterday.

Don Gullett of the Reds, who has never lost a game in Cincinnati in his two-year major league career, kept his record clean last night. The 20-year-old left-hander tossed his third shutout of the season, setting down the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-0.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 18 (AP) -- British troops in Northern Ireland shot and killed two armed civilians tonight. One of them was a deaf man, who could not hear an army order to surrender the pistol he was waving in the air.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The United Automobile Workers warned the Nixon Administration today that it would terminate its contracts with the auto companies and fight any extension of the wage freeze that would eliminate upcoming wage increases due the union.

More than 6,000 rush-hour commuters were trapped as long as two hours last night on four IND trains stalled in an East River tunnel. There was no Queens-bound service on the E and F lines between 6:25 P.M. and 8:20 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- You can't hear a concert yet or see a play at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. This enormous, white blockhouse of culture won't open officially until September. But you can eat there, in three restaurants, one upper, one middle and one lower class.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- The present management of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., counterattacked today Meshulam A. Riklis, a New York financier, for offering to back with $10-million a dissident group of stockholders if they won control of the financially troubled company.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 -- A hearing on the future of radio station WSTC, owned by Kingsley Gillespie, publisher of The Stamford Advocate and The Greenwich Time, has been set for Oct. 19 by the Federal Communications Commission.
Andrew V. McLaglen's "Fools' Parade" is one of those films, very rare in recent years, that restores faith in ordinary movie-going as a reasonable and even privileged way of passing time.

BILLINGS, Mont., Aug. 18 -- Mining men and conservationists took opposing stands today on the proposed development of copper, nickel and chromium mining in the Bear-tooth Mountains of south central Montana.

Bobby Riggs of Plandome, L. I., a former national tennis champion, and Bob Howe of Australia will meet in the first singles match today as the defending United States senior team faces Australia in the challenge round for the Stevens Cup at the Town Tennis Club, 430 East 56th Street.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 18 -- Two Jackson policemen were in critical condition and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was in fair condition after a gunfight early today between the police and members of a black separatist organization.

BEIT SAHUR, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, Aug. 18 -- For the first time since the six-day war of 1967, moderate Arab leaders of the west-bank area of Jordan have managed to meet and adopt a common stand on a question that, though substantially economic, has clear political importance.

A tentative agreement in principle for the merger of Sternco Industries, Inc., and Hartz Mountain Pet Food, Inc., into the American Home Products Corporation was announced yesterday by the three concerns.

What a strange world it must be that the President of the United States, the Secretary of the Treasury and those highly publicized leading Government economists inhabit. Can it really be that in their world there are no bills piling up month after month, year upon year?
The dollar displayed some improvement yesterday in foreign-exchange trading in the New York market where the volume of business also picked up from Tuesday's levels.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Charlie Harper's ballooned-up right ankle was swathed in elastic tape today. HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Westchester Country Club retained the Hoffhine Memorial Trophy today in the club's 28th annual Metropolitan invitation team tournament, but only after finishing in a tie with Winged Foot with a four-man gross of 292.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 19 -- The sitar players looked glum and confused.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Ron Troyer, a 27-year-old crane operator from Williamsfield, Ohio, stood off the challenge of Gary Anderson of Axtell, Neb., an international champion, today and retained the national high-power rifle championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A Texas school district won a temporary reprieve in the Supreme Court today from an extensive busing order.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- President Nixon's plans for the domestic economy are "badly out of whack," a leading economic adviser to two Democratic Presidents said today.

Your recent editorial hailing the Supreme Court decision outlawing aid to parochial schools states that "by a narrow five-to-four majority it approved the use of Federal funds -- a practice that has been followed for some years under a 1963 law -- for construction of such buildings as scientific laboratories and gymnasiums for church-related colleges."

Fourteen newspapers, including The Denver Post and The Houston Chronicle, have now dropped the column "On the Right," by William F. Buckley Jr. The cancellations continue in the wake of publication, in Mr. Buckley's magazine, National Review, of fictitious Vietnam war secrets.

AREA A -- If the weather holds up for the weekend, weakfish, blues and tuna are expected to remain in abundance at Barnegat Ridge. The blues are running up to 12 pounds offshore, and 2 to 3 pounds off the beach.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 -- George Reichhelm of the host Cedar Point Y.C. sailed into a one-point lead for the national championship of the Atlantic Class today after the first two races in the five-race regatta were completed on Long Island Sound in light easterly air.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 19 -- The "dollar crisis" was no crisis in China. Even here in this commercial capital of the People's Republic there was no public evidence that anybody was paying the slightest attention to Washington's "new economic policy."

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday proposed a meeting of different segments of the securities industry to discuss the recommendations of William McChesney Martin Jr. for the development of a single, nationwide, central auction market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Aug. 14 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Personal income of all Americans dropped $11-billion in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $859-billion, the Commerce Department said today.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

VIENNA, Aug. 19 (Reuters)--Rumania today suddenly summoned a joint meeting of the Communist party's Central Committee, the State Council and the Council of Ministers following a meeting yesterday between President Nicolae Ceausescu and the Soviet Ambassador in Bucharest.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- A policeman wounded in a gun battle with members of a black separatist group died today and murder charges were filed against 11 Negroes.

VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Grandmaster Larry Evans of Reno lost his half-point lead briefly, but regained it with the end of the 10th round in the United States Open Chess Championship yesterday.

WHITEMARSH, Pa. Aug, 19 -- Mike Hill, who drove a beer truck for five years before deciding on a career in professional golf, moved into the lead of the $150,000 Industrial Valley Bank-Philadelphia Classic today with a seven-under-par 65.
The freeze on apartment rents remained widely misunredstood and occasionally circumvented, a spot check of offered apartments here indicated yesterday.

Builders and would-be buyers of homes were given another incentive yesterday when the Federal Home Loan Bank Board authorized savings and loan associations to make conventional home loans with down payments as low as 5 per cent.
Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that "revolutionary changes" might be necessary in this country's institutions if they were to be "relevant to people's needs."
Efforts by Robert L. Vesco to appeal a court order directing him to testify before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 24 were rejected yesterday.

The Cubiculo Dance Theater's retrospective series, concluded Wednesday evening, has had the added interest of presenting a sprinkling of new works amidst the older dances. Among the most intriguing was "Holiday Time at Stanley Brown's."
United States trade with Japan -- now $11-billion a year in exports and imports -- will be sharply reduced by the emergency economic measures taken by Washington.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Despite a couple of awkward jumps, Winigo carried the Montpelier silks to victory today in the $18,900 Promise Hurdle, the feature event on Saratoga's card. Winigo paid $3.20 for $2 in taking the 1 7/8-mile hurdle contest.

The appointment by Mayor Lindsay of a special task force to conduct a thorough review of the fiscal operations of the city's municipal loan program is welcome evidence of high-level concern over charges of widespread corruption in the program.
A diary kept by Drew Pearson, the Washington columnist, from 1949 to shortly before his death in September, 1969, will be published in three volumes by Holt, Rinehart Winston, starting next year.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday for the second consecutive session in slower trading.
The recovery of a service revolver taken from a policeman who was stabbed to death in the Bronx last fall led last night to the arrest of a 24-year-old Bronx man on a murder charge.

GREENSBORO, N. C. -- President Nixon's statement on the Austin, Tex., school case has come as a severe blow to the South. That may seem surprising, but only if one is unaware -- as Mr. Nixon certainly seems to be -- of the remarkable steps this region has taken in recent weeks to prepare itself for the inevitability of thorough, even traumatic racial change.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 19 -- Thirty leading Roman Catholics in Londonderry resigned from public office today in protest against the policy of the Government of Northern Ireland of interning suspects without trial and what the Catholics called British Army brutality.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- A small blue helicopter landed in the courtyard of Santa Maria Acatitla Federal Prison last night and guards assumed a visiting dignitary would step out. Instead, the police said today, a convicted American murderer and a Venezuelan counterfeiter scrambled aboard and escaped.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company realized a 39 per cent increase in earnings for the third fiscal quarter ended with July on a sales gain of 4.8 per cent, bringing the nine-month results to record levels, it was reported yesterday from the Akron, Ohio, headquarters.
Like a mule that won't gallop, offtrack betting's balky computer system rolled over on its back again yesterday.

State Supreme Court Justice David Ross, administrator of the city's Criminal Court, told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that by the end of the year no case in those lower courts should take longer than "three or four weeks" for disposition.

MIAMI, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The United States volleyball team defeated Puerto Rico, 3-0, tonight for its third straight victory in an Olympic elimination tournament being held in Cuba. Havana Radio reported the winning scores were 15-7, 15-4 and 15-8, with Vincent McFarlane, Dan Patterson and Larry Wendall showing up well for the American team.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The owners of a newly patented process for coating synthetic textiles believe it will be as important to plastics as xerography has been to paper. The consumer is promised improved washability and wetability, added comfort and resistance to static.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Federal judge has blocked a proposed merger of District 50 of the Allied and Technical Workers Union into the United Steelworkers of America.
ATLANTA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Laura Baugh, a 16-year-old Californian, and Beth Barry of Mobile, Ala., advanced to the final of the 71st United States Women's Amateur golf championship today.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Welfare clients in some parts of New York, California and Illinois will be required to take public service jobs or lose part of their welfare grants under a demonstration project announced today by President Nixon.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in very slow trading.

CONCORD, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Eleven states and the District of Columbia will become part of a new Federal Civil Defense radio network next year, Allan R. Zenowitz, regional director of the Office of Civil Defense, said today.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 20 -- With his quiet flair for the significant, Weeb Ewbank named Don Maynard, Larry Grantham and Winston Hill today as tri-captains of the New York Jets for Sunday's exhibition game with the Giants at Yale Bowl.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Fifteen sections of the North Sea bed were auctioned off to oil and industrial groups today for a total of $89.2-million.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The State Department took sharp issue today with the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, over his proposal that Israel promptly establish permanent government in the Arab territories occupied during the 1967 war.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- With William Levin's consistent Bold Reason in the role of overnight favorite, the oldest stakes on the American thoroughbred calendar, the Travers, will have its 102d running tomorrow. The 11/4-mile test for 3-year-olds has attracted a field of 11. The gross value will be $113,700 with the winner getting $68,220.
One of the largest jury awards ever made in an airline negligence suit was completed !yesterday with he delivery to American Airlines of the second of two checks totaling almost $11-million.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Six waves of United States B-52 bombers pounded South Vietnam's embattled northern front today in stepped-up raids designed to slow a 10-day-old North Vietnamese offensive.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Black Roman Catholic nuns have begun a drive for what has been a goal of blacks outside the church for some time -- community control of schools.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had approved for the first time portions of regional air standards for sulphur oxide and particulate matter in 15 states.

Anyone considering the purchase of some good Bordeaux wines for immediate drinking might give some thought to the 1967 vintage. Most of the best-known chateaux are in the shops now, are ready to be enjoyed and, considering the astronomical prices of so many wines, are genuine bargains.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 20 -- Daniel Ellsberg said last night that student antiwar activities were responsible acts and set an example for him in his release to the American press of the Pentagon papers.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 20 -- The $125,000 International Trot is expected to attract upward of 40,000 harness racing buffs to Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The season's largest turnout -- 36,935 has been tops so far -- will see what is believed to be the richest field ever assembled for a standard-bred event; the aggregate earnings of the nine horses representing six countries stand at $4,491,099.

A student planning to begin school in Britain next month sought this week to purchase Japanese yen to exchange later for pounds. But he was dissuaded from doing so by his Chicago bank, which pointed out to him the costs, difficulties and even risks that such a transaction involved.

Tucked away inside this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall is a Mozart piano concerto festival, one of the brightest ideas to strike anyone at Lincoln Center in some time. Thirteen concertos, or about half of Mozart's output, are being heard, and on Thursday night it was the turn of the three 1782 works numbered K. 413, K. 414 and K. 415, as melted down to piano quintet size by the composer.

LONDON, Aug. 20--Harold Wilson, reflecting Labor party discontent with Government policy, asked Prime Minister Heath today to call Paraliament back from recess for a debate on the situation in Northern Ireland.

A refurbished playhouse in the East Village is about to offer something new in vintage screen fare. Starting tomorrow. Theater 80 St. Marks will become what may be the only showcase ever devoted entirely to movie musicals.

The first year of legalized abortion in New York City has brought a substantial decline in maternity mortality. Also down significantly are the city's total birth rate and its rate of illegitimate births. Equally important in social terms, the year's experience shows that women of all ethnic and racial groups have availed themselves of the opportunity to prevent unwanted births legally -- and, in many cases, at little or no cost.

VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 19 -- The Rev. William Lombardy of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx, defeated International Grandmaster Larry Evans, Reno, in the 11th round of the United States Open Chess Championship at the Ventura Fairgrounds today. The victory gives Father Lombardy, an international grandmaster, undisputed possession of first place.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- A convention of 1,600 black Roman Catholics began today with many delegates debating whether they could remain in a church that they say is not "relevant" to its black members.

WASHINGTON -- A day care center that was opened here this summer for the benefit of 50 children of employes of the United States Office of Education is intended as a model for other employers throughout this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Corporate profits before taxes in the second quarter were up $3-billion from the first quarter and $6-billion from the year-earlier quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.
