PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 21 -- Red Cross officials of North Korea and South Korea met at this neutral armistice camp at noon yesterday in the first step toward talks to solve the problem of families divided by the Korean war.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 21 -- The Tokyo stock market appeared to be recovering a measure of calm today after a hectic week. Short, silver-haired, a trifle portly, with twinkling brown eyes and a gentle smile, Mr. Sears prefers to be thought of as one of the last of the real country lawyers.

CAIRO, Aug. 25 -- Angry shouts from defense attorneys challenging the legality of a three-man revolutionary tribunal disrupted the opening session this morning of the trial of the former Vice President, Aly Sabry, and other high officials arrested in May after a challenge to the leadership of President Anwar el-Sadat.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Ron Johnson, the Giants' No. 1 running back, will be up and walking tomorrow, according to Dr. Anthony Pisani, the club's physician, who operated on the player's right thigh today to eliminate a deep blood clot.

" I've told all the Democratic Presidential contenders that if they have only one day to spend looking at urban problems, come to my district," Representative Herman Badillo said the other day. "My district has it all."
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25 -- A state-auhtorized challenge to the constitutionality of the Vietnam war was dismissed today by United States District Court Judge Earl R. Larson.
Jerry Koosman won his first game in two months yesterday when he pitched the New York Mets to a 5-1 decision over the San Francisco Giants and abdicated as the medical freak of the baseball season.
BONN, Aug. 25 -- Voigtlander of Braunschweig, West Germany's oldest camera maker, will stop its production and close down in September, 1972, its parent company, Zeiss-Ikon, confirmed today.

City agencies have bid for 13,000 employable relief recipients to work for them under the new state law requiring such persons to work out the amount of their relief grants if the State Employment Service does not find private jobs for them.

HOUSTON, Aug. 25 -- Assistant Attorney General Will R. Wilson Jr. acknowledged today that he had gotten a $30,000, unsecured loan last August from a bank owned by Frank W. Sharp, a Houston real estate developer who was under investigation by Federal authorities on suspicion of stock fraud.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 26 -- "Washington overestimated the effect of the 'Nixon shock' here," a foreign diplomat said yesterday. "It expected Japan to crumble and revalue the yen in a panic."

The Ford Motor Company turned in a strong selling performance in the mid-August period, but it was not quite enough to prevent total sales for the entire industry to dip slightly below the 1970 level.

Judge Charles D. Breitel of the State Court of Appeals yesterday referred to the chief of the court a request by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Polk to keep their 3-year-old foster child Angela pending an appeal of a court directing them to return the child to an adoption agency.
Last fall, United Air Lines installed wider seats in its jets, touching off a "seat war" in which major airlines tried to out-do one another by providing more hip and leg room.

Discussions of America's health care problems usually begin with the assumption that this nation suffers from severe shortages in all the basic human and material resources required in this field. But at the current meeting of the American Hospital Association in Chicago much attention has been paid to the problem and costs of excess capacity.
Let's say you're a Schenley shareholder and you didn't like the terms under which Glen Alden took over your company. That's your prerogative, but what could you do about it?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The nation's military and defense contractors, at the request of the Defense Department, report that they are quietly making substantial reductions in the number of their employes who hold top-secret Government security clearances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- United States international monetary reserve assets declined by $221-million in July, the last full month before President Nixon's action suspending convertibility between the dollar and gold, the Treasury reported today.

The Consolidated Edison Company has asked the Atomic Energy Commission for quick approval on starting up its new 873,000-kilowatt nuclear plant at Indian Point to meet the "crucial requirements" for electricity here.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patricia Nixon will begin refurbishing the state rooms of the White House this fall, particularly in the Blue Room, where small receptions are held, and the Red Room, most dramatic of all the formal salons in the executive mansion.
The Puritan Sportswear Corporation, men's sportswear division of Warnaco, Inc., said yesterday that it would voluntarily freeze prices on all its merchandise until at least the end of the year.
Two children were injured, one of them seriously, yesterday afternoon when a building about to be demolished collapsed, partly burying the two boys in Brooklyn's Coney Island section.
Seven firemen were injured last night when they were showered with a barrage of bottles, bricks and other debris while responding to a large bonfire in the South Bronx.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Three former state troopers who were involved in a stakeout shooting in which two unarmed burglary suspects were killed were given suspended sentences today in Superior Court on perjury charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The president of the United Automobile Workers, one of the most outspoken opponents of President Nixon's new economic program, said today that his union would try to "accommodate" itself to the 90-day freeze "as a practical matter."

An orchestra composed of instrumentalists from 60 nations will be assembled here in October under the auspices of the Federation of People-to-People Programs, and will play three concerts in four days under the direction of Arthur Fiedler before disbanding.

Telephone users in this state seem likely to get a bill of rights to protect them against having to pay a bill for inadequate service. The proposed safeguards underscore the degree to which rising consumer pressure and administrative changes in the Public Service Commission have turned that state agency into a watchdog for the public, instead of the supine servant of the utilities it once was.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25 -- William L. Waller, who calls himself a redneck, won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination and almost certainly the Governor's office in yesterday's runoff primary with an unusual combination of black and white votes.

The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday that the railroad's net loss in July widened sharply to $27,953,761 from a deficit of $1,835,384 in June. In July, 1970, the first month after the road filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws, it had a loss of $33,924,696.
The Treasury announced plans late yesterday to raise about $1.25-billion by offering five-year, two-month notes at a special auction next Tuesday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 26 -- In a surge of attacks on allied installations yesterday, enemy forces shelled several American bases and sent explosions ripping through a huge American ammunition dump at Camranh Bay.

The Fibreboard Corporation announced yesterday the election of Melvin L. Levine as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Levine, formerly executive vice president, succeeds George W. Burgess, who becomes chairman and will continue as chief executive officer. Mr. Levine, 54 years old, prior to joining Fibreboard last year had been executive vice president of the United Fruit Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The nation's hospital directors who are meeting here today are reacting gingerly to President Nixon's wage-price freeze, with most of them saying they are willing to go along with the Executive order.

Neil A. Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, resigned his high-level desk job at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Washington to become the first University Professor of Engineering at the University of Cincinnati -- a position created especially for him.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Numbered Account was re-activated today, and as a $5,000 supplementary nomination, won the hearts of the favorite players in the crowd of 17,187 fans who saw the 80th running of the Spinaway, Ogden Phipps's 2-year-old filly, a Kentucky-bred daughter of Buckpasser, opposed half a dozen others of her age and sex in the six-furlong sprint and won by 2 1/2 lengths.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Ugandan troops advanced nearly 10 miles into Tanzania during border clashes, a high Government source said today.

Mayor Lindsay, citing the murders of nine New York City policemen this year, appealed formally yesterday to Attorney General John N. Mitchell to support new Federal legislation to halt the traffic in handguns.

The city commission investigating allegations of police corruption has obtained photographic and tape-recorded evidence showing dozens of policemen dealing with Harlem heroin dealers and gamblers, according to sources within and outside the commission.

Nearly all the bridge literature of the thirties and forties has been superseded in the last two decades. Bidding ideas have developed greatly, and even in the areas of play and defense there have been advances.

The 65-year-old owner of a small supermarket in Queens chased two gunmen who had held him up yesterday afternoon, intercepted their car, wrested a shotgun from one of them and in an exchange of fire mortally wounded the man.
On the Central Park Mall, in the green islands of Broadway above Lincoln Center, in playgrounds and small parks, men from the welfare rolls were at work yesterday morning, cleaning up the city.
Edward M. Bernstein, a Washington economic consultant with close ties to the United States Treasury, called yesterday for a basic reform in the structure of international financial reserves.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 25 -- Attorneys for the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., asked a three-judge Federal court today to initiate contempt of court proceedings against Gov. George C. Wallace.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Steve Thompson does not dislike football and he doesn't classify himself as "quote religious," but today the New York Jets' 6-foot-5-inch, 245-pound first-string defensive tackle announced his retirement from the sport because of his beliefs in God.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The dollar slumped further against all leading European currencies today as foreign exchange trading quickened. The markets were orderly but tense.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Pentagon's civil rights chief is resigning following reports that Defense Department officials have been unhappy with his performance in office.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Martha's Vineyard has always played host to a varied crowd of summer visitors, but each major group tends to gravitate toward a favored section of this 150-square-mile island, which is 45 minutes by ferry from Cape Cod.

Pork belly futures advanced 27 cents to 45 cents a 100-pounds yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in fairly active trading. The February, 1972, contract, the most actively traded, closed at $17.65 per 100 pounds up 33 cents.
MANILA, Thursday, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- A Government spokesman said that Communist guerrillas attacked a regional military headquarters early today and destroyed two Phillippine Air Force helicopters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- A scheduled trial of 21 militant South Vietnamese students charged with pro-Communist activities was indefinitely postponed today because none of the 16 defendants free on bail appeared in court.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 25 -- The father of Stephen M. Bingham, the attorney suspected of smuggling a gun into San Quentin Prison last Saturday shortly before an attemped escape in which six persons were killed, said tonight that his son could have been the unwitting instrument of an escape plot.

HONG KONG, Thursday Aug. 26 -- Peking announced today that Communist party committees had been formed in Szechwan, Tibet, Ningsia and Heilungkiang. The move completed the process of rebuilding the party at province level, where party committees were smashed during the Cultural Revolution, and many of the party leaders were purged.

Betty Friedan, the founder of the National Organization for Women, said yesterday that some woman, perhaps herself, would probably run against Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn in next year's Democratic primary.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday after profit taking in the afternoon erased most of the session's earlier gains.

DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia -- Shorn of the official State Department backing it had sought, the company of the Cafe La Mama in New York opened an abbreviated European tour at the Dubrovnik Festival the other night with the first of two scheduled performances.

PRAGUE, Aug. 25 -- An informal and apparently highly successful experiment in East-West relations ended this morning at Prague Airport, perhaps typically, with a rousing rendition of Handel's "Hallelujah" chorus.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Former West Virginia Attorney General C. Donald Robertson, his brother and a former Federal housing official were indicted today on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States.

S. de Villiers vainly tries to persuade us that our negative image of South Africa is a fiction invented by misinformed detractors [Op-Ed Aug. 3] we read of the political trial of the Very Rev. CLEVELAND. Aug. 25 -- Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted today a record-breaking goal of $13,267,355 for 1971-72 to maintain its vast network of medical and social service institutions in Israel and for programs in this country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu told his campaign managers today to proceed with plans for the October Presidential elections while American officials continued their efforts to try to salvage the appearance of a contested race.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 25 -- A man was killed and 35 people, mostly young women, were injured today in the worst bomb blast in Belfast this year.
The J. C. Penney Company, Ic., which operates many retail stores, had record sales and earnings in the fiscal second quarter and half year ended July 31, the company reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago Board of Trade announced today the implementation of a system designed to detect financial problems of member firms at an early stage and to protect nonregulated customer funds that might be affected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Steel importers appealed to the Treasury today for an exemption from the new 10 per cent import surcharge, on the ground that steel imports were as much controlled by quotas as exempted products like sugar, beef and oil.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Ralph Nader charged today that California's mountains, deserts and seacoast were being assaulted by speculators who bulldozed thousands of lots that had little or no prospect of becoming home sites.

PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 25 -- Before golf's newest tournament was a day old, Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player, two of the game's leading experts, were on their way home. Both were surprising victims in first-round upsets as the $200,000 national match-play championship began today.

BONN, Aug. 25 -- The West German Government formally endorsed today the tentative agreement on West Berlin reached Monday by negotiators for the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (AP) -The Baltimore Orioles dissipated a 6-0 lead, then rallied to beat the Chicago White Sox, 8-7, in a rain - shortened eight - inning game tonight.

A good deal of the bellicosity seems to have gone out of the verbal warfare between organized labor and the Administration over President Nixon's wage-price freeze.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Union lawyers representing affiliates of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. generally agreed today to avoid a massive court challenge to President Nixon's 90-day wage-price freeze. The Government of Nationalist China, which normally tolerates book piracy as a dollar-earning industry, has issued an order to confiscate all copies of an unauthorized facsimile edition of Irving Wallace's "Nympho and Other Maniacs."

Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey announced yesterday that the New York Giants had agreed to leave Yankee Stadium and had signed a 30-year lease to play football in a new stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands in 1975.
TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- The Bank of Japan had to buy dollars on the Tokyo exchange today -- a total of $600-million -- after a couple of days in which the flow was reversed.
ATLANTA, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Rico Carty, the Atlanta Braves outfielder, said today he might have suffered permanent eye damage as the result of an altercation with three white Atlanta policemen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 27 -- Six American soldiers were killed in two sharp ground attacks near Danang today and yesterday, and G.I.'s were still under orders to stay off roads and out of civilians areas in case of demanstrations or terrorism aimed at disrupting Sunday's lower house elections.

MANDALAY, Burma, Aug. 12 -- Burma, whose dazzling golden pagodas and wealth of precious gems remain untarnished by nine harsh years of military Socialism, is hawking some of her spare treasure in exchange for toothpaste, brassieres and transistor radios.
A convention that has gained considerable popularity in recent years with experts, especially the younger ones, is the Jacoby transfer bid.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- Premier Eisaku Sato shook hands with a high-ranking Chinese Communist official today for the first time in his life, and said he hoped he would have an opportunity to meet the official again.

The New York Philharmonic plans an unprecedented one-week Orchestra Repertory Institute for black and other minority musicians beginning Sept. 7, under the direction of Richard Lert.
Stock prices showed a mild decline yesterday on a marked contraction in trading volume.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Seven double winners emerged from the second day's racing in Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 39th annual Race Week which drew 220 starters today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Assistant Attorney General Will R. Wilson confirmed reports today that he had purchased stock through his own account for a Federal bank examiner who was checking a bank owned by Frank W. Sharp, a Houston developer and financier.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United States command announced today that 10 Americans had been killed in combat in Indo-china last week, the lowest weekly toll in six years.

The incorporation of Chatham Holdings, Inc., with Andrew Fisher of Chatham, N. Y., and Raymond C. Kennedy of Hudson, N. Y. as shareholders, was announced yesterday. Mr. Fisher, who retired this year as executive vice president of The New York Times Company, is president of the new concern. Mr. Kennedy, publisher of The Hudson Register Star, a daily newspaper, is treasurer.

The Flying Tiger Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the North American Car Corporation, has agreed in principle to acquire National Equipment Rental, Ltd., for $21-million, consisting of $10-million in cash and the balance in notes.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 26 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands arrived in Indonesia today, becoming the first ruling sovereign of the House of Orange to set foot on the archipelago, the crown jewel of the Dutch colonial empire for 343 years.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 26 -After testifying before a Federal grand jury today, Robert W. Hardy tacitly confirmed the widespread suspicion that he was the informer who helped the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrest 20 persons here last weekend for allegedly trying to steal draft records.

The lawyer in charge of investigating State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer for the Court on the Judiciary will ask that court on Monday for permission to have a doctor examine the judge to determine whether he is, as his own lawyer contends, too "depressed" to submit to further questioning.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to suspend trading in three issues of the Federal Pacific Electric Company because an inadequate number of shares were publicly held.
HOLLYWOOD -- For the last two years, huge streamlined buses -- mobile film studios -- have been altering location film production in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Pentagon confirmed today that it had sought and received the resignation of its highest-ranking black official. Officials indicated that the action had been taken because of high-level dissatisfaction with his performance in office.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 26 -- The Nevada Gaming Commission voted today that until Howard Hughes furnished it with a letter bearing his fingerprints and naming the person responsible for his gambling licenses here, it would not approve new applications or shifts in names of persons on his licenses.
A Democratic City Councilman urged Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday to drop his drive against corruption and provide more police protection on the street.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

The Los Angeles Dodgers' desperate drive to overhaul the San Francisco Giants in the National League Western Division has been like shinnying up a greased flag pole. The Dodgers have trailed the Giants by as many as 11 games and as few as 3 1/2.

Tenants who alleged that their East Side "luxury" apartment building was "rife" with vice, lacked proper security and was in poor repair reached agreement in court with the building's management yesterday.
Once more this year the Police Department lowered the flags to half staff at all station houses in the city yesterday and began yet another manhunt for the killer of a policeman.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 26 -- Second-seeded Clark Graebner of New York and the teenage star, Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., survived close calls today in the $25,000 Eastern grass-court tennis championships.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- An American narcotics agent has charged that major heroin traffickers operate in the Marseilles area with a sense of security. The charge has touched off an angry protest by the French police.
Swift Co., yesterday reported sharp gains in earnings for the quarter and nine months ended July 31, in line with results of several other meat packers.
Offtrack betting's schizophrenic computers are "on the threshold of stability," the president of Computer Sciences Corporation insisted yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 26 -- Their spirits lifted by two straight victories over the two best pitchers on the Oakland Athletics, the New York Yankees arrived here today in time to see if the Boston Red Sox could lose to the Kansas City Royals just one more time.

Women's groups around the country yesterday observed the 51st anniversary of their right to vote by warning that they would use it against any "Congress person" who opposed or tried to weaken the proposed equal rights amendment.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The dollar turned in a mixed performance in European trading in foreign exchange today amid the cross-currents of national financial developments.

The market for tax-exempt bonds, which had lagged badly this week, raised yields yesterday to levels that could entice investors. A $100-million Ohio offering proved a quick sell-out.

For manufacturers of consumer goods anxious to know when enough of their products are in the stores to begin a spot-television campaign, Lebhar-Friedman, Inc., has a new service designed to come up with quick answers.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- For the past decade, in between two military coups d'etat, it just so happens that Turkey has had high-ranking generals as Presidents of the republic, first Cemal Gursel and now Cevdet Sunay, senior retired officer and former chief of staff. It is no accident that this has been the case. The Turks are a martial people and the army plays a very special role in their tradition and society.
HOUSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Mark Spitz of Sacramento, Calif., won his second 1971 National Amateur Athletic Union swimming championship tonight in defending his 200-meter free-style title.

Two former pages for the National Broadcasting Company started their own business four years ago to produce and distribute "public service" radio and television spots for companies and trade associations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Government's leading business indicators, which tend to foreshadow future economic movements, showed a solid advance in July, the Commerce Department said today.

Standard Brands, Inc., the food processing and packaging concern, was ordered by the State Supreme Court yesterday to begin construction by tomorrow of a water pollution abatement facility at its Charles Point plant in Peekskill.
Soybean futures declined more than 5 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but more than half the loss was trimmed by late buying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -The chairman of the Presidents' Council of Economic Advisers predicted today that the Administration's new economic program would add a net of $15-billion to the gross national product next year and create about 500,000 new jobs.

The dollar strengthened slightly yesterday in the New York foreign-exchange market, but dealers were reluctant to ascribe any special significance to the movement. Leafy as Police Commissioner last October, he let it be known that a new generation of top commanders would soon be running the city's 32,000-man police force. Anyone familiar with the innovative summer arts program that Trinity Church started in the Wall Street area two years ago would not be surprised that "Ambit," a dance piece commissioned by the church from the young dancer-choreographer Raymond Johnson, was chosen to close this year's festival.

Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, asserted today that he was in total agreement with President Nixon's policy of limited school busing. The distressing news from Northern Ireland necessitates some delicate action in order to prevent this open wound from festering any more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- As the public schools open for the fall term, busing continues to be both a scare word and a straw man for those who are opposed to or dubious about desegregation. Busing also continues to be the only real hope for achieving substantial desegregation in the North and the larger cities of the South; and it is therefore potentially one of the most important instruments for improving American education.

A tentative settlement was reached yesterday in the 92-day strike against Western Union in the metropolitan area by members of the Communications Workers of America. If the agreement is ratified, the 3,100 strikers will return to work Sept. 13.

Delinquency on home mortgage loans increased to the highest level in more than a decade during the second quarter, Mortgage Bankers Association said yesterday. SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Federal officials said today that they had reason to believe Stephen M. Bingham, charged with five counts of murder in the violence at San Quentin Prison Aug. 21, had fled from California -- possibly to Canada or Cuba.

Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says that there is no substantive reason for classifying as top secret his recommendations to a Presidential committee on the underground nuclear test scheduled for early next month on Amchitka Island.

LISBON, Sept. 1 -- A Portuguese prisoners' aid organization reported today that the number of political detainees more than doubled during the first seven months of this year. Israel's devaluation of her currency will offer some assistance to apparel manufacturers exporting to the United States, but fashion and quality considerations will be the prime factors in expanding their market, Robert Keller, president of ATID, a nonprofit organization for promotion of Israeli goods, said here yesterday.

Paul G. Hoffman, an Under Secretary in the United Nations and administrator of the United Nations Development Program, will retire in January, Secretary General Thant has announced. Mr. Hoffman, who turned 80 on April 26, has been at the United Nations 12 years.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange omitted its usual weekly report.

The dollar was a bit stronger in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. In light trading, the Canadian dollar, the German mark and the Swiss franc were all slightly lower in relation to the dollar than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Under Secretary of the Treasury and the president of the National Education Association disagreed today over the status of teacher pay increases during the current wage-price freeze.

TONOPAH, Nev. -- It's been nearly three years now and folks up here in this dusty old mining town are beginning to lose their patience with Howard Hughes, the billionaire. The trans-Atlantic airlines yesterday postponed until Sept. 15 a showdown in their dispute over new fares, ruling out a price war at least temporarily.

NEWARK, Sept. 1 -- The strike of the Newspaper Guild at the The Evening News here will reach its 100th day tomorrow amid indications that pressures are mounting on both sides for a resolution of the dispute.

The likelihood of a third movie's being removed from New York followed Paramount Pictures' decision on Tuesday to shift production of "Last of the Red Hot Lovers" and "Play It Again, Sam" because of a contract dispute with a local union.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The Soviet Union took note of the monetary upheavals in the capitalist world today with a token devaluation of the ruble against the Western currencies that have floated up to higher rates.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1 -- At times, Howard Beissinger, a Hamilton, Ohio, farmer turned harness horseman, found little to like about Speedy Crown. There was the foal's original name, Headin' and Healin'. Then there was a nasty splint that nearly wrecked the yearling's future. And three weeks ago, there was a 1:57 4-5 time trial at Springfield, Ill. Beissinger thought the colt could have moved faster that day.

The New York State Banking Board, in parallel decisions that tightened significantly the guidelines governing bank mergers in the state, denied yesterday three proposed acquisitions of small banks by major bank holding companies.
NEWARK, Sept. 1 -- Newark, which has become a predominantly black city with a still largely white police force, today graduated its first Police Academy class with a majority of black members.

The RCA Corporation announced yesterday the election of Edgar H. Griffiths as executive vice president-services. Prior to this appointment, Mr. Griffiths was president of the RCA Service Company subsidiary. In his new post he will be responsible for the RCA Service Company, the Hertz Corporation and RCA Parts and Accessories. He also was elected chairman of the executive committee, board of directors of the Hertz Corporation.
American Ballet Theater will perform Sept. 11 and 15 at the Opera House of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington during the center's inaugural week.

It isn't the worst novel I've ever read. B. Gilden (the pen-name of Katya and the late Bert Gilden, the husband-and-wife team who wrote the commercially successful "Hurry Sundown").
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept 1 (AP) -- The United States command announced today the start of a troop reduction of 42,000 that will cut American strength in South Vietnam to 177,000 men by Dec. 1.

Three months after the city decided to shelve the Tuesday-night closings of Madison Avenue for a pedestrian mall -- a decision caused by objections from businessmen and residents -- the Economic Development Administration has decided to resume them.

Former Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary was defended yesterday by his successor and attacked by his predecessor on the question of police corruption.

CAIRO, Sept. 1 -- Millions lined up at polling places today to mark a red circle on a ballot to signify their assent to a federation with Syria and Libya, or a black circle if they disapproved of the new venture toward Arab unity.
RICHMOND, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Virginia Supreme Court held today that the United States' involvement in Vietnam did not constitute a war in the legal sense.

DUBLIN, Sept. 1 -- He speaks softly with a gentle Cork lilt. He moves quickly and nervously, gripping a pipe, slightly stooped, eyes darting. He remains trim and physically vigorous -- a carryover to the days when he was one of Ireland's best-known athletes.
An award of $145-million for Trans World Airlines against Howard R. Hughes was affirmed here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

Governor Rockefeller's informal and incomplete list of appointees to the new Adirondack Park Agency offers hope that one of the state's greatest resources will be preserved for the enjoyment of future New Yorkers.

Bobby Fischer's 19-game victory streak, which includes 6-0 triumphs over Grandmaster Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union and Bent Larsen of Denmark in the world chess eliminations, started in a tournament in Palma, Majorca, in Spain.

The eldest son of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. declined to answer 20 questions before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday and eventually was upheld in his refusal to respond to those related to the discovery last July 28 of three loaded guns in his brother's rented car.

Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has proposed new eligibility requirements for acting school supervisors as the result of a Federal judge's ruling earlier this summer that restrained the city school system from holding traditional examinations and issuing new eligibility lists for supervisory posts.

Joseph Rorech, a key prosecution witness in the Alice Crimmins murder case, was taken into custody in Waterbury, Conn., yesterday on a Federal charge of interstate flight to avoid prosecution on New York fraud charges.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Stronger bumpers and minor styling refinements highlighted the 1972 model cars unveiled today by the Cadillac Division of the General Motors Corporation.

Ferguson Jenkins of the Chicago Cubs, a major league pitcher par excellence, walloped a couple of homers yesterday.

The goodwill gesture President Nixon has made toward this country's two largest trading partners by announcing a visit to Canada next spring and a desire to visit Japan should help ease the strained relations brought on by his new economic policy. The Johns-Manville Corporation has brought suit against the New Jersey Township of Bedminster in what is believed to be the first challenge by a national building organization to large-lot residential zoning in the New York suburban area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Treasury, in a move that will relieve major hardship for many importers, ruled today that imports already in shipment to the United States on Aug. 15 will not be subject to the new 10 per cent import surcharge.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 1 -- Today was an English-speaking day at the Venice Festival.

Sales and earnings of the H. J. Heinz Company in the first fiscal quarter, ended July 28, were the highest in its 102-year history "despite continuing inflationary pressures around the world," the company reported yesterday.

Newswriters at the National Broadcasting Company in New York City have voted 51-25 for union representation by the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians in place of the Writers Guild of America East. They have been represented by the guild.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday the retirement of two high police officials and the demotion of two others in his continuing drive to reshape the New York City Police Department.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview of Premier Eisaku Sato by James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times. The interview was held yesterday and the transcript was approved by Mr. Sato today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, named today administrators for regional offices in New York, Denver and Atlanta.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 1 (AP) -- A former aide to the late Illinois Secretary of State Paul Powell surrendered and was booked today on a charge of having tampered with public records.

Puerto Rican and black street gangs, some well organized, others not, have surfaced in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx. WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Mrs. Aristotle Onassis notified trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts today that she would not attend the formal opening next Wednesday of the $46-million memorial to her late husband.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British Government announced today that Prime Minister Heath would meet next week with Prime Minister John Lynch of the Irish Republic to discuss the crisis in Ulster.
The tax-exempt note sector proved a sparkling exception to otherwise luckluster activity in the credit markets yesterday.

Joe Cahill, leader of the militant "provisional" faction of the Irish Republican Army, was denied entrance to the United States by immigration authorities as he stepped off a plane from Ireland at Kennedy Airport last night.

A State Supreme Court justice on Long Island was accused yesterday of having bought his nomination for the post from a former Republican leader in Suffolk County for $50,000 and of having used a coded Swiss bank account to make the transaction.

Petitions for a referendum here in November on the question of statehood for New York City were filed yesterday by Representative Bella S. Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan.

In the economy of 1971, the attainment of an acceptable employment level is impossible without unacceptable inflation. Faced with this dilemma, President Nixon froze all wages and prices for a ninety-day period. This action was designed to channel the increasing aggregate demand insured by the monetary expansion during the first half of 1971 into output and employment increases, not price increases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A United States intelligence report says that South Vietnam's military leaders are "less than unanimous" in supporting President Nguyen Van Thieu in his determination to run in the Oct. 3 elections even though he is unopposed.

The possibility that the soybean harvest will be seriously affected by drought brought about cautious short covering in the trading of soybeans futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

When the people who live on 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue say that it is a "good block," they mean that they feel more or less safe there. The quadrupling of the Federal - City Joint Narcotics Enforcement Task Force to 172 agents -- 108 of them from the New York Police Department -- was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay, who said the plan might "spread elsewhere" as a model for similar Federal-urban operations.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Lee Trevino returned to competitive golf today after an absence of four weeks from the pro circuit, most of which was spent recovering from an appendectomy.

In an "experiment in justice" Abbie Hoffman is being sued before a counter-culture tribunal. WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 2 -- New health code provisions that for the first time make the installation of public sewers a virtual requirement in new residential developments in Westchester County were made public here today.

The American Legion elected a new national commander at its convention in Houston. He is John H. Geiger, an architect and executive of United Air Lines who lives in Des Plaines, Ill. Mr. Geiger succeeds Alfred P. Chamie, a Los Angeles lawyer as commander of the Legion, which claims a membership of 2.7 million.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- The one crisis nobody wants to hear about is Cyprus and yet this familiar little volcano seems to be getting ready to explode again. The world already has its hands full with monetary troubles, Middle East troubles, Sino-Russian troubles, North Irish troubles, winding down the Vietnam war and winding up the economy. It detests the thought of another headache in Cyprus.

Bennett Cerf, the publisher and television personality who died last Friday at the age of 73, left an estate valued at more than $1-million, according to his will, which was offered for probate in Manhattan Surrogate Court yesterday.

Stan Bahnsen of the Yankees had a most pleasing and unusual experience last night at Yankee Stadium. As he walked to the mound to start the third inning against the Washington Senators, he enjoyed an 11-0 lead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Wholesale prices, both food and industrial, rose strongly in August, the Labor Department reported today. The rise confirmed a general worsening of the price picture since the temporary improvement of last fall and winter.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- The Big Four ran afoul today of the complexities of the German language in their attempt to issue a translation of their accord on Berlin. This delayed the signing of the documents for at least 24 hours, and perhaps for several days.

Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday after they allegedly tried to bribe a captain and a sergeant of the Police Department's inspections division to let an illegal gambling ring operate freely in the central part of the Bronx.

Larry Adams received the news on showing up for work at Belmont Park yesterday that he had been fined $100 by the stewards for reporting late to the jockeys' room after repeated warnings. The American Contract Bridge League has announced that it will seek to raise $250,000 next year to support research into the causes and prevention of cerebral palsy.

Although the volume of complaints about violations of the Federal wage-price freeze has mushroomed here in the last few days, the Internal Revenue Service still is relying almost entirely on voluntary compliance to enforce the freeze.

OXFORD, Md., Sept. 2 -- Charlie Scott became the first Chesapeake Bay sailor to win a North American Yacht Racing Union championship as he carried the Annapolis Yacht Club colors to first place today in the Sears Cup regatta for juniors.
The Knickerbocker Championships, one of the world's oldest established tournaments, begins at the New York Hilton Hotel today under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 2 -- A 23-year-old Dutch tourist, arrested last February for taking photographs outside a Pakistani air base, has been convicted of spying after a secret trial and sentenced to two years' imprisonment, newspapers reported yesterday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 2 (UPI) -The Alabama House officially endorsed Gov. George C. Wallace's fight against busing today by passing a bill to allow a child to attend any school regardless of Federal court orders.
The North American Rockwell Corporation announced yesterday it has consummated its stock purchase agreement under which it will make a $35-million cash investment in Collins Radio Company.

Cesar Cedeno, who hit only seven home runs in his rookie season at Houston last year, smacked a 200- foot, grand-slam homer last night in the Astrodome in rallying the Astros to a 9-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

President Nixon can make a major contribution in his television speech on Labor Day to rebuilding unified national support for his ninety-day wage-price freeze, now the target of widespread and often ill-reasoned union attack.

The help-wanted advertising index rose two points in July to stand at 85 per cent of the 1967 average, the Conference Board reported yesterday. It was the third consecutive month in which the index has risen but the July figure was still six points under the 91 average in July of 1970.

A major part of the South Bronx, including some of the most deprived areas of the borough, has been designated a special redevelopment area by the Federal Government's Department of Commerce, it was disclosed here yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Sept. 2 (AP) -- The United States command announced today that 19 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week. It was the highest weekly toll in seven weeks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- B. F. Skinner, who is widely viewed among his peers as the most influential psychologist in the country, paused between bites of a ham and cheese sandwich the other day to talk about his latest book, an uninhibited assault on some of the Western world's most prized ideals.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 2 -- Bill Widnall of this port finished fourth in the sixth race of the International One-Design Class world championship today. With one race remaining, only members of the Marblehead fleet have a chance to overtake him for the lead.

The New York Telephone Company broke off contract negotiations yesterday with its striking workers, charging that its equipment was being sabotagd -- that cables had been cut in Queens and Suffolk County.

T. I. M. E.-DC, Inc., transcontinental motor carrier serving market areas in the United States and Canada, announced yesterday the appointment of Roy M. Wilkins as its new president. Davis to the newly created position of executive vice president. He had been vice president, Eastern Division.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- An American in Israel has been in a coma since Friday after consuming contaminated vichyssoise prepared by Bon Vivant, the Food and Drug Administration said today.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 7 -- The Brookhaven Town Board cleared the way today for the first federally subsidized low-income housing to be built in Suffolk County under the Federal Housing Act of 1968.
MIAMI, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Two tropical storms -- Fern and Edith -- developed today, Fern in the Gulf of Mexico and Edith in the Central Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Senator George McGovern, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs, accused the Department of Agriculture today of bowing to pressure from the Office of Management and Budget to cut over-all costs of the school lunch program.
Newly franchised 18-to-20-year-old voters have not flocked to register for voting in the state Presidential primary next June, a spot check of Election Boards around the state showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously in early June to conduct monetary policy with the aim of slowing the rapid growth of the monetary "aggregates" such as the money supply, it was disclosed today.

The Yankees' brief hopes of taking over third place in the American League Eastern Division almost completely disappeared last night in the midst of a madcap six-run rally by the Red Sox that led them to a 9-3 triumph at Yankee Stadium.
TOKYO, Sept. 7 -- Kameichiro Hanashima's lovebird was drowned Sunday because it would not leave its eggs when the sea began to flow over the wall of the spillway in front of the house.

The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized American Airlines and Trans World Airlines yesterday to fly the wives and children of businessmen coast-to-coast for $99 round trip, plus $7.92 tax. The new rate, which goes into effect Oct. 1, will be the lowest in history for a transcontinental jet round trip.

MIAMI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- L. B. Maytag Jr., president of National Airlines, Inc., said today that his airline faced a threat to its existence if the proposed merger of Northeast Airlines and Delta Air Lines was approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
A 13-year-old boy is bound to remember this sort of day.
MONTREAL, Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Joan Payson flew over from Maine tonight to watch her New York Mets in Canada and had a sensationally unrewarding trip as the Montreal Expos shellacked her boys, 9-3.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7 -- The Canadian Government outlined today a plan to help exporters who are forced to lay off significant numbers of workers because of the United States's 10 per cent surcharge on imports imposed by President Nixon, as part of his New Economic Policy.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- One of the most fortunate men in the United States business world this year must surely be William H. Sandy, 42 years old. About 10 weeks ago his boss handed him some $5-million worth of business, gave him the pick of the company's 70 best employes, advanced him a loan on ridiculously low terms and told him to start his own concern, the Bill Sandy Company, Inc.

For the second day in a row, a women's match produced the only startling reversal of form at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens. Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter, the seventh-seeded player, fell victim to unheralded Laura DuPont of Charlotte, N. C., 0-6, 6-2, 6-4.

The first note of Leonard Bernstein's Mass ended, in effect, the long preliminary controversy over the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. In that debate some of the country's foremost architectural critics compared the style of the project with everything from the Moscow subway to a "concrete candy box." But now that the $70-million Center is officially open, it is too late to cry over spilt concrete.

More and more, the autoracing season grows longer. In Florida and Southern California races are feasible in December and January. But what about the North? Well, there's a movement afoot to organize a schedule of indoor races for three-quarter (TQ) midget cars -- or, more precisely, to expand the TQ races that have hither-to been limited to three dates in Atlantic City's Covention Hall.

BONN, Sept. 7 -- West Germany's Minister of Transportation, Georg Leber, announced today that he would ask Parliament to approve West Germany's first general speed limit, 100 kilometers (about 62 miles) an hour on all two-lane highways and country roads.

The feud between the United States Lawn Tennis Association and the contract professionals took another turn for the worse yesterday when a major sponsor threatened to terminate its television contract for the United States Open championships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Administration sought today to bring pressure to bear on six corporations that reportedly raised dividends in defiance of a Presidential request. The effort produced no immediate results.
Philip H. Iselin, president of the New York Jets, received a cold turkey lunch from Mayor Lindsay yesterday and little encouragement for his proposal to expand Shea Stadium.
"Every building should have someone like Bob," said a tenant at 333 West 57th Street.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 7 -- The Westchester County Administration proposed today that the county contract with the State Environmental Facilities Corporation for management and disposal of its solid waste for the next 20 years.
This is in response to the travesty that happened on the beaches of Old Lyme as reported in The Times Aug. 31.

More than one-quarter of the original purchasers of apartments in a city-aided Mitchell-Lama apartment development in east midtown Manhattan have canceled their contracts to buy as monthly maintenance charges have soared above original estimates.
Two former Marine officers said yesterday that revulsion against killing and the inhumanity of war had led them to seek discharge as conscientious objectors.

MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- The Soviet Union announced today that its unmanned Luna 18 craft had gone into lunar orbit, increasing the expectation among Western specialists that the Russians were about to attempt another moon landing, possibly to retrieve more geological samples.

LONDON -- This is my final report this year of the London theatrical scene, and it might be as well to stress what a very good season London has had. There is almost a superfluity of fantastic acting -- after a time it becomes so good that you almost take it for granted, and this is a pity.

Anthony Powell may be the last great novelist to deal at first-hand with the English aristocracy, which is disappearing much as the lions, elephants and rhinos are disappearing from Africa, leaving each country the poorer for it. The manners of the English upper classes were a cornucopia of incongruities that furnished at least two centuries of novelists with material even the best of them could not have invented.
PAHQUARRY TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 7 -- "Beautiful, lonely country," said Eric Noel, indicating with the wave of his hand a narrow roadway flanked by trees.
BOSTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- A gunman tied up two men early today, doused them with gasoline and set them afire, killing one and seriously injuring the second.

It was "educational enforcement" day in scattered areas of the Bronx yesterday as a task force of four city departments began a campaign against illegal parking, but there was some doubt as to who was being educated.

As Congress begins its examination of President Nixon's program for economic recovery, the law passed earlier this year to establish public service jobs for the unemployed deserves reappraisal. In the light of the high priority Mr. Nixon wants assigned to restoring full employment, it is plain that the new program is much too small to make much impact in reducing the army of jobless.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- For a man who has always had supreme confidence in himself, it was galling for Roger L. Stevens to confess to President Kennedy that he was failing in his attempt to build a national center for the performing arts.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- The dollar moved up in value against several European currencies today, going in the opposite direction to that intended by President Nixon in his efforts to improve the American competitive situation abroad.

The chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that the commission had no jurisdiction in a dispute involving community groups in Harlem and a white physician at Harlem Hospital who was accused -- and officially cleared -- of spitting at a black dietary aide.

A summit meeting to fashion a united New York City political front against an increase in the 30-cent transit fare failed yesterday to budge the positions of any of the participants on revenue measures to offset transit deficits.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- John Brown Engineering, a big British engineering company, has won an order for a power station in Burma to be built at a cost of $7.7-million. The contract said that Burma would make part payment in rice -$2.4-million worth.
A former convict was arrested at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street yesterday by Federal agents who seized five stolen paintings, including a two-sided work by Picasso.

A study commissioned by Action for Children's Television has found that 23 per cent of the viewing time on commercial television programs for children is taken up by commercials, that the presentation of commercials averages out to one every three minutes and that 71 per cent of the creative fare contains at least one instance of human violence frequently accompanied by "laugh tracks").

GORHAM, N. H., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, said today that he could beat President Nixon in the New Hampshire Presidential primary in 1972 if the voters "are given a fair shot at understanding the issues."
The short, happy Jet career of Mike Battle ended yesterday when he was placed on waivers and nobody in the National Football League picked him up.
Richard Kluger, editor in chief of Atheneum Publishers, resigned yesterday because of what he called "a basic disagreement over what constitutes effective book publishing."

The versatile Wustenchef of the Augustin Stable added the $34,550 Brighton Beach Handicap to his list of victories yesterday, taking the Belmont Park feature by two lengths over Sigmund Sommer's Big Shot II. Third was June McKnight's formidable 5-year-old mare, Princess Pout.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The defense for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg has filed a motion to block a Federal grand jury subpoena for records stored under Dr. Ellsberg's name.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 8 -- In one of those frequent pro football trades that involve more than meets the eye, Randy Johnson, a quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons, was dealt today to the Giants.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, running on a "truth in government" campaign to oust President Nixon in 1972, charged the Administration today with "concealment of the facts" and "deliberate deceit" in its economic policies.

Northwest Industries, Inc., which had been thinking of paying the first cash dividend on its common stock in almost two years, said yesterday it had decided not to do so, because of President Nixon's request that corporations avoid dividend increases.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The clearest trend among the nations today is toward some kind of new world order none of them can define. In the words of the old song, they don't know where they're going but they're on their way.

ALBANY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The State Education Department said today that an estimated total of 4,274,800 youngsters would be attending public and nonpublic elementary and secondary schools in the state this year, an increase of only 1,500.

Although most voters in New York City can be forgiven for not being aware of it, both the Republican and Democratic parties are holding primary elections next Tuesday. There has been little hoopla because the races are few compared with other recent primaries and the offices to be filled are hardly at the top of the American political order. Nonetheless, some have a significance that merits voter attention.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 8 -- First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. has been called as a defense witness in the court-martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina. He will be brought here Friday or next week from Fort Benning, Ga., where he has been confined to his bachelor apartment pending final appeal of his conviction for murdering civilians at Mylai.

UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Relative quiet reigned throughout the city tonight after two days of racial disorders that culminated last night in a wave of fire bombings and vandalism to business property.
Ralph Nader attacked President Nixon s economic plan yesterday as "a bonanza to industry" and "the biggest tax cut in history for corporations."

Bess Myerson, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, came out strongly yesterday for no-fault auto insurance and immediately found herself under repeated attack from members of a legislative committee who considered her ill-prepared to answer questions on the subject.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- The official Soviet press agency tonight attacked allegations that Martin Bormann, Hitler's top lieutenant, was a Soviet spy during World War II as a "fabrication."

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, apparently striving to thwart any decline in police morale stemming from his campaign to root out police corruption, commended the city's policemen yesterday for their "loyalty to the best interests of the department" and "dedication to the welfare of the people of this city."

Seven members of the Jewish Defense League were accused yesterday of conspiring to bomb the Soviet Union's trade agency here last April 2 and to plant a bomb on June 12 at the Soviet Mission's estate at Glen Cove, L. I.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 8 -William Maley of the Battery Park City Authority in New York stood like Gulliver today with one foot in the Bronx and one in Queens.

The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company was indicted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of dumping industrial waste into the Hudson River from the company's mill at Hastings -on - Hudson, in Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States and the Soviet Union will open high-level discussions in Moscow next month on how to avoid incidents involving their warships and aircraft.
Doris Caesar, a sculptor, died yesterday at her home on North Street, Litchfield, Conn. She was 78 years old.
The First National City Bank has curtailed sharply the service that it is willing to perform for its correspondent banks that offer its Master Charge credit card to their customers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Nixon, according to officials in the White House and the State Department, is giving serious consideration to canceling or postponing the underground test of a five-megaton antimissile warhead scheduled for next month on Amchitka in the Aleutians.

The Xerox Corporation yesterday announced a $500,000a-year social service leave program. The photocopiermanufacturing company said 20 or more employes would be granted up to 12 months leave of absence at full salary to participate in a social program of their own choosing.
Leonard Ginsberg, a former president of Hearn Department Stores and a leader in charitable causes, died Tuesday night in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

PRASAUT, Cambodia, Sept. 8 -- Scores of Cambodian peasants have gathered in this bombed-out village on Route 1 seeking protection from what they describe as pillaging and wanton attacks by South Vietnamese soldiers operating in Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Knowledgeable Government officials said today that men with draft lottery numbers above 140 were almost certainly safe from the possibility of induction this year, even if Congress passes a new draft law this month.
Three men were arrested yesterday and accused of killing a Brooklyn supermarket manager two weeks ago because he was too slow in opening a safe.

About 40 Tactical Patrol Force policemen helped men from the local precinct to patrol Washington Heights last night to forestall a repetition of the violence between Dominican and Negro youths that flared there the previous two days.

A $314-million merger was proposed yesterday as Textron, Inc., one of the nation's first conglomerates, agreed with a group of large stockholders of the Kendall Company on a plan to acquire that corporation.
Arthur Miller has written a new play, "The Creation of the World and Other Business," which Robert Whitehead will produce on Broadway in January or February.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Crowned Prince, the world's most expensive race horse as a yearling, redeemed his reputation today by winning the seven-furlong Champagne Stakes.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 -The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the Marxist guerrilla organization, said today it would not be bound by any decision, adopted at the projected conference between commando and Jordania Government representatives.

Joe Cahill, leader of a militant faction of the Irish Republican Army, was deported by United States immigration officials yesterday, a week after he was detained at the direction of the State Department.
A growing number of women and girls coming to New York for abortions are being victimized by cab drivers who charge exorbitant fees for rides from the airports to hospitals in and around the city.
One of the newest Japanese imports to Manhattan -- architecture -- was previewed yesterday as the new headquarters of the Japan Society were unveiled at 333 East 47th Street.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 8 -- Contending that the people are "fed up with the rotten image that has made Jersey City a national joke," Dr. Paul Jordan, a New Jersey drug abuse expert, today became the 44th person to announce his candidacy for mayor.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 8 -Ignoring Gov. George C. Wallace's suggestion to oppose busing orders from a Federal court, Mobile today quietly put into effect a massive busing plan for its schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee warned today that the Pentagon's reliance upon ever more costly weapons could imperil the national security by forcing dangerous reductions in the size of the military forces.

Peter Lawford, taping a television interview in Los Angeles, casually mentioned that he planned to marry Mary Rowan, the 21-year- old daughter of Dan Rowan, star of the Rowan and Martin "Laugh-In" show on TV.

Nolan Ryan will be pitching for the home team against Stan Bahnsen and Steve Kline when the New York Yankees invade Shea Stadium to play the Mets tonight in the ninth annual Mayor's Trophy game beginning at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- In a long-delayed statement of overall policy, the Department of Transportation endorsed today a substantial relaxation of the regulatory rules that had told truckers, airlines and railroads whether they could operate, where they could travel and how much they could charge.

Political and community leaders in the Yorkville section denounced the city's plan to build housing on the site of the former Ruppert brewery, at a public hearing of the City Planning Commission yesterday.

Belatedly, the Detroit Tigers are making a run at Baltimore's Eastern Division leaders. Is it a salary drive for 1972 contracts? Or is it a realization that, as a team, the Tigers might have done better throughout the season?

On the face of it, only one conclusion is possible from the futile London conference of British and Irish Prime Ministers on the crisis in Northern Ireland: Neither Edward Heath nor John Lynch has yet realized how rapidly Ulster is drifting toward civil war, with all the terrible consequences that could bring for everyone.

MANHASSET, L. I., Sept. 8 -- In a contemporary structure with arched, exterior niches on the main thorough-fare in this affluent Long Island community, Bloomingdale's opened today the first store in a new venture -- a chain of home-furnishings specialty stores. For decades the New York-based company has concentrated on operating full-scale department stores.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 -- Israel will try to reassure Egypt in the coming weeks that an interim settlement to reopen the Suez Canal would not be allowed to become permanent but would instead pave the way for broader accords.
MONTREAL, Sept. 8 -- Tug McGraw hit his first big league home run tonight, but otherwise the New York Mets were no match for the Montreal Expos, Rusty Staub and Carl Morton's ripped pants.

PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Protesters carrying American flags and daring buses to run over them demonstrated today against a court-ordered school busing plan. A leader of the opposition demaned, unsuccessfully that all schools be closed "until they can be made safe for our children."

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- Moscow stepped up its campaign today to discredit China's policies by reviving the assertion that Peking was seeking to emerge as the world's leading power by pushing the United States and the Soviet Union into a nuclear war.

Perhaps the brightest new star in the feminine firmament in the last two years has been Mrs. Judi Solodar of New York. As Judi Friedenberg, she won a series of championships in the Midwest before moving to New York early this year to marry John Solodar, an established expert.
A deputy police inspector, a sergeant and a patrolman teamed up yesterday in the Bronx to arrest two men who, minutes earlier, allegedly robbed a Brooklyn man of $140 while posing as policemen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -The Agriculture Department said today that it planned to cancel a policy whereby needy persons can now get up to 49 cents in change when they use food stamps at stores.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A grand jury investigation of the March 1 Capitol bombing and May Day demonstrations suffered a setback today when a Federal judge refused a Justice Department request that two reluctant witnesses be granted prosecution immunity.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 8 -- Bowing to the inevitable, the six Common Market countries have decided to abandon for the moment their laborious search for a common position on the immediate problems posed by the American decision to float the dollar. They will concentrate instead on seeking to establish a joint position on the reform of the international monetary system.

A gunman raped a teen-aged girl in Central Park early yesterday and killed her boy friend when he tried to defend her, the police reported. He also wounded the man who had been with him when he accosted the young couple.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Lee White, the running back who will be remembered as the man whose fumble last month put Joe Namath in the operating room again, was placed on waivers by the Jets and claimed for $100 by the Los Angeles Rams today.
YONKERS, Sept, 8 -- The City Council here is scheduled to vote next Wednesday on a bill that would effectively ban the sale of soft drinks and beer in nonreturnable cans or bottles.

A Brooklyn police lieutenant with 12 years' service was suspended yesterday following his arrest on charges of soliciting a criminal to rob a Queens amusement center.
TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- Telephone service between the United States and China via Tokyo has gone into effect.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally asked Congress today for fast action on President Nixon's new tax program and indicated a willingness to see Congress make at least some limited changes in the plan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- An aluminum dome, 52 feet high and 164 feet in diameter, will be built at the South Pole by the Navy between Nov. 1 and Feb. 15 next year, Rear Adm. Leo B. McCuddin, commander of the naval support force in Antarctica, announced today.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Dean Meminger changed jerseys today at Monmouth College. Off came a powder blue shirt with the lettering "Sports Foundation, Inc. College Interns" and in its place he put on the white uniform of the New York Knicks with No. 7 and Meminger lettered on the back.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1971 cotton crop at 10,952,400 bales, up only slightly from August indications but 8 per cent more than last year's output of 10.1 million.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- The top political and business characters in Tokyo are playing down the American-Japanese financial crisis. WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Manufacturers' inventories declined slightly in July but shipments dropped even more, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin is preparing to join the large field of Democrats seeking the party's 1972 Presidential nomination.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- The old Sun Sing Theater on Grant Avenue, the gaily lighted, tourist-choked heart of Chinatown, was jammed. Its 800 seats had filled up early, mostly with serious-faced Chinese women and squirming youngsters.

CAVITE, the Philippines, Aug. 31 -- The United States flag was lowered for the last time today at Sangley Point Naval Station, ending a 73-year chapter of American naval history and opening a time of trouble for this city of 76,000 down the bay from Manila.

With a $7-million grant from the Ford Foundation as the initial gift, the Juilliard School today opens the first capital fund campaign in its history. The goal is $36-million.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, said today that President Nixon's economic strategy might lead to unemployment of 6.5 per cent through next year.

The city has begun moving to renovate highways and streets and to create new parking space for thousands of autos in the area around Yankee Stadium, meeting some of the conditions set by the Yankees' owners before they agree to remain in the Bronx.

WOODSTOWN. N. J., Sept. 12 -- A special legislative investigating committee from Puerto Rico this weekend saw several squalid migrant farm-worker camps in which laborers complained bitterly of working and living conditions and a lack of adequate medical care.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Fewer than a dozen motorcycle-riding South Vietnamese students staged a brief demonstration in front of the American Embassy today, demanding that the United States and its allies withdraw their troops from Vietnam before Christmas.
Wilbur Wood, a relief pitcher turned starter, became the first Chicago White Sox pitcher in seven years to win 20 games yesterday as he defeated the Royals, 3-0, at Kansas City on a fivehitter.

A son followed his father in Puerto Rican self-help leadership here yesterday, with announcement of the election of Jose A. Cabranes, 30-year-old international lawyer, as board chairman of Aspira of New York.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Bourbon, a colt who was a disappointment in the Epsom Derby, won the $155,240 Prix Royal Oak, a race often used as a prep for the Arc de Triomphe, at Longchamp today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 -An Egyptian editor, now serving life imprisonment for spying for the United States, has stated that he was falsely accused by a former Egyptian intelligence chief and that he had kept in touch with the Americans because the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser, asked him for information about activities of the United States Embassy in Cairo.

BRAINERD, Minn., Sept. 12 -- The McLaren team of Peter Revson and Denis Hulme turned in their familiar one-two finish today in the Minneapolis Tribune-Can-Am of 210 miles over Donnybrooke Speedway. With the field's only two competitive cars knocked out of contention early in the day, it was one of the team's easiest victory's of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -The United States and the Soviet Union were understood today to have agreed on a system to handle nuclear accidents together, supported by a new communications satellite hot line to insure instantaneous consultations.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 -- Fritz Peterson and three other Yankee pitchers feasted on Polynesian food last night, but Roy Foster and Graig Nettles feasted on Peterson today and powered Cleveland to a 5-2 victory.

TAKASAKI, Japan, Sept. 12 -- Yasuhiro Nakasone, the former Defense Minister, put forward today three requirements for normalization of relations between Tokyo and Peking; Recognition of the People's Republic as the legitimate representative of China, giving substance to this recognition by allocating China's seat in the United Nations Security Council to Peking, and acknowledgment hat Taiwan is part of China.

Walt Whitman heard America singing, and it is still singing in "Leaves of Grass," which is described as a musical celebration of Whitman and which opened last night at the Theater Four. This has music by Stan Harte Jr., who has himself adapted Whitman's poetry.

After almost two months of activity that the losers insist isn't really revealing, the National Football League's preseason schedule finally ended last night. Life magazine reported yesterday that an engineer for the space agency, John Dietz, warned repeatedly of the danger from inflammable material in the Apollo 1 space capsule for eight months before the fire that killed three astronauts in a 1967 ground test.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A decade ago, one medical group in Manhattan charged $35 for a basic physical checkup; today it charges $65. CARMEL, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Bruno and Emilio Odello are farmers, as was their father, Battista, before them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- A transcript of secret Senate testimony described today the Central Intelligence Agency's role in secretly training and supporting 30,000 guerrilla troops in Laos since 1962.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Spokesmen from the business community told President Nixon today that the next phase of the new economic strategy should be managed by the Federal Government, with the private sector playing essentially an advisory role.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev was buried today in a simple ceremony from which the Soviet leaders were absent but which was marked by a statement of homage from his son.

MADRID, Sept. 13 -- Sit-ins by doctors throughout Spain in support of psychiatrists at a Madrid hospital have ended after the Madrid provincial authorities agreed to most of the psychiatrists' demands.

TORONTO, Sept. 13 -- The possibility of trade warfare with the United States was raised in Parliament during a question period today, another sign of the anxiety, dismay and frustration produced in Canada by Washington's new program to curb imports and bolster exports.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Frank Robinson of the Orioles, became the 11th man in baseball history to hit 500 career homers tonight when he hit nos. 499 and 500. The feat came as Baltimore beat Detroit 9-1, and then lost 10-5.

BOHIER LAKE, Quebec -Rain rattled against the windows of our Norsman float plane as we came in for a landing on a small, unnamed body of water that lies a quarter of a mile south of Bohier Lake. As we were taxiing toward shore, where the plane was tethered to two spruce trees, the squall passed overhead, however, and sunlight streamed down between the steep, green hills.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- New car sales soared far above the year-ago level in the first third of September with at least some of the gains credited to growing consumer confi dence resulting from President Nixon's New Economic Policy.
