Cable television represents "the last opportunity for black people to establish a firm place in mass communications and the ecOnomic mainstream," Theodore S. Ledbetter Jr., president of the Urban Communications Group, Inc., of Washington, told a religious seminar yesterday.

Husky Oil, Ltd., announced yesterday that its directors had approved in principle a plan to acquire through a share-exchange tender offer the remaining 45 per cent of the Empire State Oil Company that it did not already own.
CAIRO, Sept. 14 -- President Anwar el-Sadat said today that he still favored a peaceful settlement of the conflict with Israel but indicated that he was discouraged about the chances for one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Supreme Court officials confirmed today that copies of an opinion by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger on the thrust of school desegregation rulings by the full Court had been mailed to all Federal circuit and district court judges.

Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that the union had abandoned -- at least for the period of the Presidential wage-freeze -- its traditional stance of "no contract, no work."
A Manhattan lawyer who is a consultant to the city's New Taxi Commission said yesterday that his life had been threatened because of his activities in the so-called gypsy taxicab industry.

MONTREAL -- The confident assertion that "the death penalty serves no useful purpose" and that imprisonment offers a more satisfactory method of dealing with the problem of murder is contradicted by a number of self-evident facts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson warned today that collective bargaining agreements scheduled to take effect after the 90-day wage and price freeze might have to be changed because of the administration's post-freeze policies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The two most influential members of the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today that Congress should repeal part of a recently granted tax break for business. They would do this to provide new tax relief to poor persons without voting more over-all tax reductions than President Nixon has asked.
TORONTO, Sept. 14 -- Mitchell W. Sharp, Minister of External Affairs, said today that Canada, unlike the European Common Market, did not advocate formal devaluation of the United States dollar.

The smallest crowd of the year in Shea Stadium saw the New York Mets divide a double-header with the Montreal Expos yesterday, and the chief gain for the Mets was that they finally saw the last of Rusty Staub until 1972.

Eugene L. Sugarman, a former deputy city controller convicted of 11 counts of receiving bribes and taking unlawful fees totaling $88,000, was sentenced yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court to one to four years in prison.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 -- The United States commander in South Vietnam, Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, reportedly assured Senator McGovern today that under the Vietnamization plan no United States ground forces or air power would be left in Vietnam to support Saigon's army.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 -- The Yankees, who earned an extra $1,179.11 per man for finishing second last year, executed another big move tonight toward receiving additional income this season.

Alex Karras, who could crush a quarterback or create a quip with consummate skill, was dropped yesterday by the Detroit Lions in their final roster cut of the season. The move was a surprise because Karras, a 36-year-old defensive tackle, had been outstanding in pre-session games.

You can't help but like the Bee Gees. Like them -- not love them, that is. They look so haberdashery-neat and straight-arrow, so intensely eager to please, that you accept them on that basis, despite the limits of their musical gifts.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 14 -- A witness testified today that four months after the killings at Mylai First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., told a fellow officer that the slaying of civilians during an assault on the hamlet of Mylai 4, Match 16, 1968, was committed without the knowledge of Capt. Ernest L. Medina. Captain Medina was "certainly surprised" when he learned of it, the witness quoted Lieutenat Calley as saying.

The American Stock Exchange posted its fourth consecutive loss yesterday as the list declined in stepped-up trading.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 -- The Argentine Government has banned all imports in a move to halt an outflow of hard currency and avert a balance-of-payments crisis.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Not performed in London for more than 200 years, Etherege's "The Man of Mood" is the latest Restoration comedy to benefit from the abolition of that cordon sanitaire formerly known as "Restoration style."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The House voted today to repeal a never-used law that gives the Federal Government authority to put suspected spies or saboteurs into detention camps during time of war or insurrection.

Richard Benjamin is making like Walter Mitty in an uneven, middling-good comedy-drama titled "The Steagle." That title, if it matters, refers to a football team merger back in the good old days.

Leonard Gershe's comedy 'Butterflies Are Free" has been at the Booth Theater for nearly two years now and it still has a settled air to it. It is a warm and funny play, and it has a quality of heart to it that never degenerates into mush and sentimentality.

FORT MEPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 15 -- The impeachment of a key Government witness and the admission as evidence of a reported statement by First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that tended to exonerate Capt. Ernest L. Medina of responsibility for the killings at the Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai were achieved by the defense today at the Medina courtmartial.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -In a major reversal of environmental policy, Federal officials told American housewives today to return to the use of phosphate detergents.

The bond market yesterday seemed to be trying to snap out of its recent sinking spell. Some sectors succeeded and others didn't. Treasury securities rose in price, some for the second day in a row, and tax-exempt bond dealers talked about a better atmosphere in their market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Walter J. Hickel, former Secretary of the Interior, says that the antiwar march on Washington, the military incursion into Cambodia, Vice President Agnew's criticism of the nation's news media and the fatal shooting of four students on the Kent State University campus led to his break with the Nixon Administration.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 -Bobby Murcer was getting ready to take practice before tonight's game when Mike Cuellar walked by.
American Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a net income for August of $14,933,000, or 61 cents a share, compared with $6,984,000, or 34 cents, in August of last year.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Prerace drug testing made its New York debut tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, giving bettors a virtual guarantee that no horse was being helped or hindered by an illegal medication.

A scientist whose awesome range of mind entitled him to be called a natural philosopher. John Desmond Bernal also ful. filled Karl Marx's prescription for intellectuals to change the world as well as to understand it.

The inability even to agree on an agenda symbolizes the difficulties that confront the ten leading industrial nations as their finance ministers and central bankers meet in London to seek answers to the world monetary and trade crisis. There is no agreed agenda because the United States and its nine major trading partners want to start negotiating on different issues.

Braniff Airways, Inc., announced in Dallas the election of Mrs. Albert Lasker of New York, noted philanthropist, as a director of the company. Harding L. Lawrence, chairman of Braniff, pointed out that Mrs. Lasker was the first woman to serve on the board as well as one of the few to serve as director of any major corporation.
Consumer buying plans showed no appreciable increase in the weeks immediately following President Nixon's announcement of a wage-price freeze, the Conference Board said yesterday.

FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 15 -- The commander of a helicopter unit during the assault on Mylai 4 testified today that he had told Col. Oran K. Henderson of reports by his pilots that some 125 noncombatants had been killed by American soldiers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 -- Four Roman Catholic priests were convicted of subversion last night by a Brazilian military court and sentenced to prison terms ranging from six months to four years.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday overcame early weakness and finished mixed on moderate trading.
A "particularly gracious neighborhood" in the heart of the Bedford-Stuyvesant slum area in Brooklyn was established yesterday as the city's 17th historic district.

Zhores A. Medvedev, a Soviet biologist and author, has defied official warnings and written a detailed journal of his arrest and detention in a mental hospital last year. He was confined for 19 days and released after protests from top Soviet scientists and writers.

A commission on the future of the City University headed by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has recommended preservation of the university's free-tuition policy and an increase in state support to 75 per cent of the university's operating costs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The spokesmen for poverty-stricken seasonal farm workers told a Senate hearing today that they would like coverage under minimum wage legislation equal to that in other industries.

AREA A -- The pickings for bluefish on the Klondike slimmed out yesterday after expeditions there had paid big dividends early in the week. Capt. Dave Bogan said the Bogan's Basin's fleet's sights were being set for Barnegat Ridge for this morning, where blues ill the 6-to-8-pound range were being taken in number.

FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 16 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina testified at his murder trial today that he never saw the ditch at Mylai where group after group of South Vietnamese civilians were herded and slain by his troops.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16 -- For the seventh consecutive month, the Texas Railroad Commission has cut oil production, as slackening demand has been reported to it by companies that buy the oil from Texas wells.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 16 -- The fading San Francisco Giants lost again today, this time dropping an 8-1 decision to the Cincinnati Reds.
Three 32-story luxury apartment houses can be built on the Glen Oaks Golf Course at the eastern edge of Queens, the Board of Estimate decided yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The deadlocked London monetary conference has aroused fears among European officials that a new recession may engulf the world.
NEENAH, Wis., Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said today it will dispose of its Moraine Sulphite Business Papers Mill in West Carrollton, Ohio.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Warren H. Lieb of Columbia Yacht Club, Chicago, sailed into a 3-point lead in the seventh annual Shields Class national championship today by placing fifth and second for 7 points in the first two races of the five-race regatta on Long Island Sound off the Indian Harbor Y.C.

W.K. Hicks of the New York Jets and Bennie McRae of the New York Giants were separated by about 25 miles yesterday, but both defensive backs were feeling the special pangs and pains known to the brotherhood of football players and both were worrying about their opening-day games.

A panel of industry executives yesterday indicated that the road to adequate energy supplies for the United States in the coming years would certainly be complicated, possibly difficult and probably expensive.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he had warned 134 political candidates from 1970 either to file statements of campaign contributions from the primary and general elections or to face prosecution.

Japan's Ambassador to the United States, Nobuhiko Ushiba, said last night that there was a serious "communications gap" between Japan and the United States, going far beyond current uneasiness over money exchange rates.

BUFFALO, Sept. 16 -- State Correction Department officials gave permission today for lawyers to interview prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility. They acted after a National Guard member testified in Federal Court here that he had seen prisoners being beaten and abused by prison guards and state troopers after the Attica rebellion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that there was no longer a "significant health hazard" through radiation emissions from new television sets.

Paraje, an Argentine-bred 5-year-old running in the silks of Sigmund Sommer, ended a string of 11 races without success yesterday by winning the 1 1/8-mile feature at Belmont Park by a neck over Meadowhill's Naskra, with the Hobeau Farm's Beaukins next in the field of eight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The House Post Office and Civil Service Committee rejected today in a close, party-line vote President Nixon's proposal for a six-month delay on pay increases for Federal white-collar employes.

WASHINGTON -- When even a liberal with the doughty credentials of David Susskind is impelled to react against what he called "rancid liberal rhetoric," it is obvious that the polemics of the doctrine of societal guilt have gone too far. Yet, that is exactly what has occurred in the aftermath of the riot and ensuing bloodshed at Attica state prison.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Nixon today accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie of a "libel on the American people" for having stated that they would not approve a Negro nominee for Vice President in the 1972 election.

EDISON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- An attempted bank holdup here today resulted in the fatal shooting of one patrolman and the serious wounding of another. The lone armed robber was shot to death by a third policeman, who happened to be passing by.

The Administration is pressing the Senate for quick passage of a modified -- and weakened -- Selective Service Act, arguing that the military services face a "manpower crisis" unless conscription is speedily resumed. The fact is that a crisis already does exist within the armed services, but it is more qualitative than quantitative. The problem cannot be resolved merely by restoring the Administration's authority to draft men.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he believed the nine hostages slain in the Attica prison uprising had been killed in a cross fire of troopers' bullets after the decision on Monday to wrench the facility from the control of prisoners.
The Federal Reserve, in a significant change of policy, announced yesterday it would begin shortly to make outright open market purchases and sales in the securities of Federal agencies.

A sharply improved economy. Lower unemployment. Less inflation. The likelihood that any upturn in interest rates will be checked by Government controls. The prospect that continued turmoil in international finance may disrupt the flow of trade and investment.
The consumer's tolerance for borderline -- between truth and deception -- has been stretched to the breaking point, an official of the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that he saw no chance of meaningful peace talks in Paris until there had been an all-out military confrontation with North Vietnamese forces, which he predicted would come in 1973.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 -- Brooks Robinson supplied the flashy double-knit orange uniforms the Orioles wore for the first time tonight and he also supplied the grand-slam homer that powered Baltimore to a 6-2 victory over the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Nixon declared today that he would substitute a program of "strong, effective" restraints on major industries after the 90-day freeze on wages and prices expires at midnight Nov. 13.
The people who create and place advertising were shocked, surprised and saddened yesterday by the news of the death of Look, a major national advertising medium for 34 years.
Bache Co., Inc., the nation's second largest brokerage house, made its first public offering of its own stock yesterday, selling 2.5 million shares of common stock at $16 a share.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Organized labor and civil rights groups lost a major fight today as the House approved a sharply stripped-down version of a bill designed to end job discrimination.
A construction project that is said to be the first in the country to combine housing and an elementary school was dedicated by city officials in the Bronx yesterday.
New York City's chief environmental official differed sharply yesterday with the changed Federal attitude toward phosphates in detergents.

For those who can't make it to Leningrad, a glimpse of its great Kirov Ballet Company, last here in 1964, will be available tomorrow night at the first public New York screening of "Swan Lake," a 1969 Soviet film featuring the Kirov.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 (AP) -- South Vietnamese infantrymen reported killing 49 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers today in the heaviest contact so far of an operation designed to upset an expected enemy offensive in the Mekong Delta's U Minh forest.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 -- Thirty-nine American soldiers were arrested for drug use last week in one of the United States command's largest single roundups of drug users.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16 -- President Emilio G. Medici has presented to Congress a development plan for Brazil that reads like a capitalist version of China's "Great Leap Forward."

Henderson admitted today that he had signed a false statement in the aftermath of the Mylai 4 slayings that told of heavy fighting between American troops and enemy forces in the South Vietnamese hamlet on March 16, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Jesse L. Steinfeld, the Surgeon General of the United States, told Congress today that the Federal Government, because of a hazard to health, might eventually have to ban detergents made with caustic soda.

Eliot's "The Hollow Men," which he found particularly fitting in view of his summons by President Nixon to begin setting up the vast machinery required to run the President's welfare reform program if and when it receives final Congressional approval.
Offtrack betting flourished in New York during August despite repeated computer breakdowns, Howard Samuels said yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 16 -- Persons close to the Pakistani Government said today that Pakistan was making a final effort to improve relations with India, Iran, it was said, would play an important role as intermediary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- One month has passed since President Nixon froze wages and prices and lit a political fuse under the American political system. TORONTO, Sept. 16 -- The French painter Edouard Vuillard (1868-1940) is not one of those artists who are constantly on our minds. Indeed, his work is so agreeable -- so shamelessly easy to like -- that we are sometimes in danger of forgetting exactly how strong and original it is.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- White House officials said tonight they had learned on what they felt was good authority that Democratic Senate leaders had threatened their colleagues that campaign contributions in 1972 would be influenced by the way they voted on the draft extension bill.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- Three riot policemen were stoned and beaten to death today and almost 150 were injured as radical students made a last-ditch effort to prevent the Government from preparing farmland for the construction of Tokyo's second international airport.

MADRID, Sept. 16 -- An assembly of the Roman Catholic bishops and priests of Spain has called for an end to the traditional links between the Spanish church and Government and for the establishment of human freedoms and social and economic justice.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany flew to the Crimea today for talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, on Soviet-backed proposals for a European security conference and prospects for reducing military forces in Central Europe.
CAIRO, Sept. 16 -- President Anwar el-Sadat accused the United States tonight of "deception" and procrastination in its efforts to promote a peaceful settlement between Egypt and Israel.

GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- The 55-member council of GATT adopted unanimously today a report holding the 10 per cent United States import surcharge "not compatible" with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It urged the United States to remove it "within a short time."

DETROIT, Sept 16 (AP) -- Saying "I thought it over and feel I don't have to prove to anybody I wasn't over the hill," Alex Karras retired today from football to enter show business and "spend more time with my family."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A Government official said today that the Administration would consider favorably plans by Mack Trucks, Inc., to help build a large plant in the Soviet Union. The official also said the Administration had not blocked the company's plans.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in operating revenues and net income for the quarter and 12 months ended Aug. 31. Revenues in both periods set new highs for any three-month or 12-month period.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Jordan asked the Security Council today to stop Israeli annexation of Jerusalem and Arab lands around the city by invoking "whatever sanctions it deems fit."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Nate Colbert, Larry Stahl and John Jeter hit home runs and Fred Norman pitched a seven-hitter as the San Diego Padres defeated Los Angeles, 4-1, tonight and halted the Dodgers' drive toward the top of the National League's Western Division.
Net income of the Campbell Soup Company rose 7.2 per cent in the fiscal year ended Aug. 1 to $67,208,000, or $2 a share, the giant food concern reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The armed services are going into the motel business to ease the housing problems of transferred servicemen and their families, Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee told a House subcommittee today.

The Continental Can Company announced yesterday the lection of Raymond G. Fisher and S. Bruce Smart Jr. as executives vice presidents. Previously group vice presidents of diversified products and paper operations respectively, with their new corporate positions they become general manager of these groups. Mr. Fisher, 60 years old, joined the company in 1952, and Mr. Smart, 48, joined Continental in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The welfare reform bill is the big proposal in President Nixon's domestic program. It has wide bipartisan support. Yet it faces a rough journey in the Senate.

Hickel.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- In 1946 the Supreme Court heard a claim that unequal population in a state's Congressional districts violated the Constitution. It was a novel claim: The institution of the gerrymander was as old as the country and had never been held unconstitutional. A majority of the Court, finding the issue inappropriate for judges, refused even to consider it on the merits.

PARIS -- Marking one's tenure of power by a prestigious monument has long been a tradition with France's rulers. It used to be churches and chateaus. Significantly, President de Gaulle did not build new palaces but refurbished old ones, in particular the Grand Trianon at Versailles, a choice aptly reflecting a policy bent more on restoring the country's past glories than on inventing new ones.

The 34th Treasurer of the United States will be Mrs. Romana A. Banuelos, a banker and businesswoman from East Los Angeles, Calif.

NEW CASTLE, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The attempted burglary at the estate of Gardner Cowles, the publisher, over the weekend here has led many local law-enforcement officials to believe that a group of highly-organized, professional thieves has returned to northern Westchester County after an absence of some months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it had furloughed 300 of its workers who have been in Amchitka Island in the Aleutians for the nation's largest underground nuclear explosion.

WASHINGTON -- Among the opening burst of art exhibitions in Washington, the National Gallery's John Sloan centennial retrospective, which opened to the public Saturday, is one of the major exhibitions of the season, and will travel to museums in Athens, Ga., San Francisco, St. Louis and Columbus, Ohio, before winding up at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia a year from now.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Australia became the eighth nation today to sign as co-sponsor of two draft resolutions by which the United States hopes to preserve membership in the General Assembly for Nationalist China while admitting Communist China and giving it a veto-wielding seat in the Security Council.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday clarified his repeated warnings that superior officers will be held "accountable" for the acts of their men, saying they will only be "held responsible for a condition [they can] realistically affect."
The United Nations General Assembly convenes here today with a blunt warning from Secretary General Thant that the U.N. "must very soon face the fact that it is a bankrupt organization."

OTTAWA, Sept. 20 -- Peking reportedly informed a number of foreign governments last week that it rejected any softening in the resolution calling for its seating in the United Nations and the simultaneous expulsion of the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Speculators acting on what dealers said was renewed American pressure for an upward revaluation of the West German mark sent the dollar plunging sharply today to a 22-year low in West Germany, the third such plunge in a week.

CAIRO, Sept. 20 -- The Egyptian armed forces were reported on "maximum alert" today in the wake of recent shooting along the Suez Canal, but official emphasis was put on defensive, not offensive, preparedness.

There is no question that some Wall Streeters, sensing a turnaround, have been taking a flier in the airline stocks. But the question is: Have the stocks discounted the future so much that they are currently overpriced?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury has returned two more tax indictments against former political associates of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.
HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- Peking has claimed a steadily rising standard of living for the Chinese people as a result of state policies and of rising agricultural and industrial production.
Germany presented two different kinds of Olympic good news here yesterday during a briefing for next year's Games in Munich.

WILLARD, N. Y., Sept. 20 (AP) -- State troopers cleared kicking and screaming protesters from the entrance to the Sampson State School for the mentally, retarded today and made a path for two buses carrying school residents to other institutions.

For the fourth season in a row, Dave McNally reached the 20-victory plateau by hurling a neat five-hit shutout last night at Yankee Stadium to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-0 triumph over the Yankees.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Frank Sullivan, the humorist who created Mr. Arbuthnot as the ultimate cliche expert on every sub-jet under the sun, enters his 80th year tomorrow in this city of his birth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval to the draft bill today, permitting a return to military conscription until June, 1973.
Have you ever seen a dream skating? If the answer is no, take time out between now and Oct. 3 to visit Madison Square Garden where Peggy Fleming is gracing the 27th edition of "Holiday on Ice."
The Xerox Corporation has canceled sponsorship of the National Broadcasting Company's new series entitled "The Quarterly Report."

For the second time this year American military aircraft have gone beyond the dubious doctrine of "protective reaction" to strike against military targets in North Vietnam. The targets, according to official spokesmen, include supply depots and truck parks as well as the missile and antiaircraft sites that have been the avowed objectives of most earlier punitive raids.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Sept. 22 -- The fate of the Danish Government hung in the balance this morning after one of the closest elections in years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Nixon asked the Senate today to approve the treaty returning Okinawa to Japan. He said that the arrangement would place United States-Japanese relationships "on a more sound and enduring basis" without sacrificing United States security needs.
The Jets' coaching staff presented a "horror" film yesterday for the edification of the players in the Shea Stadium locker room.

Several thousand pro-Peking and pro-Taiwan Chinese staged demonstrations five blocks apart at the United Nations yesterday, then marched to an unscheduled confrontation on First Avenue and 42d Street.

Look magazine's death is a grim reminder of Washington's heavy-handed discrimination between competing media. Look died because it lost too much advertising to television. It paid $4 million a year for the right to use the mails, and the price would have risen to $10 million a year, more than Look could pay for access to this public facility.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- A lawyer for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg charged today that the Federal Government had "used duplicity and failed to honor an order of the court" in seizing 28 boxes of Dr. Ellsberg's personal papers and possessions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Indian tribal chiefs called today for the Bureau of Indian Affairs to be removed from the Department of the Interior and placed in "receivership" in the White House to enable Indians to gain justice and protection of their land and resources.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 -- A Republican Nassau County District Court judge who was defeated by a Republican write-in candidate in last week's primary elections after he had accepted Conservative party endorsement filed suit in State Supreme Court here today to set aside the election.

Prices of futures of imported frozen boneless beef have reached a new high on each trading day since the futures were offered for the first time last Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The price of the nearby contract, for March, 1972, closed yesterday at $61.06 a 100 pounds, up 60 cents. A total of 24 contracts was traded.

" Hello, everybody." Dimpling, grinning and shaking hands all around, the ebullient Mrs. John N. Mitchell burst into the Seventh Avenue showroom of Jo Ellen Couture yesterday morning, spreading cheer and buying clothes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A terrorist bomb exploded tonight at the home of a labor leader once mentioned as a running mate of President Nguyen Van Thieu in what seemed to be an assassination attempt.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Carl Gilbert, President Nixon's special representative for trade negotiations, resigned today.

Manhattan's Upper East Side, already a haunt for art film buffs, will soon provide them with another attraction--a twin-theater movie house called Columbia I and II that will operate primarily as a first-run art film showcase.
Madison Avenue resumed its Tuesday evening "Magic Promenades" yesterday, with stores opened and the street closed to all but buses from 61st Street to 72d.
OTTAWA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Canadian tobacco companies announced today that they would voluntarily end cigarette advertising on radio and television Jan. 1.

August Heckscher, Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural affairs, sharply rejected yesterday a suggestion by the Friends of Central Park that he had been too busy with the cultural aspect of his job to prevent vandalism of a century-old park treasure, the Ladies Pavilion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Discussions between Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, beginning in New York Friday, will place emphasis on the Middle East and disarmament problems.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 21 -- The military judge in the court-martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina told Government and defense counsel today that he would instruct the jury that it could consider convicting the captain of the misdemeanor of negligent homicide.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- West German monetary authorities today put a 10 per cent limit on the upward float of the mark in an effort to improve their bargaining position in any future multilateral-currency realignment.

It is surprising to see The Times express regret that the Oct. 4 election in South Vietnam will involve only one general instead of perhaps two or three generals as candidates [editorial "The Thieu-Bunker Tragedy," Sept. 4]. Your premise seems to be that a meaningful free election is possible in that devastated and militarily occupied country.

The credit markets, beset by diminished confidence in the efficacy of the Administration's economic program and by swelling calendars of new issues, lost more ground yesterday and interest rates worked higher.

Companies that transport 116,000 public-school children to and from school will continue to operate today, despite a ruling by the Federal Cost of Living Council late yesterday denying their request for an exemption from the President's wage and price freeze.

DETROIT -- As the only black newsman requested to go behind the walls of Attica prison as a member of a citizens' observing committee, I found myself more at home inside the yard in the inmate-controlled D block than either of my two white colleagues.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced the appointment of the 71-member board that will govern the city's new community-based Comprehensive Health Planning Agency.

Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts announced yesterday the indictment of 18-year-old Michael Falco on charges of murder and possession of a dangerous weapon in connection with a fatal beating in a Bronx park last July 20.
WASHINGTON, Sept., 21 -- Stiff opposition from Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. greeted the National and American Basketball Associations today as they sought permission from Congress to merge.

AUSTIN, Tex. -- What's wrong with the United States?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- William J. Casey, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the commission was about ready to approve a new schedule of sales commissions on stock transactions, one that would remove the surcharge of up to $15 on orders of 1,000 shares or less.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- A small California company, the Astrophysics Research Corporation, introduced a small device today that may make a big difference in the $1-billion a year in thefts of securities, bonds and other valuable documents.

The first scattered shots have been fired in what may become a full-scale price war among major chain supermarkets in the metropolitan area. Because of economic reasons, it's unlikely that the war will soon extend into Manhattan, but the rumblings have been heard elsewhere in the city.

One week after Lufthansa German Airlines disavowed a trans-Atlantic air fares agreement, most other airlines appear to be in a quandary over how to cope with the situation. The result is uncertainty over how much it will cost to fly to Europe after Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A group of 32 Congressmen, citing a new survey on domestic air travel, urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to make major changes in the structure of airline fares.

There is a certain perspective on "The Thieu-Bunker Tragedy" that I find unheeded in your editorial opinions on the Vietnamese elections.

The eclipse of Italy on the international bridge scene may prove to be merely temporary. The great Blue Team, which retired in 1969 after 13 years of almost uninterrupted success, may decide to defend its world team Olympiad title in Miami Beach next June.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a closely watched barometer of the technical condition of the stock market, rose slightly in the month ended Sept. 15 following five consecutive monthly declines.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday named Andrew P. Kerr, a management consultant, to the $37,500-a-year post of Deputy Budget Director. Last year the city's Board of Ethics had said there was no conflict of interest in the fact that Mr. Kerr was head of a city planning council that awarded his firm a $212,000 contract.

Governor Rockefeller opened his campaign for the proposed $2.5-billion transportation bond issue yesterday by asserting that the bonds, if approved by the voters in November, could be worth 5 cents toward each subway fare.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- "When Detroit and Minnesota play, nobody wins," said Bud Grant, the Viking coach. "It's just a matter of which team is ahead when the game ends."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The House of Representatives this year has a new Speaker and operates under a new voting procedure, but it remains an unreformed institution which frustrates many of its own members and does not carry its full share of the burden of governing the nation.

You provide various yardsticks to compare the American "doctor's average income of $40,000" with that of attorneys, dentists, bankers and other professions. [News story Sept. 13.] Has any economist ever gauged a physician's income on a per-hour basis?
BOSTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- American League owners voted tonight to shift the franchise of the financially ailing Washington Senators to Arlington, Tex., between Dallas and Fort Worth, for next season.
The stock market yesterday provided a rerun of Monday's performance. RCA Corporation moved higher as the most active issue, while the general market slipped lower.
State Commissioner of Correction Russell G. Oswald said last night that the danger of another uprising at the Attica Correstional Facility still existed.

DORCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 21 (AP) -- A woman pilot was killed in a plane crash on a mountainside here, and an unidentified rescue worker died today when he fell from a rope lowered from a rescue helicopter.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 21 -- The Marin County Coroner said today that George L. Jackson was shot in the back, not through the top of the head as had been reported earlier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A Federal judge ordered the Army Corps of Engineers today to stop construction of the $386.6-million Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway until he could rule on whether the Administration-supported project would damage the environment.

The new President of the United Nations General Assembly, Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia, is noted for an ability to depict positions of bitter enemies in such ways that they sometimes end up thinking that they have been agreeing with one another all along.

VANCOUVER, Wash., Sept. 21 -- A civil damage action with political overtones opened here this week with all the speed of a tortoise race. After two days of questioning, three jurors have been accepted tentatively. It is predicted that the trial will last from two to four months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The owners of four American ship lines and the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Maritime Affairs urged a House committee today to approve proposed legislation that would permit ship owners under the Government's construction-subsidy program to sell unprofitable vessels to foreign buyers.
The police sent out an alarm yesterday for two men who raped a young ballet dancer in Central Park on Monday evening.

Using a comparison shopping list based on the one provided by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, a spot check was made Sept. 13 of prices in six supermarkets in North Jersey. Ed Bullins is a playwright and activist. He is one of the most prolific of America's younger playwrights, having already written 30 works for the theater including four plays toward his ambitious 20-play cycle about blacks in America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The superintendent of the Philadelphia school system recommended today that the Federal Government nationalize the operation and funding of the nation's 25 largest urban public school systems.

The Federal Trade Commission filed a suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn against Swingline, Inc., a manufacturer of staplers, and its parent company, American Brands, Inc., a tobacco and food company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A panel of scientists says the pesticide DDT poses no immediate threat of widespread human sicknescs or death but is likely to cause a gradual deterioration of the environment.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 22 -- Premier Eisaku Sato announced today that Japan would join with the United States in sponsoring two resolutions intended to preserve the seat of Nationalist China in the United Nations while admitting Communist China.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., indicated yesterday that it had placed the largest order in history for electronic stock-market quotation devices with the newest competitor in the field -- the International Business Machines Corporation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union today affirmed its opposition to any formula for dual representation for China in the United Nations and called for universality of membership in the world organization.

FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 21 -- The former commander of an assault helicopter unit in Vietnam testified today that he could not recall ever talking with Col. Oran K. Henderson about what his pilots had seen at the hamlet of Mylai 4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The House overrode its Judiciary Committee today and agreed to vote on a proposed constitutional amendment to permit prayers in schools.

The Communications Workers of America charged yesterday that the New York Telephone Company was refusing to bargain, and it broke off negotiations aimed at ending the 10-week-old strike by 38,500 craftsmen.

ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The chief doctor of the State Department of Correctional Services said today that an independent team of nine doctors had examined all of the more than 1,400 inmates of the Attica Correctional Facility today and had found no wounds or bruises inflicted since the inmates' revolt was crushed a week ago.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, parent company of New York's third-largest bank, announced yesterday agreement in principle to acquire the First National Bank of Bay Shore, L. I., in an exchange of shares worth about $12.5-million.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- The centralization of the General Motors Corporation is tied at least in part to an effort to make the company more difficult to break up in antitrust actions, according to Automotive News, a trade publication.

WILLARD, N. Y., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- A man who wanted to "dramatize" protests against the closing of the Sampson State School for the Mentally Retarded set himself afire today and later declined to be admitted to a nearby hospital.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Nixon Administration released to Congress today a censored 7,800-page version of the Pentagon papers. The text will be available to the public next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Two more potential Democratic Presidential candidates urged President Nixon today to nominate a woman to the Supreme Court to succeed Justice Hugo L. Black, who is retiring.

The Federal Government succeeded last week in undoing several years of public education on the harm that detergents do to the nation's waters. Illinois Central Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it had signed a memorandum of intent to acquire Lincoln Consolidated, Inc., a financial-services holding company, through an exchange of stock.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration reported today it made a record 78,902 loans during the last fiscal year, totaling $1.4-billion.

FLORENCE, Italy, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Thieves broke into St. Mark's Church yesterday and stole jewels that had been with the embalmed body of a saint, the police said. A gold ring, a gold cross and a bishop's staff were taken.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- A report from Hanoi in L'Unita, the Italian Communist party newspaper, said today that the Roman Catholic Church in North Vietnam was deeply split over the issue of cooperation with the Communist Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Tom Seaver's chances of winning 20 games diminished considerably today after the New York Mets' ace lost a 3-0 pitching duel to Burt Hooton and the Chicago Cubs. Seaver, who has 18 victories, must win his final two starts to reach the magic circle.

A former antipoverty official who was once characterized by former Controller Mario A. Procaccino as a "hardened criminal" was sentenced yesterday to 20 years' imprisonment for armed robbery.
Two major food companies, General Mills, Inc., and the Beatrice Foods Company, announced higher earnings yesterday.

The accounts in The Times and other papers of the appearance by New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson on Sept. 8 before the New York State Assembly committee concerning no-fault auto insurance reform indicate shocking conduct on the part of some committee members.

HOUSTON, Sept. 21 -- The San Francisco Giants missed a great chance to open some daylight in the home stretch tonight when they were defeated by the Houston Astros, 3-1, for the 13th loss in their last 16 games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--A group of consumer advocates told President Nixon today that all sectors of the economy should make equal sacrifices in the next phase of the President's new economic program and urged him to establish ceilings on profits and dividends.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 22 -- United States jet fighter-bombers struck inside North Vietnam yesterday in force, dropping 200 planeloads of bombs on military positions in an area extending 35 miles northward from the demilitarized zone.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 21 -- The Northern Ireland Government suggested tonight that it might phase out its controversial policy of internment without trial and introduce sweeping changes in the system of government, probably involving the introduction of proportional representational voting and the placing of Roman Catholics in Cabinet posts.

Frank Robinson joined the exclusive Five Hundred Club a week ago as he became the 11th man to hit 500 career home runs. The nation's colleges have made substantial progress toward opening their campuses to black students. It is one of the major accomplishments of the civil rights movement that most leading universities, after years of tokenism, now make it their business to recruit and subsidize large numbers of minority students.

NAPANOCH, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Guards at the Eastern New York Correction facility in this Catskill Mountain community today described the prison as "tense" in the wake of last week's uprising at Attica.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 -- Representatives of 11 countries controlling about 80 per cent of the world's oil production began meetings here today to decide on issues that have a major impact on international petroleum companies.

Ralph Nader's dispute with the American Automobile Association gathered steam inside and outside the Americana yesterday as a handful of "Nader Raiders" picketed the association's annual meeting at the hotel.

The rescue of varsity football in Philadelphia's high schools is a case of last things first. For any student it provides a revealing insight into a community's -- and perhaps a nation's -- priorities. The civic conscience in the City of Brotherly Love had apparently slept through the imposition of severe cutbacks in the high schools' educational programs and the virtual elimination of extracurricular activities much more intimately related to the learning process.

Monday evening at Philharmonic Hall was a night for nostalgia. On stage were two bandleaders who have survived more than 30 years of the ups and downs of the big band business -- Stan Kenton and Lionel Hampton.

The action by a bare majority of the House of Representatives to lift the ban on prayers in public schools is a move to undermine rather than to amend the Constitution. The principles at issue -- reaffirmed in 1963 by the Supreme Court in an 8-to-1 ruling -- are both protection of the individual's freedom from religious coercion and prohibition of the establishment of any religion by the state or its publicly supported institutions.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- A prison nurse and a guard were found dead today after police blasted their way into a prison infirmary where they had been held hostage by two convicts. The police said that their throats had been slashed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- President Nixon, "distressed" over the franchise shift of the Washington Senators to Texas, said today he was shifting his allegiance as the nation's No. 1 baseball fan to the California Angels.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 22 -Nassau County obtained an injunction in State Supreme Court here today barring continued job action at Nassau Community College in a dispute over an increase in teaching hours.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Two United States fighter-bombers destroyed an antiaircraft gun site 77 miles inside North Vietnam after receiving fire from gun position, the United States command announced today.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22 (AP) -Two 18-year-olds, one advocating increased use of the rod at school, the other increased power to the people, called for changes in local offices today after upset primary election victories in Washington.
ROME, Sept. 22 -- The Government today adopted price controls to curb a sudden increase in the cost of living that has caused grumbling among Italians.

Just as Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera was in a way a valedictory, marking the opening of Rudolf Bing's last season, so Tuesday night at the Philharmonic was a beginning. It was the Pension Fund concert of the orchestra, and Pierre Boulez conducted his first concert as musical director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -Congress completed action today on an appropriations bill containing a ban on the planned underground nuclear test on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians "unless the President gives his direct approval" for the test.

The only American military man convicted for the murdering of civilians at Mylai is First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. He was found guilty last March of the murder of 22 civilians at the South Vietnamese hamlet.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Agreement on the continued use of the naval base in Malta by Britain and her allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was announced here tonight.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Over the objections of his widow, the body of Judge Harold J. Haley, killed Aug. 7, 1970, in a gun battle at the Marin County Civic Center, was ordered exhumed today so that Ruchell Magee could try to prove he was not the judge's killer.

The State Department of Social Services has requested Federal approval for a demonstration project that would require welfare mothers with children over the age of 6 to go to work or to care in their homes for children of other welfare mothers who are working.

PEKING, Thursday, Sept. 23 -- Dr. Paul Dudley White, an eminent United States cardiologist who is visiting Peking at the invitation of the Chinese Medical Assoication, said last night that Chinese doctors have assured him that Chairman Mao is in excellent condition.

A European marketing company whose parent concern is in Australia has just introduced into the United States (the world's No. 1 marketing power) a cleansing cream for black women that was developed in Africa by a white chemist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -Officials of seven Federal agencies are expressing increasing concern over the possible health hazards of a colorless, odorless liquid named PCB that some scientists hold to be even more dangerous than DDT, to which it has a close chemical resemblance.

The Bronx borough superintendent of inspectors for the Municipal Loan Fund was dismissed from his $11,200-a-year position yesterday. He was accused of having approved payment of $268,000 for slum renovation work that had not been performed, according to Commissioner of Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin.

The city's chief utilities planner yesterday proposed the development of a state program for mutual aid on natural gas supplies for utility companies in the state, in view of a current shortage that he said might "worsen in the next few years."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- New orders for durable goods fell by 2.3 per cent, or $714-million, in August compared with a revised increase of 3.4 per cent in July, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The White House said today that it was seeking some way to defer a scheduled $2.4-billion military pay increase until the present wage-price freeze ends Nov. 13.
Critics of the state's handling of the Attica uprising demanded prison reform yesterday and disclosed plans to demonstrate sympathy for the dead prisoners and give aid to their families.
BELGRADE, Sept. 20 -- "You cannot have detente in Europe and war in the Balkans."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Monetary negotiations here next weekend will center on procedure, not substance, and the United States will be as insistent as before that the price of gold and the United States import surcharge not be among the first items to be considered in future negotiations.

PHILADELPHIA -- The Philadelphia Museum of Art has scored a small coup -- no, take out the "small" and. make it plain "coup" -- has scored a coup with an exhibition that has slipped onto the scene quietly, the first anywhere devoted to Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione, with a handsome catalogue that must stand for some time as the definitive work on this 17thcentury Genoese artist.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -Consumer prices rose substantially in August, with the price freeze still having only a limited effect, the Labor Department reported today.

Along the Massachusetts coast and the offshore islands winter often comes slowly; there may be high winds and rain, but bitter cold is uncommon, even into December.
Anne Morrow Lindbergh will publish selections from her letters and diaries, starting with her school years and continuing through World War II, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich announced yesterday.

About 15,000 high school seniors have qualified as semifinalists in the 1971-72 National Merit Scholarship competition, which involved 655,000 students in 16,600 schools throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.

The Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx said yesterday that they would fight Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5-billion transportation bond issue unless they were guaranteed that the 30-cent subway fare would be maintained.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Toughness. Yes, toughness. That is what we admire here. Here in Washington. The nation's capital, baby, and don't you forget it.

Approval by the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission of more than $7.9-million in 1971-72 grants to four methadone maintenance programs in the metropolitan area was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

A West German charter airline announced yesterday that it would slash the price of a round-trip flight between New York and Germany to $135 on Feb. 1. The move expanded a price war that promised bargains for travelers, but that almost all airlines said threatened to lead them into insolvency.

A prosecutor disclosed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that a former chief inspector of the Police Department had been involved in the alleged corruption efforts of Hugh Mulligan, a reputed bookmaker and loan-shark.
Since Verdi's "Rigoletto" was performed by the Metropolitan Opera last season, the return of the work on Tuesday night was not a momentous occasion, but the performance was not without interest.

RACINE, Wis., Sept. 22 -- A group of lawyers, jurists and law scholars, after meeting here for four days, proposed last week a new plan for establishing an international criminal court and additional offenses specified as international crimes.
TULSA, Okla. -- "I hate to sound like I'm waving a banner, but I guess we did put our liberal money where our liberal mouths were," said Mrs. R. W. Caldwell.
FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 22 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina was acquitted today of all charges of involvement in the killing of civilians at Mylai.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- If ever there was a mad scientist, it was Isaac Newton.

GREENLAWN, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Charges of misuse of millions of dollars of town funds and of the use of inside political information by town officeholders for personal profit were made today in the campaign for control of the government of the Town of Huntington in Suffolk County.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- After a simmering summer truce, the textile war between the United States and Japan has erupted again. And, the Japanese say, the Americans shot first.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Mayor Frank Curran has been defeated in a bid for a third four-year term as head of California's second-largest city.

James Plumeri, a reputed Mafia figure known as Jimmy Doyle, was buried in St. John's Cemetery in Queens yesterday after a private, Roman Catholic funeral service. Doyle was found murdered on a Queens street Friday.
The election of Adam Malik as President of the United Nations General Assembly is a personal triumph for Indonesia's dynamic Foreign Minister and a favorable portent for this crucial U.N. session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, said today that Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts, the only Negro Senator, would be an asset to the G.O.P. national ticket.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its worst performance in more than seven weeks yesterday as the list fell sharply in stepped-up trading.
Mayor Lindsay heralded the printing industry yesterday as "one of the major industries" of New York City at a ceremony opening a campaign by city printers to increase their share of the market.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22 -- A Montgomery newspaper reported today that a ranking Alabama legislative official and a brother of Gov. George C. Wallace "split a $60,000 payoff" from a prominent Birmingham lawyer who handled the legal work on state bond issues in 1965 and 1967.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Sept. 22 -Many of the seven hundred or so persons who braved a downpour to gather in the chapel at Wake Forest University were puzzled at the news just in from Washington. The Senate had passed the draft bill, after gutting the Mansfield Amendment to withdraw all American troops from Vietnam in nine months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Declaring that the United States Postal Service was in the "vanguard of change," Postmaster General Winton M. Blount told more than 3,000 delegates to the fifth annual Postal Forum today that postal productivity increased 3.5 per cent in the last fiscal year, under present management techniques.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- A Jewish woman who sent an anonymous letter to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has been sentenced to three years' confinement on charges of slandering the Soviet state, a Central Asian newspaper has reported.

The great social value of an independent, impartial medical examiner system has been dramatically demonstrated again with the reports on the deaths at Attica State Prison. Forty-four competitors, all under 18 years old and from 40 countries on all continents, gathered at the Zappeon in Athens to vie for the junior world chess championship. Held under the auspices of the Greek Chess Federation, the event took place in a modern open air exhibition building in antique round style.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -One-Ton yacht racing arrived in the United States for the first time today, when the Ida Lewis Yacht Club committee fired its starting gun at 12:30 P.M. for seven boats.
A wildcat strike of locomotive engineers that began at midnight will disrupt service this morning on the New Haven division of the Penn Central, the railroad said early today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The United States today lost the first skirmish in its campaign to prevent the expulsion of the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan from the United Nations.

The head of one of Europe's largest banks warned yesterday of the threat of a "growing disintegration of world trade" if the United States and the Common Market did not settle their differences over international monetary reform.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Speaking against the background of President Nixon's new economic policies, the leading executives of the United States textile industry charged here today that Japan is practicing the ultimate in economic nationalism as far as international trade is concerned.

After a long tour, Les Grands Ballets Canadiens has returned to City Center with its successful acid rock opera ballet "Tommy." More a cycle of songs than an opera and more a sequence of tableaus vivants than ballet, "Tommy" creates its own theatrical form swinging around the pounding music and ironic lyrics created by The Who.

BELGRADE, Sept. 22 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, arrived in Yugoslavia today and said he had come to "discuss a whole line of important questions." Tonight, after having begun talks with President Tito, the Soviet leader delivered a toast at a dinner in his honor that appeared to be a conditional affirmation of noninterference in Yugoslavia's affairs.

On Broadway it is usually the plays and the performances, not the theaters, that stir up memories. But yesterday it was the Music Box, celebrating its 50th anniversary, that took the bows. The Music Box, Moss Hart wrote in "Act One," is "everybody's dream of a theater."

ELMIRA, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- A deputy commissioner who is regarded as chief troubleshooter for Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald said today that he would recommend to Mr. Oswald the establishment of a "maximum security facility" to which the "more militant people, the aggressive people" within the state's prison population would be concentrated "so they won't spread their poison" to other inmates.

Yields on high-grade electric utility bonds inched their way upward again yesterday and reached 8 per cent -- a rate that apparently doesn't hold all the magic for institutional investors that Wall Street had hoped.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 22 -- Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, leader of West Pakistan's majority party, implied today that his party might begin armed resistance to the military Government if it did not cede power by the end of the year.

PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Sept. 22 -- Wally Sezna of Greenville, Del., upset David Goldman of Dallas, a two-time runner-up, 3 and 2, in the first round of the United States senior amateur golf championship today at Sunnybrook Golf Club.

In the heart of the black community of south central Los Angeles, construction is under way on what will eventually become a vast housing and commercial development known as Ujima Village.

For years plebes at West Point have recited: "A cadet may not have a horse, wife, dog or mustache." So it will be a bit of an oddity on Sunday, when a match dog show will be held on the Military Academy grounds.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- The international relief organization of the Roman Catholic Church appealed to the United Nations today to save the people of East Pakistan from "what threatens to be one of the most deadly famines of our times."
A convicted narcotics pusher was sentenced yesterday to 20 years to life imprisonment for possession of more than two pounds of heroin.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Cliff Richey has quit the Davis Cup tennis team that is to meet Rumania in the challenge round in Charlotte, N.C., Oct. 8 to 10.

The General Electric Company's total order backlog has reached a high of more than $9-billion, or "about the same as our annual sales," Fred J. Borch, chairman and chief executive officer, told some 350 security-analysts at a special meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Economic problems have replaced the Vietnam war as the chief concern of the American people, the Gallup Poll reported today.
Helen Brown, a member of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers union in Chicago, is planning to buy a home sometime next year and will need a lawyer.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said last night that "a very carefully controlled heroin maintenance program might be worth experimentation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Oscar Robertson, Zelmo Beaty and Dave DeBusschere gave vivid examples of how their income increased when it was possible to exercise a choice of employers as they testified today before the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 22 -- Scientists of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have developed a method for aerially monitoring one of the most vital activities on earth -- the biological productivity of lakes and seas.

The American Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday to incorporate as a nonprofit organization and said its membership had approved constitutional amendments to do so. The exchange has traditionally operated as an unincorporated association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In a decision that could have an important national impact on where subsidized housing is to be built, the Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment ruled today that a project previously approved for the central city of Philadelphia should have been rejected.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- William E. Kirwan, superintendent of the state police, said today that the recapture of Attica Prison was "not a turkey shoot." There was, he maintained, "no indiscriminate firing" by law enforcement agencies.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 22 -- Nine months hence what many consider a small miracle in international relations will occur: Representatives of most of the world's nations will meet at Stockholm to take collective action on global environmental problems.
Donald R. Manes, sworn in yesterday as the 16th Borough President of Queens, immediately called for the return of control of vital city services to the office of the Borough Presidents.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 22 -Thomas Gangemi Jr., whose father was forced to resign as Mayor, in 1963 because he lacked United States citizenship, announced today that he would seek the post in the special municipal elections here Nov. 2.
The keenest spectator in the International Team semifinal playoff match beginning at the New York Hilton tomorrow evening will be Lee Hazen of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -Joseph E. Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, said today that he was "completely opposed" to proposed legislation, "as it now stands," that would enable the owners of four leading American ship lines to sell vessels, including the liner United States, to foreign buyers.

To the layman, haute cuisine means expensive French food served in expensive restaurants. To a chef, however, it is a science and a style, a classic way of approaching food that was codified by Escoffier in his "Guide Culinaire." It does not depend on chic but on long years of apprenticeship for the chef.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 -- The recent experiences of Scioto Downs and Wolverine Raceway, which suffered large minus pools when Albatross won at those tracks, led the Little Brown Jug Society today to bar the spectacular pacer from the betting in tomorrow's 26th annual Little Brown Jug, which will offer a gross purse of $102,964.80.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- The Boston School Committee has abandoned a three-week integration effort and allowed some parents today to send their children to neighborhood schools largely along racial lines.

The Association of American Publishers held its fall meeting yesterday amid warnings that Government censorship and radical pressure groups are increasingly threatening the nation's First Amendment freedoms.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- The Federal National Mortgage Association said yesterday it accepted $193-million of the $437.5-million in bids submitted in Monday's free market system auction for mortgage commitments.

Stock prices took a sharp drop yesterday as some leading market averages fell to their lowest levels of the last month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Representatives Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, and William M. McCulloch, Republican of Ohio, urged President Nixon today to name Representative Richard H. Poff to the Supreme Court.
DADE CITY, Fla., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Threats and resentment over the burial of a black man in an all-white cemetery have resulted in a decision to transfer the body to an isolated Negro cemetery.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The British Government, in a change of policy, indicated today that it was ready for major political concessions to the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.
Trading of soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday was very steady, largely in response to early speculative short covering. Soybeans closed 1 1/2 cents to 2 cents a bushel higher.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday the advancement of Colin MacLennan, former vice president and controller, and Herman A. Streller, former senior vice president, operations, as executive vice presidents. Tilford C. Gains, former vice president and economist, was elected senior vice president and economist. Named senior vice presidents are Dwight G. Allen, international; Albert E. Christie, legal; Arthur C. Langsdorf, real estate and mortgage; and Leslie E. Oland, operations.
PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The North Vietnamese delegation today called off tomorrow's session of the Paris peace conference in protest against the American bombings of North Vietnam.

ATLANTA, Sept 22 (UPI) -- Municipal Judge Robert M. Sharp ruled today that Rico Carry was justified in fighting with three police officers last month and dismissed charges against the Atlanta Braves outfielder of assault and creating a turmoil.

COPAKE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -The old-time friendly telephone operator is disappearing in this rural area, but anyone with a problem can pick up the phone and talk directly with John Benedict (Ben) Ackley, president of the local telephone company.

TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- Premier Eisaku Sato's decision to join the United States in sponsoring two resolutions on Chinese representation in the United Nations drew immediate hostility from his political enemies and frosty silence from his allies today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A band of militant young Indians sought to make a citizens' arrest of a Federal official today and wound up in a noisy clash with Government guards at the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The House Ways and Means Committee completed work on the tax bill today, adding more than $3-billion over the next three years to the tax relief for individuals proposed by President Nixon.
The Government's refund to the airlines of their deposits for the now abandoned supersonic transport program has been a bookkeeping windfall in the industry's reporting of August results.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 22 -Governor Rockefeller was applauded here today at a $100-a-plate Republican breakfast after he had been praised for his actions in the Attica prison uprising, which led to the deaths of 10 hostages and 30 inmates.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The Chicago Cubs, continuing their late season surge to solidfy their hold on third place in the National League's Eastern Division, took a two-game lead over the New York Mets today with a 4-1 victory on Bill Hands's strong eight-hit pitching.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22 -- A South African doctor, as the result of experiments he made on pigs, has suggested that an inexpensive drug might counteract the terrifying symptoms of a new disease that occurs, on rare occasions, when some patients undergo surgery.

Nearly a quarter-million unfilled orders for new telephones have piled up in the ten weeks since installers, linemen and maintenance employes of the New York Telephone Company went on strike. Only the high degree of phone automation, plus the round-the-clock efforts of managerial personnel and Bell System troubleshooters brought in from other areas, has prevented a major breakdown of service -- none too good even before the strike.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- A 50year-old army general today replaced Marshal Matvei V. Zakharov, 73, as the chief of the General Staff.
TRENTON, Sept. 22 -- A bill that would ban nonreturnable beverage containers to reduce litter appeared to be immobilized today in a legislative committee.

JANESVILLE, Wis. -- I remember the first time I saw the lake. Its water was bright, diamond clear, and it flickered under the September sun so that red and orange maple leaves which had drifted into the lake lay on the white rippled sand like a pattern of old wallpaper.

School bus operators agreed yesterday to continue to transport 116,000 city pupils until at least Nov. 13, when the current wage-price freeze ends, despite the latest Federal refusal to exempt their new contracts from emergency controls.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A Senate weary from a protracted fight over the draft settled down today with little apparent enthusiasm or interest to its annual debate on the defense budget and routinely supported development of a new supersonic bomber for the Air Force.
HARTFORD, Sept. 22 -- The Mayors of four major Connecticut cities won renomination in Democratic party primaries today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union announced today the start of production on the second main assembly line of its Italian-built Fiat plant and unveiled the most complete set of statistics on car output and ownership yet published in its official press.

Jake Gibbs, who was a Yankee before any of his current teammates, left Yankee Stadium for the last time as a player last night, taking with him a new cigar humidor, an oil portrait of himself and a bushelful of fond memories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The air strike carried out against North Vietnam Tuesday was the fifth such massive raid ordered by President Nixon under his much-explained, much-misunderstood policy of "protective reaction."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Senate put aside defense matters temporarily today to decide, in defiance of a United Nations embargo, that the United States should permit the importing of chrome ore from Rhodesia.
Western diplomatic reports said yesterday that there appears to be a continuing political crisis in China.

The City Council yesterday elected Morton Povman, a Queens district leader, as Councilman from the 15th Council District, replacing Donald R. Manes, who was elected Queens Borough President Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Nolan Ryan and Bob Aspromonte, whose contributions lately have been virtually nil, provided the pitching and the hitting today that enabled the Mets to defeat the Cubs, 5-4, and move to within one game of third place.

BOGOTA, Sept. 23 -- Colombia's Finance Minister, Dr. Rodrigo Lllorente, today told Latin American economic policymakers that the international monetary system would be well served should trade ties beteen free-enterprise nations and the socialist countries of Europe and Asia so expand as to "dilute the excessive power of some of the present members" of the International Monetary Fund.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- The automobile manufacturers today reported 194,104 sales of United States-type cars in the Sept. 11-20 period, up 22 per cent from 159,201 a year before.

Railroad commuting from Connecticut suburbs was disrupted yesterday morning when engineers with a grievance called in sick, curtailing service on the New Haven division of the Penn Central from 27 rush-hour trains to 10 that were operated by supervisory personnel.

Time Inc., the country's most successful publisher of mass magazines, will take another step today toward getting into the specialty magazine field.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Major foreign currencies rose today on combustible foreign-exchange markets as officials of 118 nations began departing for Washington for a week of meetings on the monetary crisis.

The election of Edmund T. Pratt Jr. as president of Pfizer, Inc., was announced yesterday by the diversified pharmaceutical and chemical company. Mr. Pratt, formerly executive vice president, is the seventh president of Pfizer.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Fourth-seeded Clark Graebner of New York was knocked out of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today by unseeded Jim Connors of Santa Monica, Calif., 6-4, 6-3.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 23 -- Mayor Julius Wilensky was nominated for a second term today by Republican voters, turning back a challenger supported by the party organization.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 23 -- Who else but Herve Filion, heading for his fourth straight North American driving title, would help to spring the most astounding upset of the 1971 harness racing season?

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The board of directors of the financially troubled Swift de la Plata meat-packing company was replaced last night by a court order. The concern is owned by Deltec International, an American-West ternational, an American concern based in the Bahamas.

ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Another inmate, wounded by gunfire during the police assault on State Correctional Facility here 10 days ago, died early this morning.
