LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept 23 -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight that the Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx and other politicians who were threatening to oppose his $2.5-billion transportation bond issue unless the 30-cent New York City transit fare was retained were "biting off their noses to spite their faces."
Prices of soybean futures declined 2 1/8 cents to 4 1/2 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Ron Letellier, the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association titleholder, played four-under-par golf over the last 14 holes today and took the 36-hole lead in the Metropolitan open championship by three strokes.

For a year or more, Jim Hall and Ron Carter have been working as an unusually effective duo on guitar and bass. Most of their appearances have been at The Guitar, 10th Avenue at 51st Street, where they are scheduled to return on Oct. 13.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has moved to the brink of another bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 23 -- A telegram arrived for Bob Hyland a few days ago and now the 6-foot-5-inch, 250-pound guard, acquired last week from Chicago, doesn't feel quite so bad about his first game in a New York Giant uniform.

A hurdle race that started as a cavalry charge found riders falling almost like tenpins yesterday as the 14th running of the Elkridge Handicap was won by Montpelier's consistent Winigo on Belmont Park's soft turf.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- The lawyer in charge of investigating State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer for the Court on the Judiciary interrupted his inquiry today to report his findings to the court because, he said, "we just got to the point where we thought we had enough to recommend action to the court."

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Unemployment in Britain and Northern Ireland rose in September to the highest level since 1940, the Government announced today. Measures taken in July to stimulate the economy and provide more jobs have had no effect as yet, and the Government is under increasing political attack.

BUTTE, Mont., Sept. 25 (UPI) Approval of a new three-year copper contract by striking Anaconda Company craft unions has ended a strike that cost Montana workers $14-million in wages and at its height made 39,000 workers idle in five western states.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- As presently organized, the House of Representatives is insufficiently responsive to the urban and social needs of the nation. Its seniority system and committee structure are forces for the status quo and a constant drag on progressive reform.

WASHINGTON Sept. 23 -- A number of cities are making "paper layoffs" of employes to rehire them with funds intended to provide jobs for the unemployed under the Emergency Employment Act, the nation's top manpower official disclosed today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23 -- South Vietnam's many opposition groups, often considered weak cells of protest, are trying to band together to stop Nguyen Van Thieu in his unopposed bid for re-election next month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast Stock Exchange announced today the opening of a new securities depository designed to reduce "wasteful movement of stock certificates."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration has endorsed legislation to reimburse industry for losses caused by the Government's ban on cyclamate food sweeteners.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that it expects to okay a Big Board - proposed fee schedule next week -- one that would eliminate the $15 surcharge but raise the basic commission schedule to a level in line with the surcharge on small trades.

Because of questions raised over possible conflict of interest involving members of the Rockefeller family, the City Council yesterday postponed final action on appropriating $5.2-million for the acquisition and renovation of the Vivian Beaumont theater in Lincoln Center.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 23 -- The marriage of Miss Nancy Lynne Cahners to David R. Pokross Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pokross of Belmont, took place here this evening. Rabbi Manuel Saltzman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Cahners.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Two United States Senators requested today that baseball's antitrust exemption be investigated along with the request of the two major basketball leagues to merge.

A model of a new taxicab, only two inches longer than a Volkswagen but with more head and leg room than a a Cadillac limousine, was unveiled here yesterday by Pratt Institute. Its designers said prototypes could be running on New York streets in two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Justice Hugo L. Black, who retired from the Supreme Court last Friday, was put on the "very serious" list today at Bethesda Naval Hospital. A hospital statement said the prognosis was poor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The State Department was reported today to be planning to ask Congress for an additional $250-million for relief of Pakistani refugees in India and for rehabilitation programs in East Pakistan.

The Pennsylvania Company, all of whose common stock is pledged as security for a $300-million bank loan of its parent, the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, yesterday issued its own income account for 1970. The bond market, buoyed by the thought that President Nixon again might say something that would push interest rates downward, ended its week-long slide yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The retirement of Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan gives President Nixon a rare opportunity to nominate two Justices at once and presents a real possibility that the time may have come for a woman Justice to sit on the Supreme Court. Presumably, the Presi dent will have uppermost in mind to mold a "Nixon Court" that will impress his strict-constructionist philosophy upon the law for decades to come.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 23 -- Bullet, the PJ 37 sailed by Andy MacGowan, captured the second race of the Ida Lewis Yacht Club One Ton Cup series today for her second victory in a row.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- Five witnesses flown here from New York City viewed two suspects in the slaying of two patrolmen in Harlem last May in a tense, two-hour line-up here today and an assistant district attorney said afterward there was a "strong possibility" that grand jury indictments would be sought.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- On the day John Marshall Harlan was nominated to the Supreme Court 16 years ago, he invited newsmen into his judicial chambers at Foley, Square. Then, amid much clamor and bustle, he limited his comment on his nomination to one sentence: "I am very deeply honored."

The governor of the Bank of Italy called yesterday for the formation of a European monetary bloc -- including, among others, the six nations of the Common Market and Britain -- whose currencies would move in unison in relation to the dollar.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 23 -- Alfred Rose, a Birmingham lawyer who handles legal work on bond issues in Alabama, acknowledged today that his law firm had paid a $60,000 fee to the Speaker of he Alabama House in connection with bond issues in 1965 and '67.

PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Sept. 23 -- Tom Draper of Troy, Mich.; William Colm and Ernest Pieper Jr. of California, and William Hyndman of Abington, Pa., gained the semifinals of United States senior amateur golf championship after two rounds today at the Sunny-brook Golf Club.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 -- A group of left-wing intellectuals and labor leaders, including the writers Carlos Fuentes and Octavio Paz, has announced the formation of a new organization to challenge the political monopoly of Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary party.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 23 -- South Korea received a formal notice today that unless she concludes an agreement with the United States to restrict exports of non-cotton textile goods Washington would have to impose mandatory import quotas starting Oct. 15.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23 -- President Tito and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, conferred today for a second day, and the Russian, who arrived yesterday, expressed the belief that the two had succeeded in finding "a common language."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Albania today told the supporters of her resolution to oust Nationalist China from the United Nations that she would ask the General Assembly tomorrow to block from its agenda the item on China sponsored by the United States.

The Redskins are favored over the Giants in New York's home opener Sunday. That brings a partial blackout with two games on television, Dallas at Philadelphia, Channel 2 at 1 P.M., and Oakland at San Diego, Channel, 4, 4 P.M.

AREA A -- Good catches of blues are reported the length of Long Beach Island by surf fishermen. The blues, ranging from two to six pounds, are being taken on metal lures and mullet. There are some weakfish in the surf, also biting on metal and bait.

TOKYO, Sept. 23 -- The opposition Komeito, or Clean Government party, ended its annual convention today with a new program of political action intended to further its efforts to become a national rather than religious party.
LONDON, Sept. 23, (Reuters) -- British military authorities in Northern Ireland are tightening border security to prevent guerrillas from slipping into the province from the Irish Republic.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Legislation to set up an independent Federal agency with authority to champion and protect consumer interests moved a big step toward House passage today.

With Mayor Lindsay remaining aloof from the continuing struggle for control of the Manhattan Democratic organization, Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti appeared assured yesterday of re-election as Manhattan Democratic leader.

Bill Hampton, the Jets' equipment manager, displayed a special elbow pad at Shea Stadium yesterday designed to cut down skin burns on artificial turf. SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23 -- United States officials have passed the word to South Vietnamese generals that any coup d'etat against President Nguyen Van Thieu in the present elections crisis would lead to the ending of American support.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Vice President Agnew assailed four of the leading Democratic Presidential prospects today, characterizing their support for cuts in defense spending as "reckless and appalling."

KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 23 -- The New York Rangers, one of the National Hockey League's best-rounded squads, pared their training roster to 22 players today, three above the limit for regular-season play.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The nation's savings and loan associations pledged today that they would refrain from raising mortgage interest rates during the 90-day wage and price freeze and throughout all of the Phase Two economic program that is to follow the freeze.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Sept. 18 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period increased.

ROME -- The dizzying spate of art thefts and the resulting public shock have produced calls for stricter surveillance over the Italian artistic patrimony. Premier Emilio Colombo has declared that the Government is already taking measures to play a larger and more efficient role in the protection of works of art.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, -- The 215,000 American servicemen in South Vietnam will be confined to their barracks and places of work until three days after the presidential referendum Oct. 3.

A price war has broken out among the airlines flying the Atlantic. A week ago Lufthansa disavowed a trans-Atlantic fare agreement and offered a $210 round-trip fare between New York and any German city, effective Feb. 1. Agreements by the White House and the Kremlin to switch their ground-based "hot line" to a more reliable satellite communications system and to give each other advance warning of missile launches that might occasion panicky reaction are the first tangible fruits of the two-year-old SALT talks. The announcement of the Nixon Administration to accept the election decision of Nguyen Van Thieu, President of the Vietnam Government, is consistent and logical. Both doctrines were based on the expressed assumption that the people of every state should be free to determine their own political future without outside interference.

For one thing, by retelling stories that are familiar to everyone, she has produced a delightfully accessible book.

The Group of Ten, in its conference in London and now meeting with the International Monetary Fund in Washington to deal with the international monetary crisis, has thus far failed. While our counterparts agreed in principle on exchange rates more favorable for our world trade they insisted on reaching this common aim by devaluation of the dollar rather than revaluation of their currencies.
Attorney General John Mitchell is again asking the courts to give the executive branch the final say on when the Bill of Rights must bend to national security.

Charles Tourine, a reputed Mafioso, once tried to arrange an $8-million loan for Kirk Kerkorian, now the controlling stockholder in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, according to testimony given yesterday before the State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 27 -- General Motors announced here tonight that its Chilean truck assembly plant would stop operations by the end of this year.
Consumer reaction to the price-wage freeze has been overwhelmingly favorable, but it has not produced much improvement in consumer sentiment, the University of Michigan reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Following is Policy Statement Number 25 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90-day freeze on wages and prices:
Three New York City students pleaded yesterday for sex education in American high schools and readily available contraceptive information and devices for anyone who wants them, regardless of age.
Racial disturbances erupted yesterday at high schools in Piscataway and Irvington, N. J.

After just two Sundays of action, only six of pro football's 26 teams remain unbeaten, including such surprises as the Falcons and Bears. Norm Van Brocklin, the Falcon coach, proudly told an Atlanta luncheon audience yesterday, "We can battle with anybody.

City Center's plan to remodel the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, which has raised a storm of controversy in the City Council and cultural circles, will be the subject of another public hearing before the council's Finance Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee voted unanimously at its June 29 meeting to moderate growth in the money supply, it was disclosed today.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- A judge delayed Angela Davis's murder-conspiracy trial today for five more weeks, until Nov. 1, to allow her attorneys time to wind up their arguments on pretrial motions, including a request to move the trial to San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- There was Ray Bolger singing "Once in Love with Mamie," and Lawrence Welk reminiscing and leading the orchestra in "The Yellow Rose of Texas," which was played countless times in the Lyndon Johnson years, but there was an Eisenhower favorite, too, and the "Military Wife of the Century" award (a surprise) and a birthday cake on stage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Top-level United States officials confirmed today that the United States had imposed a deadline for the solution of the textile-import problem involving, Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong.

Robert Young's starring vehicle, "Marcus Welby, M.D.," finished first in the season's intial A.C. Nielsen rating survey released yesterday. Not one of the regularly scheduled new series appeared in the top 10.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -Mayor Lindsay said today that he had "no hesitation" about running in the Presidential primaries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Department of Justice charged the Atlanta Falcons today with increasing their ticket prices in violation of the President's wage and price freeze.
The American Stock Exchange registered its sixth consecutive loss yesterday in lackluster trading.

Last March 11, "after careful review of the situation and the provisions of law," Secretary of Agriculture Hardin announced that for the marketing year beginning April 1, Federal price supports for milk would be pegged at $4.66 a hundred pounds, the same as last year. Dairy farmers angrily complained. On March 23, President Nixon met with a dozen representatives of the dairy industry.

LANDER, Wyo. -- Beneath snow-draped conifers at the Sinks Canyon rifle range, hunters participating in the Lander one-shot antelope hunt gathered round several open fires, where strong black coffee steamed, and warmed numbed fingers before the men stepped to the firing line.

A progress report on the campaign to prevent the relocation of the 299-seat Forum Theater from the basement of the Vivian Beaumont in Lincoln Center to a backstage area will be presented at a meeting of the Drama Desk, the organization of theater writers and editors, at Sardi's Belasco Room on Monday.

Playoff excitement prevailed in Salt Lake City yesterday as the Knicks arrived for a pre-season game against the Utah Stars, champions of the American Basketball Association. It will be the first interleague game for both teams.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 -- "They tell you they're winding down the war -- then you turn around and bang, you're here," the young draftee said after he stepped off the chartered troop carrier at this air base.
The total output of goods and services in the United States will soar by roughly $100-billion in 1972, a broad cross section of business forecasters predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Wright Patman, the chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, accused the Federal Reserve System today of spending money improperly on items ranging from entertainment in Playboy Clubs to bonuses for employes who join a sort of agency-sponsored mutual fund.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- It is no easy thing to run for President under the best of circumstances, and for Senator George McGovern of South Dakota there have been some particularly galling ones.

It has long been a political anomaly that Manhattan Democrats, who form one of the nation's most progressive constituencies, have been led by a backward-looking politician out of yesterday's era of smoke-filled rooms. Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, recently re-elected to his post as district leader, intends to move Thursday to secure re-election as Manhattan's Democratic county leader, thus keeping intact a type of control little changed from the heyday of Tammany Hall.

Another step in the campaign to cut the backlog of criminal cases in the city's courtrooms was taken last evening when a Bronx Night Court was opened for the arraignment and disposition of charges ranging from disorderly conduct to homicide.

A Manhattan Democratic district leader challenging the reelection of Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti as Democratic county leader said yesterday that he would seek the help of Mayor Lindsay in his effort.

If Georgia McMurray has her way, the city's child care programs will be vastly expanded and in some ways revolutionized. And if past performance is any indication, the 36-year-old head of the city's new Agency for Child Development has a very good chance of getting her way.

Investors Diverisfied Services, Inc., the nation's largest mutual-fund organization, has reactivated its application to join the New York Stock Exchange through Jefferies Co., an I.D.S. brokerage subsidiary.

CENTEREACH, L. I., Sept. 27 -- The school board of the Middle Country School District tonight ratified a contract with the striking teachers association, ending a four-day walkout of the 850-member union in the district.

HYDERABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 12 -- The clamor for independence in West Pakistan's province of Sind has been muted almost completely, apparently as a result of the failure of the secessionist movement in East Pakistan.

Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, recently re-elected to his post as district leader, intends to move Thursday to secure re-election as Manhattan's Democratic county leader, thus keeping intact a type of control little changed from the heyday of Tammany Hall.

On Aug. 23 The Times published a review by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt of Ronald W. Clark's new book, "Einstein.'' This review was completely unworthy of The Times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the broker-dealer registration of the J. H. Rapp Company, Kenilworth, N.J., which had been accused of selling unregistered stock at artifically inflated prices.

The RCA Corporation has dismissed 2,000 workers in its computer - systems group, or about 20 per cent of the group's work force, as part of the company's plan to withdraw from the general-purpose computer business.

" My doctor tells me I have the heart of a 40-year-old man," said Wayne Morse, the former Senator from Oregon. Therefore, Mr. Morse has decided to run against Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican, next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The House of Sounds Festival, the first jazz presentation at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, wound up its three-day stand in the center's Concert Hall yesterday with nine hours of music -- four in the afternoon, five at night.

Offtrack betting's "typical" customer emerged from a market survey here yesterday as a white, middle-class, middle-aged unmarried male who plays the horses regularly, yet supposedly has more brains and money than his neighbor.

Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union expressed a "vigorous protest" here yesterday over Britain's decision to expel alleged Soviet spies and indicated to Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the British Foreign Secretary, that Moscow felt obliged to retaliate in some fashion.
Bohemia Stable's Lucky Ole Me, a filly who failed to win in four outings last year, registered her third straight victory yesterday at Belmont Park.

NEWARK, Sept. 27 -- Two 18-year-old draftees were arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today after they allegedly set fire to their processing papers while awaiting pre-induction physical examinations.

Swissair yesterday became the fourth airline to break away from a disputed International Air Transport Association fares agreement. It announced that it would offer a $180 round-trip group fare between New York and Switzerland, beginning Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Rev. Billy Graham, the New York Yankees and the New York Giants were among 60 people or groups backing assertions by WPIX-TV today that its programing serves the community interest.
ROME, Sept. 27 (UPI)--Italy's latest and much-publicized wave of major art thefts touched off a nationwide police effort that is having notable success in recovering stolen masterworks.

Yale University announced yesterday that one alumnus, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, the chairman of the board of Phillip Morris, Inc., had pledged $1-million to the Yale Alumni Fund over the next two years as a challenge to other alumni.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (UPI) --- General Foods of the United States pulled out today from involvement in bids to save the Lines Brothers Group, one of Britain's largest toy concerns, and said it would defer further action until liquidation proceedings were complete.
Clever is as clever does, and the Black Light Theater of Prague, which returned to the City Center last night, takes ingenuity to the point of ingenuousness.
School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner refused yesterday to extend today's deadline for compliance with mandated budget cuts by the community school board of District 5 in Central Harlem.

For the nation's biggest makers of atlases, this is the time of the major "model change" each decade, the publication of "new census" editions. They have tackled the awesome updating task -- hundreds of new maps, spectacular earth photographs from space, and more than 100,000 entries -- from A to Zip.

A claim of foul, a brief exhibition of unscheduled Wild West riding and a 2 1/4-length victory by Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s 7-to-10 Shadow Brook provided the highlights of yesterday's 63d running of the $33,480 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 29 (AP) -B-52 bombers struck in three waves near the Cambodian border today in an attempt to break up North Vietnamese forces that are reported on the offensive along the CambodianSouth Vietnamese border.
Hill Wang, for more than a decade a specialized publisher in American history and drama books, has been acquired by Farrar, Straus Giroux, a leading literary house.
John P. Fishwick, president of the Norfolk Western Railway, yesterday gave a terse description of his road's current business: "It's lousy."

LONDON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The London free market price of gold suddenly shot up today to its highest point since the days immediately after President Nixon's Aug. 15 move suspending the convertibility of the dollar into gold.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 28 -- Emperor Hirohito, of Japan took the tourist route around Denmark today on the first full day of his seven-nation European tour.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The British, Irish and Northern Ireland Prime Ministers joined today in urging a "process of political reconciliation" in troubled Ulster. But they left the specific problems unresolved.

At least 10 per cent of the income of residents of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn -- $58 million annually -- goes to organized crime, according to a study disclosed at a hearing yesterday before the State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

History seems to be repeating itself in South Vietnam. Radical students and Buddhists have taken to city streets, fire bombs and weapons in hand, ostensibly to protest President Thieu's upcoming nonelection but more likely as an expression of traditional Buddhist and student disaffection from any predominantly Catholic government in South Vietnam.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 28 -- To the accompaniment of Count Basie and his 22-piece orchestra, the San Francisco Giants won their half of the Western Sweepstakes tonight with a ringing 7-1 victory over the San Diego Padres.

All 5,000 to 6,000 substitute teachers in the city will not get their salary checks Friday, the first payday of the new school year, because of payroll processing problems and steps taken to prevent excessive hiring and overspending by local school districts.

MOSCOW, Sept 28 -- Chess experts surveyed by Tass the official Soviet press agency, give Bobby Fischer, the American champion, a slight edge over his Soviet opponent in the forthcoming international chess matches.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 -- Lastminute support by Mayor Carl B. Stokes gave the Democratic nomination for mayor to a wealthy real-estate developer, James M. Carney, in primary elections here today.

Theodore W. Kheel, the attorney and labor mediator, announced his "unalterable opposition" to Governor Rockefeller's transportation bond issue yesterday amid signs that lines were beginning to sharpen for the expected battle over the $2.5-billion proposal.
Longchamps, Inc., announced yesterday the sale of Luchow's, the German restaurant, and four other New York City restaurants to the Riese Organization for about $8-million in cash and notes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans assailed critics of President Nixon's economic policies today, accusing them of making inaccurate statements about the program and of "bringing it into the political arena."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Jim Bunning, of the Philadelphia Phillies, who pitched two no-hitters, one a perfect game, and ranked second in career strike-outs, retired today after 16 years in the major leagues.
Frustrated consumers of America, at last you have a place to turn if you feel you've been duped by an untruthful (lying) or misleading (lying) ad.
PARIS, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Elsa Schiaparelli, who was a dominant influence in international fashions in the nineteen-thirties and forties, sums up in one word how women look these days.

The Cities Service Company announced yesterday the election of Charles J. Waidelich as president, succeeding J. Edgar Heston, who has requested early retirement as president and a director for reasons of health, effective Oct. 1.

Lee Slurzberg Research did a survey of 500 Negroes in 20 urban areas to see how well advertising slogans are being remembered. The highest recall was for "Flo through tea bags" by Lipton with a 79 per cent.

Before introducing a new product, businesses test its acceptance by the public in several cities and towns. Repeated efforts have been made to apply this elementary concept of market research to new Federal programs, but political courage and administrative firmness usually fail before the test can be carried out properly.

ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Attica townspeople reported today that widows and other relatives of guards held hostage during the prison revolt here were being harassed by anonymous phone callers and unidentified youths who had thrown stones at their houses
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The so-called nonaligned countries, mainly African and Asian, have agreed on an approach designed to increase their influence on the big powers.
WARSAW -- Several hundred musicians from about 20 countries gathered here last week to take part in the 15th "Warsaw Autumn," the largest annual festival of contemporary music in Eastern Europe.
Morrison, Inc., a food service concern, raised its dividend yesterday but said it did not believe it was defying the President's wage-price freeze.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Census figures released today substantiate the complaint of Mayors across the country that city expenses have been rising faster than revenues.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The first exhibition of any painter or sculptor working in this country is eligible for a Government subsidy equivalent to half the show's cost, under a new project of the French Ministry of Culture.

Columbia has not defeated Princeton in 20 years, and that, says the Tigers' coach, Jake McCandless, "is a terrible albatross to have around our necks. Every year the number increases, the pressure builds on us.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Without anyone noticing, this country has moved remarkably close to choosing one of its Presidential candidates by a national primary.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 -- A military court today sentenced Lady Fleming, the Greek-born widow of the discoverer of penicillin, to 16 months in prison for her part in an unsuccessful plot to help a would-be assassin escape from prison.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Nixon put in an unexpected appearance this afternoon at the funeral of former Associate Justice Hugo L .Black, and heard a sermon on the unsuitability of "strict constructionists" for the Supreme Court.

Three hundred and thirty persons were evacuated from a train in the Park Avenue tunnel yesterday morning because of an electrical fire in the engine of a Harlem line Penn Central railroad train as it was about to pull into Grand Central Terminal. No on was injured.

ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- State Senator John R. Dunne, chairman of the Senate Committee on Crime and Correction, walked through the cell- blocks of the Attica Correctional Facility today, but State Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald barred him from talking with inmates.

Two men were sentenced in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges stemming from the slaying of an off-duty patrolman. During their trial here last summer, they changed their pleas to guilty.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 28 -- The Government of Pakistan said today that the secret military trial of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Bengali leader, was continuing, and warned against public speculation about its outcome.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A reorganization of the Bureau of Labor Statistics is now in process, it was confirmed tonight by Geoffrey Moore, Commissioner of Labor Statistics.

WALPOLE, Mass., Sept. 28 -- The two-day-old work strikes by prisoners at two state institutions near here showed no signs of ending today. Correction officials and prisoners' committees continued to negotiate over the prisoners' demands.

The Metropolitan Opera, in what it called a White Paper covering its operations for the last 10 years, yesterday presented its case as an organization deserving and desperately needing subsidy from major foundations and government at all levels.
WASHINGTON, Sept 28 (UPI) -- President Nixon told families of American prisoners of war today that the United States would "eventually succeed" in winning their release.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- The San Francisco County grand jury has decided to indict on a local charge two men who are under suspicion for possible involvement in the slaying of two New York policemen.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Prospects for a partial settlement between Egypt and Israel were described as extremely dim here today after recent consultations among the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four and other diplomatic exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Three months after he assumed the task of leading President Nixon's drive against drug addiction, Dr. Jerome K. Jaffe is moving to fill an information void that he and other experts on drugs have said is a major obstacle to development of a national program to combat the problem.
A Queens housewife who was a guard-supervisor in Nazi concentration and death camps during World War II lost her American citizenship yesterday.
A dissenting voice should be heard. The public, at least that part of it to which I belong, does not buy prison reform.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had launched an unmanned spacecraft, Luna 19, toward the moon.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Bob Mosbacher of Houston, the North American champion, moved into the series lead of the world Soling Class championship today after finishing second in the third race on Long Island Sound.
Selection of a citizens' committee to conduct "a full and impartial investigation of all the facts" in the Attica prison uprising is proving elusive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The United States and Thailand formally agreed today to cooperate in an effort to combat the growing narcotics traffic in Southeast Asia.

Everybody seemed to be trying to help Steve Carlton of the Cardinals gain his 20th victory of the season yesterday, even the New York Mets, who eventually lost, 5-2, to the St. Louis left-hander before 3,338 fans, the smallest crowd in Shea Stadium this season.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 28 -- Twenty-seven participants in a secret caucus of black officials in Chicago last weekend have mailed a letter to President Nixon recommending the appointment of an Alabama Federal District Judge to the United States Supreme Court.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- Paul W. McCracken, the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said here today that basic problems in the structure of international finance had played a major role in creating the world monetary crisis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Following is Policy Statement Number 26 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest ruling relative to the 90-day freeze on wages and prices:

A special three-judge Federal panel yesterday declared unconstitutional a new state election law that bars major party candidates from accepting the nomination of small political groups in local elections.
The identity of a current member of the police force for whom Hugh Mulligan allegedly sought a promotion two years ago was disclosed in court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California said today that the Central Intelligence Agency was recruiting Americans to become combat mercenaries in Laos.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Mayor Lindsay, testing the climate in California for his potential candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, indicated today in San Francisco that he was not interested in being Vice President.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff estimated today that the United states would provide about $51-billion in foreign assistance over the next five years, with the possibility that the total would go higher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Congressional hearings on freedom of the press opened today with suggestions that the concept was threatened by the Nixon Administration. The White House denied that the suggestion was valid and said the press was too sensitive on the subject.
Roy Innis, the national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, announced yesterday that the organization's 30th annual convention would be held in Harlem.
To the anger and dismay of sports fans, commuters and security men, a new breed of aggressive derelicts is operating around Madison Square Garden and Pennsylvania Station.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 -- The setting sun marked a brief truce of the divisions and arguments within Israel tonight, as Jews in Jerusalem and the world over observed the most solemn day of the Hebrew year -- Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

CLAIRVAUX, France, Sept. 27 -- Only the barking of dogs broke the silence of the wooded valley, tinted with the first gold of autumn. In the bar across the road from the prison, men moodily drank their beer or red wine, and glared suspiciously at a stranger.
Dean Candido de Leon was named yesterday president of the City University of New York's Eugenio Maria de Hostos Community College in the South Bronx.

How to prevent excessively slow play in matches of great importance is a problem that has never been satisfactorily solved. In international championships, it is usual to impose penalties on teams that repeatedly exceed the allotted time for a session. These rarely have any impact, although a slow-play penalty hassle in a European women's championship once resulted in an official verdict that no team had won.

FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 28 -- Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers said today that Col. Oran K. Henderson had testified before a Pentagon board of inquiry that he had been aware on the day of the attack on Mylai 4 that a number of old men, women and children had been killed.

Judge Edward C. McLean withheld a decision yesterday after hearing arguments on a proposed $5-million settlement agreed upon by 10 original shareholders in the Dreyfus Corporation and Abraham L. Pomerantz, who represented a client who had charged that the 10 profited illegally by selling Dreyfus shares to the public in 1965.

Negotiations resumed Monday night between representatives of five major movie companies in New York and Local 52, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators.
Roy M. Conn was described by his defense lawyer in Federal Court here yesterday as the "mastermind" of lengthy condemnation proceedings that won $55-million for Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 28 (AP) -- State officials moved today to crack down on unethical sales of municipal bonds by what they described as a "few bond dealers in the city of Memphis and conceivably elsewhere in the state of Tennessee."
STUPIDVILLE,. Tenn., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Sam Briggs's son, Larry, says his father is not qualified to be Mayor of Stupidville. On technical grounds, that is.

The destruction of the Ladies Pavilion by vandals focuses attention on only one of our threatened works of public art. In Central Park alone there are probably a dozen other exceptional structures in immediate need of emergency repairs and rehabilitation, including the Terrace, Bow Bridge, and the gem-like Bridlepath Arch north of the Reservoir.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Germany warned its Common Market partners today that it will not permit its farmers to suffer a loss of income as a result of a revaluation of the mark.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Although the lame duck Senators topped the Yankees, 4-2, tonight at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, the high point of the evening for the 3,242 fans who turned out for an almost final look at the Senators came in the fifth inning.

Your Sept. 17 editorial "Moratorium on Excellence" says, "The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation's concern with excellence is scarcely obsolete" and points out the "continuing need to seek out and encourage outstanding teaching potential." However, you place the blame for the program's current lack of funds on the "deplorable lack of foresight by those foundations that have kept the fellowship competition alive since the Ford Foundation terminated most of its support."

TALLULAH, La., Sept. 27 -- Talking around an ever-present cigar, Police Chief Zelma Wyche thumbed through the posted notices at the Madison Parish Courthouse that showed black candidates competing for 22 of 27 elective parish offices this fall.

As the new commercial television season stumbles through its third full week of heavily revised schedules, one conclusion is inescapable: It may not be the worst new season on record but it is very probably the dullest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The director of the Navy's claims review office charged today that four members of Congress had applied "unreasonable pressure" in a multimillion-dollar cost overrun case.
The Bronfman family, whose members head the Seagram whisky interests, has changed its mind about selling most of its stock in the Rheingold Corporation, the large brewing company.

The Department of Transportation, after five years of study, has come to a conclusion that seemed inescapable from the start: high-speed trains are the only sensible answer to the traffic problem in such highly traveled areas as the Northeast Corridor linking Boston, New York and Washington.

WASHINGTON -- After being around the White House for a while in connection with a book, I have news for the pouting panjandrums of the Righteous Right: their erstwhile hero, Richard Nixon, whom they have now abandoned with some fanfare, is still a perfectly decent and well-meaning man who deserves the same tolerance and the same chance as anybody else in trying to solve the problems of this complex and uneasy land.
Second-guessers of Alex Webster, head coach of the New York Giants, will have to get in line -- behind Alex Webster.
A Jamaica, Queens, market that processed meat without having it inspected was fined $1,000 last month, the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets announced yesterday.

As the New York Jets' chartered airliner taxied to its gate at LaGuardia Airport early yesterday, a burst of laughter resounded from where the players were sitting in the rear. Up front, Coach Weeb Ewbank spun in anger.
As Jews observed Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, vith all-day fasting and prayers, rabbis pleaded in sermons for a daily taking of spiritual and moral inventory to improve the lives of others.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 -- President Salvador Allende Gossens today deducted $774-million in alleged excess profits from the compensation to be paid to United States companies for three copper mines nationalized this year.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept 28 -- The County Legislature today commissioned a study of the ability of Suffolk County's resources to sustain its population -- a study that could lead to limitations on the future population of the county.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Pressed by President Nixon, Department of the Interior officials are moving to make major policy changes in the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
Soybean futures closed fractionally higher and wheat futures declined on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
The stock market won a token victory yesterday as prices advanced for the first time in seven sessions.

WARSAW, Sept. 28 -- Britain's decision to expel Soviet diplomats accused of spying is being treated in Eastern Europe as a deliberate attempt to sabotage the relaxation of tensions in Europe. Washington was said to be behind the move.
The tax-exempt bond market took a big step toward lower interest rates yesterday as it shouldered half a billion dollars worth of new issues -- including New York City's $334.86-million -- with ease.
You may remember Lord Hardwicke, Ltd. -- a franchise promotion like lots of others back in the bull market of 1969.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Russell G. Oswald, State Commissioner of Correction, said today that his department was seeking a facility to house as many as 500 of the system's most aggressive inmates, so they could be isolated from the rest of the state's 16,000 prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The White House, in a policy shift, announced its support today of legislation to create an independent Federal agency with authority to advocate and defend consumer interests.

An emotional disturbance should be treated no differently from a physical ailment in baseball, an arbitration board ruled yesterday in ordering the California Angels to restore full pay to their recalcitrant outfielder, Alex Johnson.
Andy Messersmith became the third pitcher in California Angels' history to win 20 games in one season as he beat the Minnesota Twins, 6-2.
MELVILLE, L. I., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Potter Instrument Company said today it had resolved a patent dispute with the International Business Machines Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that his Government "in principle" regarded the improvement of relations between Washington and Peking "as a natural development."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, said today that it planned a major improvement in rail service this fall.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 28 -- The New York Knicks took a liking to the American Basketball Association's red, white and blue ball and the 3-point goal and held off the A.B.A. champion Utah Stars, 96-89, tonight for their fourth pro-season victory without a loss.
MIAMI, Sept. 28 -- Premier Fidel Castro, speaking about the end of the Cuban refugee airlift, tonight warned the United States not to encourage escapes by boats from Cuba.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 -The state has agreed to equip all guards in state prisons with riot helmets that have face shields, and with gas masks, an official of the uniformed guards' union said today.At present, the union maintains, only 5 per cent of the guards have such riot-control equipment, and some of the gas masks are said to date back to World War I.
Improved earnings were reported yesterday by the Avco Corporation for the quarter and nine-month period ended Aug. 31.

The summit meeting on Northern Ireland achieved everything that could have been hoped for it at this critical stage. There was no break-up, no walkout and, so far, no recrimination or public posturing for narrow political purposes. The three Prime Ministers joined in condemning violence and in promising to try to End both violence and internment "without delay." They agreed that their discussions had served a useful purpose and that additional meetings might be helpful.
DOVER, Del., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Delaware State College, loser of its first two football games, suspended 13 unidentified players today as the result of a drug abuse investigation.
Antiwar activists will lead demonstrations Saturday at prison facilities across the nation to urge reform in prison policies in the United States and South Vietnam.

It is almost impossible not to be caught up at once by the plot of Sol Stein's second novel, "The Magician." Ed Japhet, an extremely talented Ossining, N. Y., high-school student, puts on a magic show for his fellow students. It is a thundering success. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and said that while "some steady progress" had been made in the talks on limiting strategic arms he hoped for more "forward movement" when the discussion resume in Vienna Nov. 15.

If the Giant-Dodger race for the Western Division title goes to the final day, it will be the 10th time in the last 26 years that the National League has enjoyed this ultimate in pennant suspense. To the Editor:The Op-Ed article by Bernard Lande Cohen (Sept. 15) parades once again exploded arguments in favor of capital punishment. Most murders, despite movie and TV scripts to the contrary, are not premeditated (in the layman's sense, not the lawyer's). Rather, they are volcanoes of emotion, not directed by reason, and hence not restrained by fear of penalty, even death, or other rational considerations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- A Senate securities subcommittee heard proposals today that a nongovernmental coordinating agency be created to handle a mounting paperwork logjam that, it was said, threatened to inundate the stock certificate transfer process.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, was among a number of speakers here today who urged greatly increased cooperation between the state's public and private colleges during the current period of financial difficulty in higher education

Edward T. McCormick, president of the National Stock Exchange and a former president of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he would retire Nov. 1 and leave Wall Street after a 36-year relationship with the securities industry.

The New York Stock Exchange, in a break with tradition, disclosed yesterday that it was seeking advice from the heads of all its listed companies on how the exchange should be reorganized. The Big Board has been criticized at times for having what has been described as a parochial attitude and for being operated as a so-called "private club" that did not have the public interest as its paramount concern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The leaders of nine national education organizations told President Nixon today that the Federal share of public education costs should be increased from 8 per cent to 40 per cent to relieve the heavy tax burden on property owners.

Over the last three weeks small teams of French policemen have quietly arrested 43 suspected members of one of the major European rings supplying heroin to organized crime in the United States. At the same time the Spanish police tracked down two Corsican gangsters, living in Madrid, who are believed to head the ring.
Dockworkers will not be on their jobs today, as negotiations broke off early this morning here between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.
Sydenham Hospital announced yesterday that it would open a comprehensive family-care center next week that was expected to "replace the emergency room as the family doctor."

A 36-year-old woman, trying to escape through the 12th-floor window of her midtown hotel apartment while another woman was being raped by an armed youth inside, plunged to her death last night when knotted bedsheets she was using came apart.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary will meet Saturday morning in New York to consider the qualifications of Representative Richard H. Poff, Republican of Virginia, for the Supreme Court.
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y. -- The question is a painful one, and the women here waited a long while before they started asking it, even of themselves.

Ruth Welting, a child-sized soprano whose voice is already much too big to ride half-fare, and probably still growing, sang her first Oscar with the New York City Opera on Wednesday in Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera."

The stock market, shaking its recent lethargy, posted a gain yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average, the market's most closely-watched barometer, had declined seven times in the last eight sessions, prior to yesterday's mild snapback.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel proposed today that he and Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad of Egypt meet here in the immediate future to discuss peace in the Middle East.

The majority leader of the State Senate, Earl W. Brydges, reportedly upset by State Senator John R. Dunne's widely publicized one-man tour of the state's prisons, probably will not recommend Mr. Dunne to be chairman of a commission that will suggest legislative penal reform in the light of the Attica revolt. The commission is expected to be named soon.

Tamut, the Egyptian handmaiden, will not be found in any anthology of the women's liberation movement. But a new scholarly examination of her 2-420-year-old marriage contract has disclosed that she was well ahead of her time in asserting a wife's equality in such matters as property and divorce.
In the menus below the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

DURHAM, N. H., Sept. 30 -- Dr. Thomas N. Bonner was inaugurated as president of the University of New Hampshire today after a delegation of administrators and faculty members from the University of Cincinnati came here to attack news reports critical of him.
The drive for a November referendum to make New York City a separate state was set back yesterday when City Clerk Herman Katz rejected a petition with more than 50,000 signatures.

Senator Fred R. Harris, who a week ago declared his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, came to New York yesterday and called for the breakup of most of the country's major corporations.

In his column of Sept. 23 Tom Wicker contends that the one-man election in South Vietnam would destroy "the familiar 'self-determination' rationale for continuing the war." He believes that it could trigger a resurgence of antiwar dissent and have an "incendiary" political effect in this country.
The Federal Reserve System pumped $1.1-billion into the money market during the week ended Wednesday, the central bank's weekly statement showed yeseterday.

The game of the weekend is in Dallas, where the Cowboys and Redskins, both unbeaten, meet in the Cotton Bowl. But that one will not be on television here. Instead the Sunday fare is San Francisco at Philadelphia, Channel 2, 1 P.M., followed by the Giants' game from St. Louis.

A steal-to-order ring that specialized in heavy-construction equipment was smashed yesterday after Federal and local authorities ended a four-month investigation, uncovering more than $100,000 worth of equipment that included bulldozers, tractor-trailers and dump trucks.
Bill Melton of the Chicago White Sox hit his third home run in 18 hours to win the American League home run championship with 33 as the White Sox beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 2-1.
Warren Weaver's news article of Sept. 20 on the potential impact of young people on the Congressional races goes one step short: the Presidency itself may very well be affected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- In the whole mysterious gift of life, what most astonishes and excites is diversity. No two human beings are the same. The tiniest snowflake, the most distant star, the intricately veined leaf of a tree are each unique. From jack rabbit to giraffe, from crocodile to swan, from tiger to hummingbird, nature delights in Varieties of form and phenomena.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- The Mongolian press agency said today that a Chinese Air Force plane, having apparently lost its bearings on a night flight, penetrated deep into Mongolia earlier this month and crashed, killing nine persons aboard.

PARIS, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- The uncontested South Vietnamese presidential election Sunday came in for some harsh words from Hanoi and the Vietcong today as the stalled Paris peace talks resumed after a two-week break.

A nine-member citizens committee with instruction to conduct a "full and impartial" investigation of all aspects of the Attica prison uprising in which 10 hostages and 32 prisoners were killed was named yesterday by five judges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A formula for allocating Democratic Convention delegates that would have given more power to the large states was overturned today by the United States Court of Appeals here. The unanimous formula of the three-judge appeals court reinstated a formula approved last February by the Democratic National Committee.
The bond market continued to climb yesterday, and the advance pushed interest rates on tax-exempt securities to their lowest levels in nearly six months.

The owner of a Hudson Valley restaurant and his wife were held in $75,000 bail each at their arraignment in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday on charges of kidnapping a 54-year-old Queens man in a dispute over the disappearance of $600,000 worth of rare coins.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The Foreign Office today identified the Soviet agent who defected to Britain early in September as Oleg Lyalin.

Senator Fred R. Harris, the Oklahoma Democrat who is running for the nomination for President, came to New York yesterday to underscore a major theme of his populist campaign -- breaking up business monopolies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Sept. 25 was below the volume in the corresponding week last year. Intercity truck tonnage increased 4.1 per cent in the week.

The Broadway theater season, opened last night as the curtain rang up on "Solitaire, Double Solitaire," Robert Anderson's program of two plays, at the John Golden Theater, and all indications were that the big midtown houses would be busier than they were last season.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has arranged a "seasonal swap" of natural gas with the Consolidated Edison Company, Gordon C. Griswold, president, told a luncheon meeting of security analysts yesterday.

The 78-year-old National Biscuit Company, which has a purchase option on a 120-acre golf course near Morristown, N. J., confirmed yesterday that it was considering moving its national headquarters from New York City.

The directors of the 18 municipal hospitals here charged yesterday that Dr. Joseph English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, had concentrated greater power in the central office rather than giving them more local autonomy as promised when the corporation took over the system 15 months ago.

The death of a civilization and the death of a marriage -- these are the formidable topics Robert Anderson takes on in his double bill "Solitaire, Double Solitaire," which opened last night at the John Golden Theater. This is the first new play, -- or plays -- of the sluggard Broadway season, and their craftsmanship and insights are most welcome.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Mortgage lending by savings and loan associations remained at near-record volume in August despite a reduced savings flow, Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Walter Cronkite, the television journalist, said today that the Government had too much power over the press, but a law professor asserted that the press had too much power over public expression

TOKYO, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- The United States told Japan today that import quotas would be imposed on Japanese textiles on Oct. 15, unless a plan for settlement of the long-standing dispute was accepted.
MADRID, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Nearly complete returns indicated today that the only two candidates in Spain's general election who showed some opposition to the Government had been elected to Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Legislation to strip professional baseball and football of anti-trust exemptions was introduced in Congress today by Senator Sam J. Ervin, Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, and Representative Emmanuel Celler, Democrat of New York.

SAIGON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States command announced today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week. It was the first time in 11 weeks that United States combat deaths exceeded 20.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- President Nikolai V. Podgorny left here today for Hanoi at the head of a high-ranking economic and military delegation in what was viewed as an attempt to court North Vietnam's favor after a similar effort by Peking.

An insurgent group of rank-and-file transit workers filed pledge cards of support yesterday with the State Public Employment Relations Board in a campaign to displace the Transport Workers Union as bargaining agent for 30,000 Transit Authority workers.

DENVER, Oct. 1 -- Delegates to the Consultation on Church Union stressed their commitment to racial justice yesterday as they approved a series of recommendations to revitalize their goal of uniting nine Protestant denominations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally said today that there was still a disagreement among members of the Cost of Living Council about the kind of controls that should be instituted in Phase Two of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.
John Riggins, the New York Jets' running back, soared above a pile of linemen toward the goal line. Touchdown or not?

UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 1 -- Foreign Minister Clodomiro Almeyda of Chile declared today that his Government's policy of nationalizing foreign mining interests was covered by a "solemnly declared United Nations principle" -- the right to economic independence.

Two recent reports in the magazine Science have revealed a most significant fact about some of the most noxious gaseous constituents that contribute to air pollution. The authors of these articles have shown that such gases as nitrogen oxides and especially carbon monoxide are removed with remarkable speed and efficiency by soil, particularly potting soil.
A weekend revival program of Yiddish-language feature films with English subtitles, produced here and abroad, will start today at the Anderson Theater, Second Avenue and Fourth Street.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 -- Mysterious happenings in Cairo, cloaked by an Egyptian information blackout, were related here today by travelers from the Egyptian capital.
MIAMI, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Chuck Foreman, who scored two touchdowns, led Miami to a 41-15 victory over Baylor tonight. The victors poured across 20 points in the second quarter.

MILLERSVILLE, Pa., Oct. 1 -- Despite a 20-point performance by Dick Barnett, who played 24 minutes, the New York Knickerbockers suffered their first preseason loss tonight, bowing to the Philadelphia 76ers, 88-81, at Millersville State College.

The nation's railroads placed an embargo yesterday on virtually all freight shipments to struck West Coast ports and announced that a similar ban on rail shipments would go into effect at midnight tomorrow at East and Gulf Coast ports also closed by the longshoremen's strike.

Five natural gas companies in Ohio announced yesterday that because of short supplies they could not accept any new or additional gas loads for industrial customers, effective immediately. They are also imposing limits on new commercial loads to 2,000 cubic feet an hour. Residential customers are not affected by the moves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that a forged letter represented as having been written by him to Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel is being circulated and that he had asked the Justice Department to investigate.

Tektronix, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Earl Wantland, 40 years old, as president. Mr. Wantland succeeds Howard Vollum, 58, the company's president throughout its 25-year history. Mr. Vollum will continue as chairman. Mr. Wantland continues as chief operations officer, a responsibility he has exercised since 1969 as executive vice president. Donald Alvey, Leslie F. Stevens, William Walker and William Polits were elected group vice presidents.

The Times in its Sept. 15 editorial favoring prompt operation of Con Edison's Indian Point No. 2 nuclear facility seems oblivious of the revelations over the last six months of the A.E.C.'s ineptitude in developing a safe, non-polluting nuclear power plant.
ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 1 -- Transfers of mutual-fund advisory contracts to new owners have come to a virtual stand-still in recent weeks and the value of such contracts has plummeted.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that because of lagging tax revenues "attributable to persistent national economic difficulties" the state faced a $470-million deficit for the 1971-72 state fiscal year, which ends March 31.

After reading 429 pages of Jack Newfield, which is a little like being jabbed silly by an opponent who is faster, trickier and with a longer reach, I'd say that Jack Newfield is what we need more of. As those who have read him in The Village Voice know, he's angry, impatient, impassioned and fretful to do something about the latest injustice.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Mayor Lindsay charged tonight that President Nixon "apparently" believed it was to this country's advantage "to create the greatest amount of doubt about what we intend to do and when we intend to do it."
The possibility of a prolonged longshoremen's strike, with a resultant depletion of stocks, caused considerable buying of grain and soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

A Manhattan car-rental concern whose employes allegedly assaulted customers, threatened investigators and lured clients to its office with false promises of low rates was sued this week by the city, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

Musicians love to analyze "Cosi fan tutte," trying to decide whether the characters in Da Ponte's libretto are wholly artificial or have some real blood in them and whether Mozart's music is wholly satiric or reflects genuine human emotions.

To mark his 90th birthday Oct. 25, Pablo Picasso will receive a unique gift from the French government. He will become the first living artist to have his work displayed in the grand gallery of the Louvre.
Clever collectors interested in bronze and brass have been turning to 16th-century work because of the difficulties in locating examples of the 18th century.

" I got one world," Anthony Thomas Palmigiano was saying yesterday, "Pier 11, and my home." The poles of the 47-year-old longshoreman's world are separated by seven blocks of South Brooklyn, and more than two-thirds of his life has been spent between the two.

VIENNA, Oct. 1 -- Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet cellist and conductor, who had reportedly been banned from traveling abroad, has arrived in Vienna to conduct three guest performances of the opera company of Moscow's Bolshoi Theater. He will tour the United States before the end of the year after giving 30 concerts in Japan from Oct. 16 to Nov. 17.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The member nations of the International Monetary Fund unanimously adopted today a non-binding resolution urging "as promptly as possible" a return to relatively fixed exchange rates among currencies "together with the reduction of restrictive trade and exchange practices."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- Anthony J. Russo, who has been imprisoned for 47 days for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Pentagon papers case, agreed today to appear and was set free.
Clinical trials have begun on a reversible vasectomy device that would make it possible for a man's fertility to be turned off or on through a simple operation in a doctor's office.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Steady Star, with Joe O'Brien driving, set a world pacing record today at the Lexington Trots. He did a mile in 1:52 in a time trial to wipe out the old mark of 1:53 3-5 held by Bret Hanover.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- American and Nationalist Chinese textile negotiators failed today to reach agreement on limiting exports to the United States and will meet again tomorrow, official sources said tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- "We will not make unilateral trade concessions to get the American 10 per cent import surtax removed;" a high Common Market official said today as Europeans weighed Treasury Secretary John B. Connally's statement of American monetary and trade objectives in the dollar crisis.
TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- While Japanese textile makers fight to maintain and expand their American markets, they are getting their pants beat off in their own country by Americans.

BUFFALO, Oct. 1 -- Federal Judge John T. Curtin said today that the public was receiving a "one-sided view" of the revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility because newsmen had been barred from interviewing inmates since the uprising was crushed Sept. 13.

LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Oct. 1 -- Walt Disney World, widely heralded as the new colossus of Florida tourism, opened today on a day that was perfect except for one thing: The $400-million attraction drew only a paper-thin crowd.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A team of six experts on rehabilitation of drug addicts returned from two weeks in Vietnam today with the message that the Army was doing a first-class job of treating soldiers involved with drugs. The team called the soldiers' chances of recovery excellent.

An elementary school principal in a poor neighborhood in Brooklyn yesterday challenged district rules that, he said, arbitrarily denied promotion to 10 per cent of fifth-grade pupils, those with reading problems.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1 -- Strike Out, one of two outstanding Canadian-owned standardbreds, cast a strong vote for himself in the competition for the season's pacing honors among 2-year-olds by winning the $81,216 Roosevelt Futurity tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

PEKING, Oct. 1 -- Premier Chou En-lai and other Government leaders, along with tens of thousands of ordinary Chinese, took part in National Day celebrations here today. The celebrations, with the customary giant parade omitted, took place in the capital's parks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- A $45-million antitrust damage suit against the four largest makers of white bread in the United States was filed today in Federal District Court.
Six youths were accused yesterday of throwing four Molotov cocktails at a house owned by a Negro in the Rosedale section of Queens on Sept. 12.

With his planned Tokyo bout with Mac Foster on Nov. 2 canceled because "the people didn't get up the money," Muhammad Ali will oppose Buster Mathis in a 12-round heavyweight bout on Wednesday, Nov. 17, at the Houston Astrodome.
The intricate litigation that led to a $145-million default levy against Howard R. Hughes and the Hughes Tool Company in favor of Trans World Airlines is headed for the United States Supreme Court.
This is a report. It is also, unavoidably, a love letter.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 1 -- The White House said today that it would not immediately invoke the Taft-Hartley Act to suspend the East or West Coast dock strikes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- Neither side would comment today on the course of negotiations in the 90-day-old West Coast strike.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Manufacturers' orders tumbled 0.5 per cent in August after a strong advance the previous month, the Government reported today.
The announcement by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation Thursday of an agreement to refinance its debt brought an expression of support yesterday from a large shareholder.

The Coast Guard command on Governors Island convened a board of inquiry yesterday to investigate sporadic brawls between black and white coastguardsmen on the island recently and allegations of discrimination against black servicemen.
Senator George McGovern, in his first major political appearance here next week, will walk squarely into a Liberal party fight.
The locker was all ready for Chuck Hinton, the newest Jet, when he arrived yesterday at Shea Stadium.
